text.title: You made me secure on my mother’s breast:

pasuk.text: You prepared breasts for a person, upon which to rely for sustenance.

text.title: Upon You, I was cast from birth:

pasuk.text: I was cast from birth since You took me out of the womb, as Scripture states (in Isa. 46:3): “who are carried from birth.” From the time the tribes were born, He carried them and led them.
Mighty kingdoms.
That too is an expression of the bulls of Bashan, which are fat.
Heb. כתרוני. They encompassed me like a crown (כתר), which encompasses the head.
Nebuchadnezzar.
Wax, which melts from the heat of the fire.

Heb. מלקוחי. This is the palate which is called palayc (palais) in Old French, gaumen in German. When a person is distressed, he has no saliva in his mouth. Menachem, however, interprets מלקוחי as etenayles in Old French (tongs), like (Isa. 6:6): “with tongs (במלקחים) he had taken it.” And the מלקוח is the teeth, which resemble a smith’s tongs. (The quotation from Menachem appears only in the Salonika edition of Rashi printed in 1515.)

text.title: and in the dust of death:

pasuk.text: To the crushing of death.

Heb. תשפתני You set me down, an expression of setting a pot, as (in Ezek. 24:3, II Kings 4:38): “set on (שפת) the pot.” Menachem (p. 179) interprets every expression of שפיתה as an expression of placing.

text.title: like a lion, my hands and feet:

pasuk.text: As though they are crushed in a lion’s mouth, and so did Hezekiah say (in Isa. 38: 13): “like a lion, so it would break all my bones.”

text.title: I tell about all my bones:

pasuk.text: The pain of my bones.
They rejoice at my misfortune.

text.title: and cast lots for my raiment:

pasuk.text: They plunder our property.
Heb. אילותי, my strength, as (below 88: 5): “I was as a man without strength (איל) ,” and as (Gen. 31: 29): “It is within the power (לאל) of my hand.”

text.title: Save me from the lion’s mouth:

pasuk.text: as You answered me from the horns of the wild oxen. This is the Amorite, “whose height is as the height of the cedar trees” (Amos 2:9); the thirty-one kings.

text.title: I will tell Your name to my brothers:

pasuk.text: when any of my assemblies gathers, and so I will say to them, “You who fear the Lord, praise Him.” This refers to the proselytes, and “all the seed of Jacob.”
Heb. וגורו, an expression of fear.

Every [expression of] עניה in Scripture is an expression of a cry. ענות can also be interpreted as an expression of humility, as (in Exod. 10: 3): “to humble yourself (לענת),” because he (the poor man) humbles himself and prays before You.
at the time of our redemption in the days of our Messiah.
I will say all this before them.

text.title: shall remember and return to the Lord:

pasuk.text: The nations shall remember the evil that befell us when they see the good and return to the Lord.

text.title: For the kingship is the Lord’s:

pasuk.text: For they will see that the kingship and the rule has returned to You.

text.title: They shall eat all the best of the earth and prostrate themselves:

pasuk.text: Lit. they shall eat and prostrate themselves all the best of the earth. This is a transposed verse. The humble shall eat all the best of the earth and prostrate themselves to the Lord with praise and thanksgiving for the good. דשני means the good, the fat of the earth. [People at] all the ends of the earth will see all this and return to the Lord.
Then all the dead of nations [will kneel] from Gehinnom but He will not have mercy upon them to revive their souls from Gehinnom.
[The soul] of each one.
Lit. He did not quicken. Our Sages (Mid. Ps. 22:32) derived from this verse that the dead, before their death, at the time their soul is taken, see the countenance of the Shechinah.
The seed of Israel, who constantly worship Him.

text.title: it shall be told to the generation concerning the Lord:

pasuk.text: Transpose the verse and explain it thus: It shall be told to the last generation in the name of the Lord and in His praise what He did for that seed.
The first ones shall come and tell His righteousness to the newborn people, for He performed righteous deeds for them.

The Rabbis said: Wherever it says: “A song of David,” he would play [his musical instrument] and afterwards the Shechinah would rest on him. It is a song to bring the holy spirit upon David. And, wherever it says: “Of David, a song,” the Shechinah rested on him [first] and then he recited a song.
In this desert where I am going, [therefore] I am confident that I will lack nothing.

In grassy pastures. Since he commences to compare his sustenance to the pasture of an animal by saying, “The Lord is my shepherd”, “green pastures” is appropriate for the expression, “the Lord is my shepherd.” David recited this psalm in the forest of Hereth (I Sam. 22:5). Why was it called Hereth? Because it was as dry as a potsherd (חרס) and the Holy One, blessed be He, moistened it with the good of the world to come (Mid. Ps. 23:6).
My spirit, which has been weakened by troubles and haste, He will restore to its previous status.
In straight paths, so that I should not fall into the hands of my enemies.
Heb. צלמות, in a land of darkness. He alludes to the desert of Ziph (I Sam. 23:13 28). Every [mention of] צלמות is an expression of darkness. Dunash ben Labrat defined it [in this manner].

The pains that came upon me, and the support, that I rely upon Your loving kindnessboth of them will comfort me, for they will serve to expiate my iniquity, and I am confident that You will set a table before me. That is the throne.

text.title: You anointed my head with oil:

pasuk.text: I have already been anointed king by Your orders.
Heb. רויה, an expression of fullness.
The land of Israel.
The other lands.
Seven seas surrounded Eretz Yisroel and four rivers: the Jordan, Yarmuk, Karmion, and Pigah.

text.title: Who will ascend upon the Lord’s mount:

pasuk.text: Although all the inhabitants of the world are His, not everyone deserves to come near to Him, except these: he who has clean hands, etc.

text.title: who has not taken My name in vain:

pasuk.text: Who has not sworn with My name and My soul in vain. We find an expression of an oath used with the soul (נפש) , as it is stated (in Amos 6:8): “The Lord God swore by Himself (בנפשו).”
[generation,] whose deeds are such - this is the generation of those who seek him.

In the days of Solomon his son, when he comes to bring the Ark into the Holy of Holies and the gates cling to each other, he [Solomon] recited twenty-four praises, but he was not answered until he said (II Chron. 6:42): “Do not turn back the face of Your anointed; remember the kind deeds of David, Your servant.”
Portals whose sanctity is everlasting.

text.title: I will lift up my soul:

pasuk.text: I will direct my heart.

text.title: those who betray [to the extent of] destitution:

pasuk.text: Robbers and impounders, who leave the poor destitute of their property, as (above 7:5): “and I stripped my adversary into emptiness (ריקם).”
Heb. הדריבני, adreza moy in Old French.

text.title: I hope for You all day long:

pasuk.text: That is this world, which is day for the nations of the world and night for Israel.

text.title: for they have been since time immemorial:

pasuk.text: Since the days of Adam, to whom You said, (Gen. 2:17), “for on the day that you eat from it you must die,” but You gave him Your day, which is a thousand years.

text.title: what is worthy of Your kindness, You remember for me:

pasuk.text: What is deserving of Your kindness remember for me. These are the good deeds on my record.

text.title: The Lord is good and upright:

pasuk.text: and wishes to exonerate His creatures.

text.title: therefore, He leads sinners on the road:

pasuk.text: of repentance. Another explanation: He leads sinners, meaning murderers [who flee to the cities of refuge], as it is said (in Deut. 19:3): “You shall prepare for yourself the road, etc.” Refuge, refuge," was written at the crossroads, etc., as is stated in Makkoth, chapter 2 (10b).
[For the sake of Your] great [name], forgive my iniquity…
For it is fitting for a great One to forgive great iniquity.

text.title: Who is this man who fears the Lord?:

pasuk.text: The Holy One, blessed be He, will guide him on the road that he chooses; that is the good road.

text.title: His soul shall abide in prosperity:

pasuk.text: When he abides in the grave, his soul shall abide in prosperity.

text.title: for I am alone and poor:

pasuk.text: and the eyes of the public are directed toward me, and compared to them, I am a single person. Therefore, turn to me and be gracious to me because my prayer is necessary for the salvation of all Israel.

text.title: See my affliction and my toil:

pasuk.text: and through them, forgive all my sins.

text.title: and they hate me with unjust hatred:

pasuk.text: Heb. חמס, unlawful.
Heb. יצרוני, shall watch me.
Heb. יצרוני, shall watch me.

And elsewhere (143:2) he says, “You shall not enter judgment [with Your servant].” Said David: When You judge the wicked, judge me, for compared to the wicked, I am a righteous man, but when You judge the righteous, do not bring me into judgment.
who go into hidden places to do their deeds in the dark.
I am not accustomed to come and enter their assembly.
For there is no robbery [involved] in my fulfillment of the commandments.
Heb. לַשְׁמִעַ, like לְהַשְׁמִיעַ.
This refers to Hallel, which contains mention of the past, mention of Gog and Magog, mention of the Messianic era, and mention of the future.
Heb. זמה. Every זמה in Scripture is an expression of a plan, some for good and some for evil.

text.title: My foot stood on a straight path:

pasuk.text: Heb. במישור, on a straight path.
In what is stated above: “The Lord is the stronghold of my life.”

text.title: and to visit His Temple every morning:

pasuk.text: To appear there every morning. Dunash (Teshuvoth Dunash, p. 53) explained in this manner. Menachem (Machbereth Menachem, p. 47) however associated it with (Lev. 27:33), “He shall not inquire (יבקר) ,” but Dunash interpreted it as an expression of “morning” (בקר).

text.title: That He will hide me in His tabernacle:

pasuk.text: I am confident that He will hide me in His Temple, and we learned in Seder Olam (ch. 18) that this verse was stated concerning Joash the son of Ahaziah, who was hidden by his sister, Jehosheba, in the attic of the Holy of Holies, as the matter is stated (in II Kings 11:3): “And he was hiding with her in the house of the Lord for six years.”

text.title: He will lift me up on a rock:

pasuk.text: He stood my feet on a rock.
Sacrifices over which a song is recited.

text.title: On Your behalf, my heart says, “Seek My presence.”:

pasuk.text: On Your behalf, as Your agent, my heart says to me, “All of you Israelites, seek My presence.” And I obey it.“Your presence, O Lord, I will seek.” [The word] לך is like (Job 33:6): “Behold I am like your mouth to God (לא-ל) ,” [that is,] in His stead; (ibid. 13:8), “Will you contend for God (לא-ל) ?” [that is,] in His stead. Here, too, “On Your behalf, my heart says,” in Your stead, my heart comes to me to say this.
Heb. תט, do not bend over, as (above 18: 10): “And He bent (ויט) the heavens.”

text.title: For my father and my mother have forsaken me:

pasuk.text: At the time of coitus, they intended their own pleasure. As soon as their pleasure is over, this one turns his face this way and that one turns her face the other way.

text.title: but the Lord gathers me in:

pasuk.text: The Holy One, blessed be He, guards the droplet and forms the fetus.

text.title: to the desires of my adversaries:

pasuk.text: To the desire of my enemies, to have their desire fulfilled through me.
Heb. ויפח חמס, speakers of evil. Another explanation: An expression of a trap (פח).

text.title: Had I not believed in seeing, etc.:

pasuk.text: If I had not believed in the Holy One, blessed be He, those false witnesses would have already risen against me and destroyed me. [The word] לולא is punctuated for the homily which our Sages expounded (Ber. 4a): I know that You give reward to the righteous in the world to come, but I do not know whether I have a share with them or not.
and if your prayer is not accepted, reinforce your hope.

text.title: Do not cause me to be drawn:

pasuk.text: Heb. תמשכני, do not draw me with the wicked; treras moy in Old French.

text.title: and I will thank Him with my song:

pasuk.text: Now what is the thanks?…

text.title: The Lord is strength to them:

pasuk.text: to those who rely on Him, viz. the entire house of Israel, at the time that He is the stronghold of the salvations of His anointed.
Heb. ורעם, an expression of pasture (מרעה).

Heb. הבו. Prepare for the Lord and prepare for Him, you sons of the mighty of the land. From here we derive the ruling that [for the first blessing of the Amidah prayer] we should say the blessing אבות, the Patriarchs (Meg. 17b, R.H. 32b, Mid. Ps. 29: 2). But Menachem (p. 68) associated הבו as an expression of giving.
Heb. אלים, princes.

text.title: prepare for the Lord glory and might:

pasuk.text: From here we derive that [for the second blessing of the Amidah prayer] we should say the blessing of גבורות, mighty deeds.

This is the blessing of the sanctity of the Name [the third blessing of the Amidah]. In this psalm, there are eighteen mentions of God’s name, and corresponding to them, they instituted eighteen blessings.

text.title: The voice of the Lord is upon the waters:

pasuk.text: Upon the Sea of Reeds, “The Lord thundered from heaven” (above 18:14).
Heb. הרעים, tormanta in Old French.

text.title: The voice of the Lord is in strength:

pasuk.text: At the time of the giving of the Torah, He moderated His voice according to the strength of Israel, as it is said (Exod. 19:19): “and God would answer him with a voice,” with Moses’ voice.

text.title: The voice of the Lord breaks the cedars:

pasuk.text: The kings of the nations, as the matter that is written (in I Sam. 7:10): “and the Lord thundered with a loud noise etc. upon the Philistines” ; (in Isa. 30:31): “For from the Lord’s voice Assyria shall be broken.” And at the time of the giving of the Torah (Deut. 5:23): “For who is there of all flesh who has heard the voice of the living God speak out of the fire as we have and remained alive?” You heard and remained alive, but the nations of the world would hear it and die.

text.title: He causes them to dance like a calf:

pasuk.text: The cedars and the mountains that came to hear the giving of the Torah.
The names of mountains.

taylont in Old French, to cut. Our Sages (Mechilta ibid.) explained that the utterance of the Decalogue emanated from His mouth with a flame of fire and was engraved on the tablets according to their form.
Heb. יחיל, an expression of (Jer. 6:24), “pain (חיל) as a woman in travail.”

text.title: the Lord causes the desert of Kadesh to quake:

pasuk.text: That is the desert of Sinai, as our Sages said in Tractate Shabbath (89a): It was called by five names: the desert of Sinai, the desert of Zin, the desert of Kadesh, the desert of Kedemoth, the desert of Paran. [It was called] the desert of Kadesh because Israel was sanctified on its account.

text.title: The voice of the Lord will frighten the hinds:

pasuk.text: In the future, it will frighten the nations of the world and cause [them] to quake, those who are now standing firmly like hinds, as the matter that is stated (above 18:34): “He makes my feet like hinds.” Said Rabbi Phinehas: It does not say, “like harts,” but “like hinds,” like the females, because the feet of the females stand straighter than those of the males (Mid. Ps. 22:1). Another explanation: יחולל is kria in Old French, to create, as (in Prov. 8: 25), “before the hills, I was created (חוללתי).”

Like (Gen. 30:37), “by uncovering (מחשף) the white.” He will strip the forest trees, i.e., he will strip the nations, compared to forest trees, of their glory, as is stated (in Amos 2:9): “whose height is as the height of the cedar trees.”
which will be built.
Everyone will praise Him there and say…

text.title: The Lord sat [enthroned] at the flood:

pasuk.text: alone in His greatness, and now also, the Lord sits alone forever, “but the idols will completely pass away,” (as in Isa. 2:18), yet to His people He will give strength and a blessing of peace. Our Sages, however, expounded upon it in Midrash Psalms (29:2) that the nations became frightened and startled, and they came to Balaam and said to him, “What is the sound of the stirring that we heard? Is He going to bring a flood upon the world?” He replied to them, “He already swore that He would not bring a flood. Rather, the sound of the stirring that you heard is that the Holy One, blessed be He, is giving a Torah to His people.”

text.title: A song of dedication of the House:

pasuk.text: which the Levites will say at the dedication of the House in the days of Solomon.

text.title: I will exalt You, O Lord, for You have raised me up:

pasuk.text: Heb. דליתני, You have lifted me on high.

text.title: and You have not allowed my enemies to rejoice over me:

pasuk.text: Heb. לי, like עלי, over me, for they would say, “David has no share in the world to come,” but when they saw that the doors opened for the Ark because of me, then they knew that the Holy One, blessed be He, had forgiven me for that sin, and the faces of David’s enemies became as black as the bottom of a pot.
That is the forgiving of iniquity, as (in Isa. 6:10), “and he repent and be healed.”

text.title: from my descent into the Pit, etc.:

pasuk.text: Heb. מירדי, like מִיְרִדָתִי, from my descent into the Pit, that I should not descend into Gehinnom.

text.title: Sing to the Lord, His pious ones:

pasuk.text: about what He did for me, because you can take refuge in Him, and He will benefit you; and even if you are experiencing pain, have no fear.
[For] His wrath lasts but a short [moment]; life results from His favor, there is long life in appeasing and placating Him.

text.title: And I said in my tranquility:

pasuk.text: In my tranquility, I thought that I would never falter. However, the matter is not in my power, but in the power of the Holy One, blessed be He. With His will, He set up my mountain, my greatness to be [my] mightbut when He hid His countenance from me, I was immediately frightened.

text.title: To You, O Lord, I would call:

pasuk.text: I would call to You and supplicate constantly, saying before You: “What gain is there in my blood, etc.,” and You heard my voice and turned my lament into dancing for me.

Heb. פתחת, alachas in Old French, to release, like (Gen. 24:32): “and he untied (ויפתח) the camels.” Our Sages, however, explained the entire psalm as referring to Mordecai, Esther, and Haman, in Pesikta Zuta.

text.title: and I said in my tranquility:

pasuk.text: Haman said this.

text.title: To You, O Lord, I would call:

pasuk.text: Esther said this etc. until “be my helper.”

text.title: You turned my lament into dancing for me:

pasuk.text: Mordecai and all Israel said this.
Pleysiz in Old French, a fortress.
Heb. תנחני, mene moi in French, lead me, as (in Exod. 32: 34): “go lead (נחה) the people.”
Heb. אפקיד, komondere in Old French, I will entrust. I always entrust my spirit because You redeemed me from trouble.
Who await the salvation of pagan deities.
Heb. הסגרתני, livras moi in French, but Menachem (p. 125) associated it as an expression of closing, and likewise every expression of סגר.
Heb. עששה, an expression of a lantern, עששית. If a person puts glass in front of his eyes to see something on the other side of the glass, the appearance (of that thing) is unclear.
Heb. עששו, an expression of decay, as though a moth (עש) had eaten them.
From all my tormentors [not because of my tormentors].
Heb. חרפה, a reproach.
I am very much a reproach.
A mes connaissances in French, to my acquaintances. They are frightened by what happens to me.

Which is in the process of becoming lost. Any expression of אבדה, loss, does not refer to the owner of the lost article, saying that he lost it, but that the lost article is lost from him, as is stated (in Deut. 22:3): “which will be lost from him” ; (in Ezek. 34:4), “the lost one you did not seek.”

Heb. דבת, the counsel of many. דבת is an expression of (Song 7:10): “making the lips of the sleeping speak (דבב).” Likewise, every דבת in Scripture, parledic in Old French, gossip (so Gen. 37:2, Num. 14:36, Ezek. 36:3).
that they scare and frighten me.
Heb. בהוסדם, when they take counsel.
Heb. זממו, an expression of thought.

text.title: My times are in Your hands:

pasuk.text: The times that pass over me are through Your orders and by Your decrees.

text.title: let me not be shamed because I called out to You:

pasuk.text: Since I called You, it is not fitting that I should be shamed.

text.title: let them be silenced to the grave:

pasuk.text: Heb. ידמו, let them be silenced and made dumb to die.

text.title: that speak against a righteous man falsely:

pasuk.text: That say to Saul concerning me, “David seeks to harm you.”

Heb. עתק, untruth, something unfounded, as (Gen. 12:8): “And he moved (ויעתק) from there” [i.e., something removed from the truth]. Dunash (pp. 17f.) however, interpreted it as an expression of a great and strong thing, as (in Job 21:7): “grow strong (עתקו) and powerfully rich” ; (Prov. 8:18), “powerful (עתק) wealth” ; (Isa. 23: 18), “and for stately (עתקו) clothing.”

I knew that those who fear You have good reward in the world to come, nevertheless, in this world, because the wicked surround them, I pray for them that You hide them in the secrecy of Your countenance.
Heb. מרכסי, from the groups of wicked men who group together to harm them.

text.title: for He has been wondrously kind to me in a beseiged city:

pasuk.text: In Keilah, when Saul said concerning me (I Sam. 23:7): “for he has been shut in by coming into a city with doors and bars.”

text.title: But I said in my haste:

pasuk.text: When I left Keilah and came to the desert of Maon, I was hastening to leave because Saul and his men were surrounding me and my men, to seize us.
in my heart.

Heb. נגרזתי, I have been cut off, an expression of an ax (גרזן) which cuts the tree. Because of its cutting (גרזתו), it is called גרזן, an ax. This is how Dunash explained it (p. 57). (Menachem, however, defined it like נגרשתי, I have driven out, but it has no parallel in the Torah. (p. 59).

text.title: The Lord guards those who believe:

pasuk.text: in His salvation and rely on Him.

Heb. יתר (with measure for measure and with exactitude, like an arrow on a bowstring. Not in all editions.) Or, יתר can be interpreted as a rope for a rope, a line for a line. Another interpretation: יתר is an expression of haughtiness, as (in Isa. 15:7): “Because of the haughtiness (יתרה) with which they acted.”

text.title: Strengthen yourselves, and He will give your heart courage:

pasuk.text: as you see that He did for me, to save me because I hoped for Him.
The Sages said (Pes. 117a): Every Psalm in which “maskil” is mentioned was said through an interpreter.

text.title: Praiseworthy is he whose transgression is forgiven:

pasuk.text: Whose transgression the Holy One, Blessed Be He, forgives, and He conceals his sins. (נשוי is anpardone in Old French, pardoned. The implication is forgiveness, because the forgiveness of iniquity represents [the sin] being lifted up and withdrawn from upon a person.)

text.title: to whom the Lord ascribes no iniquity:

pasuk.text: provided that in his spirit there is no guile, thinking to revert to his “vomit.”
When I was silent, [when I refrained] from confessing my transgressions before You.
because of my many sighs and my worries all day, that I was worrying about the punishment.
the fear of Your hand and Your decrees was heavy upon me.

Heb. לשדי, my moisture, and so (in Num. 11:8): “the moisture (לשד) of oil,” the moisture of oil. This is how Dunash explained it (p. 14). Menachem (p. 171) associates [it with] an expression of plunder as (above 12:6): “from the plunder (משד) of the poor” ; (above 17:9) “Because of the wicked who have robbed me (שדוני).”

text.title: as in the droughts of summer:

pasuk.text: Until it dries up as the drought of summer out of my worry of the heaviness of Your hand, that I was worrying about my sins; therefore…

text.title: I would inform You of my sin:

pasuk.text: always. This is a present tense. For I said, It is good that I should confess my transgressions to the Lord, and now that I confessed and said to Nathan the prophet, “I have sinned,” (as in II Samuel 12:13)…

text.title: You forgave the iniquity of my sin:

pasuk.text: as the matter that is stated there (verse 13): “Also the Lord has removed your sin, etc.”

text.title: at the time that You are found:

pasuk.text: When You are found to accept his prayer, and what is this?…

text.title: only about a flood of vast waters:

pasuk.text: that they should not reach him, that he should not fall into the hands of enemies, who are like flooding waters. And so we find that David prayed for this and said (II Sam. 24:14): “Let us fall now into the hand of the Lord, for His mercies are great; but into the hand of man let me not fall.”

text.title: You are a shelter for me:

pasuk.text: to hide in Your shadow from before the enemy.
Heb. תצרני, like תשמרני.
A song of rescue.
Heb. תסובבני. This is the present tense. You always encompassed me with songs of deliverance. And so You said to me…

text.title: I will enlighten you and instruct you which way:

pasuk.text: to go.
With My eye; I will hint to you what to do. איעצה is an expression of winking the eye, as (in Prov. 16:30): “He winks (עצה) his eyes to think perverse thoughts.”

text.title: Be not like a horse, like a mule:

pasuk.text: which does not discern between one who benefits him and one who does him harm, for when you insert a bit into his mouth, he closes his mouth and shakes his bridle, and when you curry him and brush him, you must close his mouth and chastise him with a bit and bridle while you adorn him and groom him.

text.title: so that… he does not come near you:

pasuk.text: So that he should not come near you to hurt you while you groom him, with bit and bridle (when he is being groomed, to close his mouth. When he is being groomedwhile you curry him and brush himyou must close his mouth with a bit and bridle so that he does not come near you.) בלימה is an expression of closing in the language of the Mishnah: Its mouth is closed (בלום), its feet are closed (מבלמות), in Tractate Bechoroth (40b). (Menachem associated לבלום, and also בלימה [Job 26:7] as an expression of regulating [p. 45].)

text.title: with a lyre of ten melodies:

pasuk.text: Heb. בנבל עשור, of ten kinds of melody.

Heb. כנד, an expression of height, and so did Onkelos render (Exod. 15:8): נצבו כמו נד, they stood up like a wall, and so did Menachem (p. 121, missing) explain it. נד and נאד do not have the same meaning.

text.title: He puts the deeps into treasuries:

pasuk.text: under the earth.
He looks.

text.title: He Who forms their hearts together:

pasuk.text: All of their hearts together and knows all the thoughts. Our Sages, however, explain that it refers back to “From His dwelling place, the Creator oversees their hearts together,” and they derived from here that all are examined with a single glance (Rosh Hashana 18a).

as the matter that is stated (in I Sam. 21:14): “And he changed his speech before their eyes, etc. And he scribbled upon the doors of the gates.” That he disguised his speech and his sanity and feigned madness and let his saliva run down upon his beard.

All Philistine kings were called thus, and all Egyptian kings [were called] Pharaoh. Although his name was Achish, he was called Abimelech. The Midrash Aggadah explains that he was as righteous as Abimelech (mentioned in the Torah in relation to Sarah), for he did not want to kill him although his men said to him, “Is this not David, the king of the land?” As is stated in Midrash Psalms (34:1).

text.title: My soul boasts of the Lord:

pasuk.text: I boast, and praise myself that I have a patron like this to save me and protect me. Se porvantera in French, I will boast.
the wonders that He did for me. Through my praise, they will understand it and rejoice.
Heb. מגורותי, an expression of fear, as (in Num. 22:3): “and Moab became terrified (ויגר).”
All those who looked to Him out of their trouble.
Their faces shone.
Heb. יחפרו, they will be ashamed, as (in Isa. 24:23): “And the moon shall be ashamed (וחפרה) and the sun shall be abashed.”

text.title: Comprehend and see that the Lord is good:

pasuk.text: Comprehend His word.
Heb. יראו. Be afraid, the imperative form.
Heb. רשו, an expression of poverty.
Heb. כל טוב, nient bon, any good, as (in Exod. 12:16): “any work (כל-מלאכה).”
in your place.
elsewhere.
His angry face, les ires in Old French, ire, as (in Lev. 20:5): “And I will direct My face, etc.” So did Menachem (p. 143) associate it.
i.e., the righteous, and the Lord hearkens.
Many evils and terrors befall him, and he is saved from all of them.
The Holy One, blessed be He, [guards] all his bones.
The evil that the wicked man does will kill him.
Heb. תמותת, [equivalent to] תמית.
They will not regret saying, “We are guilty, because we took shelter in You.” Repontiront in Old French, se repentiront: they repent.

text.title: O Lord, strive with those who strive against me:

pasuk.text: Make a quarrel with those who make quarrels with me.
Heb. לחם an expression of war (מלחמה), and so לחמי, battle those who battle with me.

text.title: And arm Yourself with a spear:

pasuk.text: Heb. והרק. Arm Yourself, as (in Exod. 15:9) “I will arm myself (אריק) with my sword” ; (Gen. 14:14), “And he armed (וירק) his trained men.”

text.title: and bar the way before my pursuers:

pasuk.text: Protect between me and them, as a barrier.
A moi meme in French, to myself, as (in Jer. 18:20): “for they have dug a pit for me (לנפשי).”

Both together, so that their feet should slip on the slippery places and the darkness should not allow them to beware of the slippery places, as it is written (in Jer. 23:12): “Therefore, their way shall be for them like slippery places in the dark: ‘let them be thrust and fall therein.’”

text.title: they have dug it for my soul:

pasuk.text: they have dug a pit into which I should fall.
Heb. שואה, darkness, broine in Old French, obscurity.

text.title: and his net that he hid:

pasuk.text: So is the custom to hide the net and to cover it with straw or with earth, in order that the one who passes over it should not notice it until he is trapped in it.
when I see their downfall.
will praise You for everything, for now…
constantly against me, etc.

text.title: and may my prayer return upon my bosom:

pasuk.text: That is to say: If they say that I afflicted myself only for their detriment, that their illness should become more serious, may my prayer that I prayed for them return to me.

text.title: I walked about as though it were a friend or as though it were my own brother:

pasuk.text: As though it were my brother or my friend; I walked about depressed because of their distress.

text.title: as the mourning of a mother:

pasuk.text: As a son who mourns for his mother or as a mother who mourns for her son.
Heb. קדר, an expression of blackness.
An expression of humility.

text.title: And, when I limped, they rejoiced and gathered:

pasuk.text: And when I limped because I suffered a fracture, they rejoiced and gathered [around me].
Heb. נכים, lame people, as we translate “Pharaoh-neco,” חגירא, lame. Menachem (p. 122f.) associated it with (Isa. 16:7), נכאים, broken-hearted, amenuyze in Old French, crushed.

text.title: Were they to tear, they would not draw blood:

pasuk.text: Were they to tear my flesh, my blood would not flow to the ground when they embarrass me [lit. make my face white].

text.title: Because of the flattery of scorn for food, they gnash, etc.:

pasuk.text: Because of the flattery of scorn of eating and drinking, that they flatter Saul in order that he give them to eat and drink, they gnash their teeth against me.

Heb. מעוג, an expression of eating, as (in I Kings 17:12): “if I have food (מעוג) ,” written regarding Elijah, but Menachem (p. 130) interpreted it as an expression of a loaf of bread, and so “if I have a cake (מעוג).”

text.title: how long will You look on?:

pasuk.text: How much patience do You have to look upon all these?
Heb. משאיהם, from their darkness.

text.title: my only one from young lions:

pasuk.text: This refers to “Return my soul.” Return my only one from young lions.

text.title: those who are my enemies for an unjust cause:

pasuk.text: who hate me because of a false matter, that they testify against me what never entered my mind. Let them not rejoice at my downfall.
Let those who hate me not wink their eyes at me, to mock my downfall with their eyes. יקרצו means seynt in Old French, signal.

text.title: and against the crushed people of the earth:

pasuk.text: Heb. רגעי, on the crushed people of the earth, and so (in Jer. 31:34): “Who stirs up (רגע) the sea” ; (Job 7:5), “my skin wrinkled (רגע).” And so did Dunash explain it.
Heb. האח, an expression of joy of one who boasts with the lust of his heart, out of their [sic] great joy, that they see their lust gratified.
the heavenly retinue to judge my cause from my enemies.

text.title: The word of the transgression to the wicked man, in the midst of my heart, etc.:

pasuk.text: This is a transposed verse. I feel within my heart that the transgressioni.e., the evil inclinationsays to the wicked man that the fear of God should not be before his eyes.

text.title: in the midst of my heart:

pasuk.text: Like a person who says, “It seems to me.”
The transgression made smooth places appear to his eyes in order that the Holy One, blessed be He, find his iniquity to hate him.

text.title: he refrained from learning to improve:

pasuk.text: He refrained from contemplating to improve his deeds.

text.title: he stands on a way that is not good:

pasuk.text: The Holy One, blessed be He, placed before him the good way and the way of death, yet he chooses for himself a way that is not good.

text.title: O Lord, Your kindness is in the heavens:

pasuk.text: Because of these wicked men, You remove [Your] kindness from the earth creatures and raise up Your faith until the sky to remove it from the sons of men.
is as scarce to the creatures as the mighty mountains because of the deeds of the wicked, and Your judgments come upon the world until the vast deep. Another explanation:

text.title: Your righteousness is like the mighty mountains:

pasuk.text: The one with whom You wish to deal charitably, You raise up and strengthen like the mighty mountains. אל is an expression of strength, as (in Ezek. 17:13): “and he has taken away the mighty of (אילי) the land.”

text.title: Your judgments are the vast deep:

pasuk.text: Whomever You wish to judge, and wreak vengeance upon, You humble him to the vast deep.
Heb. משפטיך, joustiza in Old French, justice.

text.title: You save both man and beast:

pasuk.text: People who are as astute as Adam, but who make themselves as humble as beasts, You save, O Lord.
It is not fitting that it be extended to these wicked, but the children of men who take refuge in the shadow of Your wingsthey will be sated from the fat of Your house, etc.

text.title: Let the foot of haughtiness not come with me:

pasuk.text: Let the foot of these wicked men not come with me at the time of the reception of reward, [because] their lot should [not] be with the righteous.

text.title: neither shall the hand of the wicked cause me to wander:

pasuk.text: from my place when I return to inherit a double [portion]: my portion and the portion of the wicked man, in the goodness, as the matter that is stated (in Isa. 61:7): “Therefore, in their land they shall inherit twofold.” And then…

text.title: There the workers of iniquity have fallen:

pasuk.text: There they will understand their downfall, and there they were thrust away and were unable to rise.

text.title: Do not compete with the evildoers:

pasuk.text: He reproves Israel that they should not compete with the success of the evildoers to do as their deeds, as (in Jer. 12:5): “how will you compete (תתחרה) with horses,” to run as they run, a atir in Old French, to compete.

text.title: do not envy those who commit injustice:

pasuk.text: to commit injustice like them.
Heb. ימלו, seront tronke in Old French, they will be cut off, an expression of cutting off.
and do not say, “If I do not rob and steal,” or “If I give charity to a poor man, how will I sustain myself?”
Then you will dwell in the land for a long time.
You will eat and be sustained from the reward of [your] faith, that you believed in the Holy One, blessed be He, to rely on Him and do good.

text.title: So shall you delight in the Lord:

pasuk.text: Enjoy delights by being supported by the Holy One, blessed be He.

text.title: Commit your way to the Lord:

pasuk.text: Commit all your needs to Him.

Heb. דום. Wait for His salvation, as (in I Sam. 14:9): “If they say thus to us, ‘Wait (דמו) !’ ” mentioned regarding Jonathan. Menachem (p. 64), however, associates it as an expression of silence, as (in Lev. 10:3): “and Aaron was silent (וידם).” He likewise interpreted (Lam. 3:26): "It is good that one should wait quietly (ודומם) in this manner, and Dunash (p. 27) concurs with him.
Heb. והתחולל, an expression of hope (תוחלת).
saying, “I will be as wicked as he, and I will prosper as he does.”
Desist from being wicked so that anger does not come upon you.
a matter that will bring upon you the wrath of the Holy One, blessed be He.
whom you now see prosperingthey will be cut off.
When you wait a little longer, you will see that the wicked man is not here.

text.title: and you shall look at his place:

pasuk.text: and you shall look at the place where he was, and he is not there, because he has died and has perished.
Heb. וחרק, as (in Lam. 2:16): “and gnashed (ויחרקו) their teeth”; e rechineynt in Old French.
the wicked initiated quarrel and strife without previous provocation.

text.title: The few of the righteous are better:

pasuk.text: The few men who go to the aid of the righteous are better.

text.title: than the multitude of many wicked men:

pasuk.text: Amraphel and his allies initiated a war in the world for the purpose of capturing Lot and provoking Abraham, but the few who were with Abraham succeeded and wiped out all those armies.

text.title: The Lord knows the days of the innocent:

pasuk.text: He recognizes the deeds of their days, and their inheritance and the reception of their reward from Him shall be forever.

text.title: like disappearing light on the plains:

pasuk.text: Heb. כרים כיקר, like the light of the morning cloud, which appears at dawn and glistens on the broad plains, which does not last. כרים means a plain, as (in Isa. 30:23): “a wide plain (כר נרחב).” כיקר is an expression of “disappearing light (אור יקרות)” (as in Zech. 14:6). Others interpret כיקר כרים : like the glory of lambs that are fattened for the slaughter.

text.title: A wicked man borrows and does not pay, but the Righteous is gracious and gives:

pasuk.text: The Holy One, blessed be He, Who is the Righteous One of the world, is gracious with His own and gives it to the one who lent what he [the borrower] stole from him.
By the Righteous One of the world, shall inherit the land.
He who is mighty in the fear of the Holy One, blessed be He; les pas du fort in French, the steps of the strong one.
Fureut afettetes in French, are prepared for reality.
Heb. יפל, aluverjera in Old French, falters, an expression of (Gen. 24: 64): “and she fell off the camel.”
Heb. כי, like אם.

text.title: he will not be cast down:

pasuk.text: He will not be cast away to be forsaken.
This verse was recited by the Prince of the World (the chief angel), for if it was David, he was not so old.
the righteous man is gracious to the poor and lends to them.
This seed that he sows with his charity will ultimately be blessed.
at first words of wisdom in his heart to see the law that the Torah decided for each thing, and afterwards his tongue speaks judgment.
His steps do not slip.

Heb. ומתערה, rooted, as (in Isa. 19:7): “the well-rooted plants (ערות) by the stream.” In the language of the Mishnah there are many [examples]: e.g. (Oktzin 3:8): “A tree that was cut off but is yet rooted by its bark.”

text.title: as a native who is fresh:

pasuk.text: As one of the natives of the land who are well-rooted and abounding with property. And so did Menachem (p. 20) explain it: כאזרח רענן moist and growing like a well-rooted tree, and the native (אזרח) of the natives (מאזרחי) of humans are men of roots.
Scrutinize the ways of the innocent to learn from their deeds.

text.title: for there is a future for the man of peace:

pasuk.text: If he has no beginning, he has a future, but the transgressors, the sinners and the wicked their future has been cut off and they have been destroyed together.

text.title: A song of David, to make remembrance:

pasuk.text: To recite it in time of distress, to make remembrance of the distress of Israel before the Holy One, blessed be He, and he recited it as relating to all Israel.

Heb. נחתו, have been cast. The expression of נחת applies to the bending of a bow, and since the arrows are shot by bending the bow, he wrote נחתו בי [literally] “were bent in me.” Similarly, (in Exod. 15:9): “I will unsheath my sword חרבי) (אריק,” [lit. I emptied my sword.] The Torah should have written: אריק תערי, I will empty my sheath, but because when they draw the sword from its sheath, the sheath is emptied of it, he therefore relates the emptying to the sword. Similarly, (above 18:35): “a copper bow was bent (ונחתה).” The “nun” is not a radical, because, if it were a radical, it would have to be ננחתו, but the “nun” of נחתו, and so ותנחת, is not a radical but is sometimes dropped, like the “nun” of נגף, to smite; נשך, to bite; נדר, to vow; נקם, to avenge. And when it is passive we say: נִגַּף, smitten; נִשַׁ, bitten; נִדַּר, vowed; נִקַּם, avenged, like נִנְקַם, נִנְדַּר, נִנְשַׁ, נִנְגַּף. The “dagesh” in the word replaces the “nun.” Similarly (in Lev. 26:36), a rattling (נִדַף) leaf, “ (in Lam. 3:49),” My eyes stream (נִגְרָה), “ like נִנְגְּרָה. So does he say נִחֲתוּ like נִנְחֲתוּ, and so (above 18:35): ” and a copper bow was bent (וְנִּחֲתָה), “ like וְנִנְחֲתָה. It was customary for the ” cheth “ to be treated like the letters that do accept a ” dagesh “ in most places, e.g. (in I Kings 13:18): ” He lied (כִּחֶשׁ) to him, “ in the form that is punctuated by a” dagesh, “ [i.e., the pi’el conjugation,] like דִבֶּר spoke, from the same conjugation as וַיְדַבֶּר, כִּחֶשׁ from the same conjugation as (Gen. 18: 15): ” And Sarah lied (וַתְּכַחֵשׁ), “ and we do not say כֵּחַשׁ as we say from הַמְבָרֵ, בֵּרַ and we do not say בִּרֵ as we say דִּבֵּר, because the power of the ” dagesh “ ; is not recognizable in the ” resh, “ but in the ” cheth “ the power of the ” dagesh “ is recognizable, and so (in Deut. 32:5): ” Have they injured (שִׁחֵת) Him?“ like כִּפֵר, atoned, דִּבֵּר, spoke. Here, too, he says, נִחֲתוּ like נִגְּשׁוּ they approached, נִתְּנוּ, they were given, from the roots נחת, נגש, נתן, the ” nun “ being a defective radical, replaced by a ” dagesh “ in the passive voice. So is (I Sam. 2:4): ” The bows of the mighty are broken (חתים), “ from the root נחת and חתת as you say from נסב, סבב, from נשם, שמם; (Lev. 26: 22),” and your ways shall become desolate (וְנָשַׁמוּ) , “ (ibid. verse 32),” shall wonder (וְשָׁמְמוּ) over it.“ Similarly, בָּלַל, נָבֹל, (Gen. 11: 9)” for there the Lord confused בָּלַל “ (ibid. verse 7)” and let us confuse (וְנָבְלָה) their language there." So does he say נחת and חתת in the active voice.

text.title: and Your hand has come down upon me:

pasuk.text: This is the explanation of “Your arrows have been shot into me.” And this is its interpretation: What bent the bow to shoot the arrows? Your hand has come down upon the bow to shoot arrows at me. ותנחת is an expression of ותרד, it came down, and in this the “nun” is a radical. Similarly (18:35), “and a copper bow was broken (ונחתה) ,” in which the “nun” is not a radical.
Perfection, anterin in Old French, wholeness.
Heb. יכבדו, are heavy.
Heb. נעויתי an expression of (Chullin 60b): “Convulsions (עוית) seize him.” Etourdissant in French, stunning.

text.title: For my loins are full of self-effacement:

pasuk.text: In my thoughts, I am insignificant in my own eyes.
Heb. נפוגתי, I passed out, an expression of (Gen. 45:26), “and his heart fainted (ויפג).” (Lam. 3:49), “without respite (הפגת).”
You know my needs.

Heb. סחרחר, surrounded by grief. This is one of the double words, like (Lev. 13:49), “dark green (ירקרק), dark red (אדמדם) ,” (Ned. 66b) “round (סגלגל)” (Lam. 1:20), “my spirits are troubled (חמר מרו).”

Those who appear to me as lovers in time of their pleasure, and when they see that the affliction comes upon me, they do not stand up for me in the time of my strait, but stand aloof and do not aid me.
who showed themselves to be close to me.

text.title: And those who seek my life lay traps:

pasuk.text: They seek traps for me.

text.title: But I am as a deaf person:

pasuk.text: Israel hears their reproach from the nations but does not respond. Why? Because I hoped for You, O Lord, that You would redeem me and save me from them.

text.title: For I said, “Lest they rejoice over me”:

pasuk.text: For this reason we remain silent, because we say to ourselves, “If we answer them brazenly, they may witness our downfall and rejoice over us when our feet falter, and they will magnify themselves over us saying, ‘Weren’t you boasting of your salvation?’”

text.title: For I am ready for disaster:

pasuk.text: For this reason, we are concerned lest they rejoice over us, because we are accustomed to blows and are always ready and prepared for disaster.

text.title: and my pain is always before me:

pasuk.text: It is always prepared to come before me.
My heart tells me my iniquity. Therefore, I worry, and fear my sin, lest it cause me disaster and pain.

text.title: are in the vigor of life:

pasuk.text: They are in the vigor of life with tranquility and goodness.
And those who hate me because of false words have become exalted.
Because we cleave to the Holy One, blessed be He, and to His commandments.

The name of one of the singers, and there was also a musical instrument called Jeduthun. According to the Midrash Aggadah (Song Rabbah 4:1 [4]): concerning the edicts (דתות) and concerning the distressing laws and decrees that are decreed upon Israel.

text.title: I said, “I will guard my ways, etc.”:

pasuk.text: As for uswe had in mind to watch ourselves with all the troubles that come upon us, neither to criticize nor speak harshly of the Divine Attribute of Justice although the wicked who oppress us are before us.

Heb. מחסם, as (in Deut. 25:4): “You shall not muzzle (תחסם) an ox, amuzelment in Old French. And I made myself mute in silence many days. We also were silent from ” good, “ even from words of Torah, because of their fear of them, our pain was so intense and frightening. When we were silent, our heart was hot within us and in the thought of our heart it burns in us like fire. That causes us to speak with our tongue (in silencenot in all editions) before You, and this is what we say,” O Lord, let us know our end." How long will we be in distress, and let us know when we will be over it.
The days of man are measured like a thing that is measured with handbreadths; so are man’s days limited.
Heb. וחלדי, and our old age is as nothing before you. חלד is an expression of rust (חלודה), rodijjl in Old French; rust, old age.
his life and his condition are a life of vanity.

Heb. בצלם, in darkness. Dunash explained it as an expression of darkness (צלמות) (Teshuvoth Dunash p. 89), but Menachem (p. 150) explained it as an actual image, as (in Gen. 9:6) “for in the image of God He made man.” His view is impossible, however.

text.title: all that they stir is but vanity:

pasuk.text: All their stirring and lust.
grain in the field all the days of the harvest.

text.title: yet he knows not who will bring them in:

pasuk.text: He does not know who will gather them into the house; perhaps he will die before the ingathering.

text.title: And now, what have I hoped:

pasuk.text: What is the request that I ask and hope from You? It is only that You save me from my transgressions.

text.title: do not make me the reproach of:

pasuk.text: the ignoble Esau. Bring afflictions and pains upon him too, so he will not be able to say to me, “You are suffering, and we are not suffering.” This prayer was instrumental in bringing about the pains of illnesses upon the nations.
For You brought upon us trouble more than all nations.

text.title: from the fear of Your hand:

pasuk.text: Heb. מתגרת, from the fear of Your blows. תגרת is an expression of (Num. 22:3): “And Moab became terrified (וַיָגָר).” The “tav” is a defective radical in the word, like תנובה, produce; תלונה, complaint; תקומה, restoration; תכונה, characteristic. This is how Menachem explained it, but I maintain that תגרת is not an expression of מָגוֹר, fear, because he should have said תגוּרה as he says from: וישב (and he returned) תשוּבה, [from] ויקם, וירם and וילן : תקוּמה, תרוּמה and תלוּנה, so he should say from ויגר, תגוּלה, or מגוּרה as (above 31:14, Jer. 20:3): “terror (מגור) from all sides” ; (Isa. 66:4) “and their fears (ומגורתם) I will bring.” Thus you learn that מתגרת is nothing but as (II Chron. 25: 19), “Why should you provoke (תתגרה) disaster?” ; (Deut. 2: 5), “Do not provoke (תתגרו) them,” in which case the verb is גרה like קוה, to hope; אוה, to desire; צוה, to command, of which the noun is תקוה, תאוה, מצוה. So one says from גרה, תגרה, and this is its explanation: from the blows of Your hand, with which You fight me, I perish.
that are written in the Torah for our iniquities that we have sinned before You and for which You chastised us.

text.title: You have caused his flesh to decay:

pasuk.text: You have caused our flesh to decay like a moth-eaten garment. Heb. חמודו means his flesh, which is his desire (חמדתו).
Loosen Your hand from smiting me.
Heb. ואבלגה,that I regain my strength.

text.title: I have greatly hoped for the Lord:

pasuk.text: in Egypt, and this psalm is meant for all Israel.
His ear.
From the imprisonment of Egypt and from the roaring of their tumult.
From the sea. היון is an expression of mud, fanyas in Old French (fange in modern French), slime.
Heb. כונן, He prepared my steps.
The song of the sea.
Heb. רהבים, an expression of haughtiness, as (in Isa. 3:5): “they shall behave haughtily (ירהבו) , the youth” ; (Song 6:5) “for they have made me haughty (הרהבותי).”

text.title: and those who turn to falsehood:

pasuk.text: Those who turn from the straight way to follow the falsehood of pagan deities; e tornons in Old French, and those who turn away; in modern French, et se tournant.

text.title: Your wonders and Your thoughts are for us:

pasuk.text: You created Your world for us; You split the sea for us, and You thought for us to benefit us in our end [by keeping us] in the desert for forty years because of the Amorites, who cut down the trees and made their land desolate when they heard that Israel was coming out to go to inherit their land.

text.title: There is none to equal You:

pasuk.text: We cannot compare any king or savior to You. The expression ערך is like (Lev. 27:12): “valuation (כערכך) ,” a prizjjr in Old French, to estimate, [a priser, in modern French].

text.title: were I to tell and speak:

pasuk.text: Were I to come and tell and speak, they would be too many to tell.

text.title: You desired neither sacrifice nor meal offering:

pasuk.text: on the day of the giving of the Torah, as the matter that is stated (in Exod. 19: 5): “And now, if you will earnestly hearken to My voice, etc.,” and likewise (in Jer. 7:22) Scripture states: “For neither did I speak with your forefathers nor did I command them, etc., concerning a burnt offering or a sacrifice.” I said, (Lev. 1:2) “If… from among you,” but I did not require it as an obligation to burden you. The daily sacrifices and the additional sacrifices are only to bring Me pleasure, that I ordained and My will was performed, but it is a small matter.
saying, “Hearken to My voice.”
You made them hollow [enabling me] to hear.

at the time of the giving of the Torah, behold I came to You to be bound in Your covenant. (Exod. 24:7): “We will do and hear,” and this matter is written as testimony concerning me in the scroll of the book, i.e., in the Law of Moses.

text.title: and [to have] Your law within my innards:

pasuk.text: Even my food is according to Your law; I ate neither unclean beasts nor untithed produce.
The song by the sea, the song by the well (Num. 21:17-20), and the song of Deborah (Jud. 5).
Heb. אכלא, I will not withhold, an expression of (Gen. 8: 2): “And the rain was restrained (ויכלא).”
Heb. לא תכלא, do not withhold.
Heb. יצרוני, watch me.
Heb. אפפו, have surrounded.
Heb. לספותה, to destroy it, as we translate (in Deut. 2:14): "until the entire generation… had vanished, דרא עד דסף כל-.
[as translated,] may they be bewildered.

Heb. על-עקב. When they receive their shame in the wake of everything [they have done], in the measure that they measured out and in the way they walked against Me. עקב is like (below 77:20): “and your steps (ועקבותיך) were not known” ; (Song 1:8), “go your way in the footsteps of (בעקבי) the flocks.” They are all an expression of footsteps, in French traces, footprints on the heel.

text.title: those who say about me, “Aha! Aha!”:

pasuk.text: Those who say about me and for me, “Aha!” When trouble comes, they pray for our misfortune.
Every expression of poor and needy in Psalms refers only to Israel.
Heb יחשב. May He pay heed to me to think of my poverty and neediness, to save me. Pensa in French, to think.
Heb. דל, the ill, to visit him, as the matter that is stated (in II Sam. 13:4): “Why are you so poor (דל) …?” mentioned in reference to Amnon.
This is Gehinnom (Ned. 40a). And in this world, what is his [the visitor’s] reward?…

text.title: The Lord will preserve him and keep him alive:

pasuk.text: i.e., the visitor and benefactor who visits him and benefits him.

Heb. ערש, lit in French, as (in Deut. 3:11): “Behold his bed is an iron bed.” When he too takes ill, He will support him. What is the meaning of “on his sickbed” ? This is the seventh day of the sickness, when he is very ill. In this manner, it is explained in Aggadath Tehillim (Mid. Ps. 41:5).

text.title: when You have transformed his entire restfulness in his illness:

pasuk.text: Even in the time that his illness has become more acute, when all his restfulness and tranquility have been transformed.

text.title: I said, “O Lord, be gracious to me”:

pasuk.text: As for me, I have none who visit for good, and when I cry out from my illness and say, “O Lord, be gracious to me, etc,” my enemies rejoice over me and say evil things about me: “When will he die, etc.”
He pretends to be troubled, and when he sits before me, his heart gathers thoughts of violence to himself, [of] what evil he will speak when he leaves, and when he goes outside, he speaks of it.
something that is harmful to me, and what is that thought?…

text.title: An evil thing shall be poured into him:

pasuk.text: All the wicked things that he did shall be poured and spilled into his body, and if he lay down, he shall not rise. This is how they curse me.
Heb. עקב, an ambush, as (in Josh. 8:13): “and their ambush party (עקבו) on the west of the city.”

text.title: With this I shall know, etc.:

pasuk.text: When You are gracious to me and raise me up, I shall know that You have desired me; when my enemy will not shout with shouts of joy over me, and I will see that because of my innocence, You have supported me.
When I stand up from my illness, I will bless You in this manner.

Assir, Elkanah, and Abiasaf. At first, they were in their father’s counsel, but at the time of the controversy they parted, and when all those around them were swallowed up, and the earth opened its mouth, their place was left within the mouth of the earth, as the matter that is stated (Num. 26:11): “But the sons of Korah did not die.” There they uttered a song, and there they composed these psalms. [Then] they ascended from there, and the holy spirit rested on them, whereupon they prophesied concerning the exiles, the destruction of the Temple, and the Davidic dynasty.

text.title: As a hart cries longingly for rivulets:

pasuk.text: Heb. תערג. The expression of ערג applies to the voice of the hart as the expression of נהם, roaring, applies to a lion; שּׁקוק, growling, to a bear; געה, lowing, to oxen, and צפצוף chirping, to birds. [See Teshuvoth Dunash, p. 18.] Our Sages said: The hind is the most pious of the beasts. When the beasts are thirsty for water, they gather to her so that she should raise her eyes to heaven. And what does she do? She digs a pit and thrusts her antlers into it and lows. Thereupon, the Holy One, blessed be He, has compassion on her and the deep brings up water for her.

“As a hind cries longingly” is not stated, nor, “As a hart cries longingly (יערג) [in the masculine].” Only, “As a hart cries longingly.” Scripture speaks of [both] a male and a female. The male cries longingly for water, as we explained, and the female when she kneels to give birth, [because] her womb is narrow. [When] she cries out, the Holy One, blessed be He, is compassionate and prepares a serpent, which bites her on her birth canal, whereupon her womb opens. Menachem (p. 138) connects תערג with (Song 5:13): “His cheeks are like a bed of (כערוגת) spice,” but his view is impossible. Dunash (p. 18) too explained it as the sound of the hart.

text.title: when will I come and appear before God?:

pasuk.text: to make the pilgrimages on the festivals. Here he prophesied concerning the destruction of the Temple. “Why are you downcast?” is stated here three times, corresponding to the three kingdoms destined to curtail the Temple service, and Israel will cry out and be redeemed: the kingdoms of Babylon, Greece, and Edom.
The people of Israel say this in the Babylonian exile.
From here we derive that distress satiates a person, and he does not seek to eat. Similarly, Scripture states regarding Hannah (I Sam. 1:7): “and she wept and did not eat.”

text.title: These things I will remember, etc., how I passed on with the throng:

pasuk.text: Pasoye in Old French. I remember this, and my soul pours out when I remember the festive pilgrimage, how I would pass on with the throngs of people and walk slowly with them until the House of God. סַ is an expression of a number. Another explanation: סַ is an expression of a human barrier. Another explanation: סַ is an expression of a covering and a booth, meaning covered wagons. סַ is an expression relating to צָב (Num. 7:3), “covered wagons” (עגלותצב). Covered like a booth, their name in the language of the Aggadah is סקפסטאות and אסקופיטי.

I walked slowly with them, as (Shab. 128b): “We may make calves and foals walk (מדדים) ,” and, “A woman may make her child walk (מדדה). This word serves in place of two words: אדדה עמהם, I walked with them, etay amut semble in Old French, to move together. Menachem (p. 62) associated it as an expression of affection (ידידות) , as (Jer. 12:7): ” I have delivered My soul’s beloved (ידידות) into the hand of her enemies.“ But Dunash (p. 27) interpreted אדדם as an expression of silence (דממה) , and likewise (above 37:7): ” Wait (דום) for the Lord, etc.“ Accordingly, the interpretation of אדדם is: ” I will be dumb, “ and I was silent until I came to the House of God with shouts of joy, as (above 39:2): ” I will guard my mouth [as though with] a muzzle, etc.“ and as (above 38:14): ” But I am like a deaf man, I do not hear, and like a mute, etc.“ דם is the radical of אדדם I would walk with them, as (Gen. 37:4): ” And they could not speak with him in peace," [equivalent to] לדבר עמו בשלום.

who were going to celebrate, and on this the liturgical poet (in the morning service of Parashat Shekalim, in the Yotzer of [the prayer] “Ayleh Ezcherah”): “A vast celebrating multitude, flooding like a river.” According to the Midrash Aggadah (Mid. Ps. 42:4), it is Greek, because they call a pool of water “chogegin.”

Heb. תשתוחחי, an expression of (below 44:26): “For our soul is cast down (שחה) to the dust.” When שַּׁח is used in the reflexive (מתפעל) , the “tav” separates the radicals in the manner of every word whose root begins with “shin.”
Wait and look forward to the redemption.

text.title: I will remember You from the land of Jordan:

pasuk.text: From what You did for us in the Jordan and the peaks of Hermon; after all the provocation with which we provoked You in Shittim, You dried the Jordan for us.

From Mount Sinai, which is younger than other mountains; after we provoked You there with the episode of the [Golden] Calf, You forgave our iniquities and went with us. All these I remember in my exile, when You have refrained from doing good for me, and Your decrees are being renewed one after the other.
One trouble calls the next one.

text.title: to the sound of Your water channels:

pasuk.text: (Tes canals in Old French, canaux in modern French) which spray retribution upon me like flooding waters, until all Your breakers and waves have passed over me.“Your breakers” is an expression of the waves of the sea, because the waves of the sea ascend, break, and fall.

text.title: By day, may the Lord command His kindness:

pasuk.text: May the light of the redemption come, and may the Lord command His kindness to us.
In the darkness of the exile and the troubles.

text.title: may His resting place be with me:

pasuk.text: Heb. שירה. May His resting place be in our midst. שּׁירה is an expression of camping, as we translate (II Sam. 17:26): “And Israel encamped,” וּשְּׁרָא. I learned this from the Great Masorah, which associates this [word] with (I Kings 5:12): “And his songs (שירו) were a thousand and five,” in the “aleph-beth” of two words with different meanings (homonyms). This taught [me] that this is not an expression of song, but the Midrash Aggadah does interpret it as an expression of song, interpreting in this manner: Israel says to the Holy One, blessed be He: “We remember what You did for us in Egypt. You commanded us one commandment by day on the eve of the Passover, and we observed it, and at night, You redeemed us and we sang Hallel before You. But now we keep many commandments, yet You do not redeem us. Because of this, I will say to God, my Rock, ‘Why have You forgotten me?’”
Heb. קדר, an expression of blackness, as (Micah 3: 6): “and… shall be darkened (וקדר) about them.”

text.title: With murder in my bones, my oppressors have reproached me:

pasuk.text: It seemed to me as though they were killing me, so confined within my bones was that with which my oppressors provoke and reproach me.
The Holy One, the light of my countenance, my GodI still have hope in Him. Why, then, should you stir?
Heb. שפטני, lit. judge me.
That is Ishmael, who dwelt between two righteous men [Abraham and Isaac] and did not learn from their deeds.

text.title: Send Your light and Your truth:

pasuk.text: The King Messiah, who is compared to light, as it is stated (below 132:17): “I have set up a lamp for my anointed,” and Elijah the prophet, who is true, a faithful prophet.
Heb. ינחוני, menoront moi in old French, they shall lead me.
To the Holy One, blessed be He, who is the joy of my exultation.

text.title: and I will thank You with a lyre:

pasuk.text: because You took me out of my exile.

From here you learn that the sons of Korah were speaking for the generations following them, for if it were for themselves, they should not say, “our fathers told us,” because they themselves witnessed the miracles of the desert, the Jordan, and Joshua’s war. In this manner, it is explained in the Aggadah of Psalms (Mid. Ps. 44:1).
You inflicted harm on the seven great nations, You sent them out from before us, and with Your hand and Your strength You drove them out of their land and planted our forefathers in its midst.
Heb. רציתם, an expression of favor.
Now too.

text.title: we will trample those who rise up against us:

pasuk.text: Heb. נבוס. We will tread and trample our enemies, an expression of (Ezek. 16:6): “wallowing (מתבוססת) in your blood” ; (Prov. 27:7), “tramples (תבוס) honeycomb” ; (Zech. 10:5), “And they shall be like mighty men, treading (בוסים) the mire of the streets.”

text.title: Even if You have forsaken us and put us to shame:

pasuk.text: Even if You put us to shame, we will forever thank Your name.
Heb. תשיבנו. This is a present tense.
They plunder our property, each man for himself.
Epondis nous in Old French, tu nous repandis in modern French.

text.title: when You crushed us in a place of serpents:

pasuk.text: This כי serves as an expression of כאשר, when. Even when You humbled us in a land of plains and pits; [in] a desert, a place of serpents, and You covered us with the darkness of deathdespite all this, if we forgot the name of our God, will God not search this out? For He knows the secrets of the heart.
As sheep of slaughter.

text.title: and redeem us for the sake of Your kindness:

pasuk.text: We do not come with the power of our deeds, but do [this] for the sake of Your kindness.
They founded this psalm in honor of the Torah scholars, who are as tender as roses and as beautiful as roses, and perform good deeds as fresh as roses.
Through an interpreter.
Heb. שיר ידידות, a song of loves, a song of praise for them [the Torah scholars] to endear them to the people and to endear their Torah to them [the people].
In this manner, the Psalmist commenced his song: My heart caused a good theme to swarm within me in your praise, O Torah scholar.
Heb. רחש, an expression of moving, and so is every expression of swarming and crawling.

text.title: I say, “My works are for a king”:

pasuk.text: This song, which I have founded and composed, I say to one who is fit to be a king, as it is stated (Prov. 8:15): “Kings reign with me.”
as poetic as the pen of an expert scribe. I saw in the commentary of Rabbi Moses the Preacher: מָהִיר in Arabic means expert.

text.title: You are more handsome than [other] men:

pasuk.text: who engage in the work of transitory life. Why? Because charm is poured into your lips to instruct according to the halachah. הוּצַק means “poured,” as (Exod. 38:27): “to cast (לצקת) ” ; (Gen. 28:18), “and he poured (ויצק) oil.”
as it is stated (below 29:11): “The Lord shall grant strength to His people.” And what is their reward?“The Lord shall bless His people with peace.”

text.title: Gird a sword on your thigh:

pasuk.text: to wage the war of Torah, and that is your majesty and that is your glory.
To instruct according to the law and to behave with righteous humility.

The Torah and the matter of truth in which you shall engage shall teach you tactics of war so that your right should perform awesome things. Since he mentions the study of Torah in an expression of war, the expression of the right hand, prepared to fight, is appropriate (i.e., it is customary to fight with the right hand).

text.title: Your arrows are sharpened, etc., in the heart of the king’s enemies:

pasuk.text: Heb. שְּׁנוּנִים, is aiguises in French, sharpened. This is a transposed verse. We find that the disciples are called arrows, as it is stated (above 127: 4): “As arrows in the hand of a mighty man, so are the children of youth.” And Torah scholars who argue with each other about halachah are called enemies to each other for the time, as it is stated: “they will not be ashamed when they speak with the enemies in the gate.”
As a reward for Torah, nations shall fall under Israel.

Your throne, O prince and judge, shall exist forever and ever, as the matter that is stated (Exod. 7:1): “I have made you a judge אלהים) (נתתיך over Pharaoh.” And why? Because “a scepter of equity is the scepter of your kingdom,” that your judgments are true, and you are fit to govern.

text.title: anointed you… with oil of joy:

pasuk.text: Every expression of greatness is depicted by the anointment of oil, as is the custom of the kings.
Heb. קדה (Exod. 30: 24) is translated קציעתא, cassia.
All your garments smell with the fragrance of spices. Its midrashic interpretation is: All your betrayals (בגידותיך) and sins are expiated and smell of a fragrant scent.

text.title: more than ivory palaces, those that are Mine will cause you to rejoice:

pasuk.text: More than the best ivory palaces, are the palaces that are prepared for you in Paradise to cause you to rejoice with them. שֵּׁן is ivoire in French, ivory.

text.title: those that are Mine will cause you to rejoice:

pasuk.text: The palaces that are Minethey will make you rejoice, those that give you your reward.
will visit you, as the matter that is stated (Isa. 49:23): “and their princesses your wet nurses.”

lit. your visitors. Heb. ביקרותיך. The “kaph” is punctuated with a “dagesh” because it is an expression of visiting, although it is preceded by a “yud.” I saw in Rav Saadia’s punctuation that this word is arranged with (Isa. 42:24), “Who subjected Jacob to plunder (למשיסה) ,” which is written with a “yud” although the “sammech” is punctuated with a “dagesh.” Menachem, however, associated it as an expression of value, as (Job 28: 16): "with precious (יקר) onyx.

Heb. שגל, the queen, as (Neh. 2:6): “and the queen (השגל) was sitting beside him” ; (Dan. 5: 2), “and they shall drink with them, the king and his nobles, his queen (שגלתה) and his concubines.” Your wife will stand at your right.
with a collection of golden ornaments that comes from Ophir.
Hearken, O nation of Israel, and see the good way.
to the Torah.
The nations among whom you were raised.
The idolatry that your fathers worshipped on the other side of the river.

text.title: And the King shall desire your beauty:

pasuk.text: And if you do this, the King, the Holy One, blessed be He, will desire the beauty of your deeds.

text.title: And the daughter of Tyre shall seek your presence with tribute:

pasuk.text: Heb. יחלו, as (Exod. 32:11): “And Moses prayed (ויחל).” And as reward for this, you will merit that those who are now the richest of the people will bring you tribute and gifts.

text.title: All honor [awaits] the King’s daughter who is within, etc.:

pasuk.text: Those who deserve all honor, and they are the nation of the King, who behaved with modesty now their garments will be more esteemed than the settings of gold of the High Priests. משבצוֹת is chatons in French, settings.

text.title: With embroidered garments, she will be brought to the King:

pasuk.text: In embroidered garments, they will bring her as a gift to the King of all the earth. רקמוֹת is a broderies in French. This is what is stated (Isa. 66:20): “And they shall bring all your brethren from all the nations as a tribute, etc.”

text.title: virgins in her train who are her companions:

pasuk.text: Some of the idolatrous nations will follow them, as the matter that is stated (Zech. 8:23): “shall take hold of the skirt of a Jewish man, saying, ‘Let us go with you, for we have heard that God is with you.’”
The Psalmist addresses the Holy One, blessed be He.
He addresses each Israelite.
The Psalmist addresses the Holy One, blessed be He.
The name of a musical instrument in Chronicles (I Chron. 15:20).

in the future, on the day concerning which Scripture states (Isa. 51:6): “and the earth shall rot away like a garment.” The sons of Korah saw the miracle that was performed for them, that all those around them were swallowed up while they [the sons of Korah] stood in the air and said to Israel, through the holy spirit, that a similar miracle would be performed for them in the future.

text.title: His waters shall stir and be muddied:

pasuk.text: Heb. יחמרו, they shall cast up mud, clay (חמר) , and dirt as is their wont. Menachem (pp. 90f.), however, associated it with (Lam. 1:20), “my reins have shriveled (חמרמרו),” regrezeliront in Old French, have shriveled.

text.title: mountains shall quake from His pride:

pasuk.text: [The pride] of the Holy One, blessed be He, Who is mentioned in the beginning of the psalm (verse 2).

text.title: But as for the river its rivulets:

pasuk.text: Heb. פלגיו, ses ruisseaux in French, its rivulets.
of Paradise.
at the end of the redemption.
Heb. המו, an expression of stirring.

Shall melt - so explained Menachem, similar to (Exod. 15:15), “all the inhabitants of Canaan melted (נמוגו) ,” and to (Ezek. 21:12), “every heart will melt (למוג).” But Dunash explained it as an expression of movement, as in (I Sam. 14: 16), “the multitude was wandering (נמוג), and it was coming closer,” and so in every instance.
That He has made the lands of the nations desolate.

text.title: He puts a stop to wars:

pasuk.text: from upon us.

text.title: until the end of the earth:

pasuk.text: that all the lands of the nations shall be at peace with us.
of the nations He shall break.

text.title: wagons He will burn with fire:

pasuk.text: The war chariots of the nations of the world. [The war chariots of the star worshippers.]
all nations from further marching upon Jerusalem.

text.title: and know that I am God:

pasuk.text: That I will execute judgment upon you.

text.title: I will be exalted among the nations:

pasuk.text: I will be exalted with My vengeance which I will wreak upon those nations.
Join together with one another to shout to God with a voice of praise.

text.title: He shall plague peoples in our stead:

pasuk.text: Heb. עמים תחתינו ידבר, He shall afflict the peoples with a plague (דבר) instead of our soul(s) so that His wrath will subside through them, and we will be saved, as the matter that is stated (Isa. 43:3): “I have given Egypt as your ransom, etc.” Menachem, however, associated it with an expression of leading (p. 61).

and restore us to its midst. Then He will be exalted with the trumpet blast and the sound of the shofar that we will sound before Him over the burnt offerings and the peace offerings, and we will say, “Sing to God, etc.”
So will everyone say.

text.title: God has sat upon His holy throne:

pasuk.text: Now the throne is complete and the greatness is recognized, and they will declare that the volunteers of the people have gathered to His city.
Who offered themselves to the slaughter, to be slain for the sanctity of His name.

text.title: the people of the God of Abraham:

pasuk.text: who was the first volunteer, the first of the proselytes [he was the first to volunteer himself to proselytize]. Now it is known that

text.title: God has the shields of the earth:

pasuk.text: and He has the power to be a shield for all who trust in Him.

text.title: in the city of our God:

pasuk.text: In the future, when He builds His city, He will be great and praised because of it.

Heb. יפר נוף, a city that is a fair branch; an expression of the branches (נוף) of a tree. Another explanation: A fair bride, for in the coastal cities they call a bride ninfe (nymphe in Greek) (R. H. 26a). Menachem (p. 124) associated it with (Josh. 17:11) “the three regions (הנפת) ” (i.e., there [on Joshua] he explains that it means regions; as Rashi explains there: contree in French, a region. In this manner, Rashi explains in Joshua 11:3,) but Dunash (p. 34) defined it as an expression of a branch of a tree, and Mt. Zion was called “the fairest of branches” because it is (nearShem Ephraim) the Mount of Olives.

text.title: the joy of the entire earth:

pasuk.text: Now what is its joy? The north side, angles in French, angle, corner. Redak (Shorashim) also defines it as corners, and so in Ezekiel (46:21). The northern side of the altar [was] where sin offerings and guilt offerings were slaughtered, and whoever was grieved because of the sins he had committed would bring a sin offering or a guilt offering, and he would be forgiven. He would then emerge happy, and the sacrifices would benefit the entire world.

text.title: He is known as a stronghold:

pasuk.text: When He will dwell therein in the future, they will say this [will call Him thus].
to wage war against it in the wars of Gog and Magog.
to war.
the Holy One, blessed be He, going forth and waging war against those nations, so they wondered.
Feront etourdis in French, were stunned, as (Jer. 23:32): “and their bewilderment (ובפחזותם).”

That is an expression of retribution, with which the Holy One, blessed be He, recompenses the wicked, as it is stated (Exod. 14: 21): “and the Lord led the sea with a strong east wind, etc.” Similarly (Ezek. 16:27, 26): “The east wind has broken you in the heart of the seas” ; (Jer. 18:17), “Like an east wind, I will scatter you before the enemy.”
They are the neighbors of Tyre, which is Africa, and it is of Edom.
the consolations from the mouth of the prophets, so have we seen [them].

text.title: We have hoped, O Lord, for Your kindness:

pasuk.text: The prophet repeatedly prays to the Holy One, blessed be He, and says, “We hoped and waited for Your kindness, to see this Your salvation in the midst of Your Temple. Menachem (p. 65) interpreted it as an expression of thought, as (Esther 4:13): ” Do not think (אל תדמי)."

text.title: As is Your name, O God, so is Your praise:

pasuk.text: Just as Your name is great, so is Your praise great in everyone’s mouth.

text.title: the daughters of Judah shall exult:

pasuk.text: All the other cities of Judah are as daughters to Zion, as (Num. 32:42): “and he captured Kenath and its daughters.”

text.title: for the sake of Your judgments:

pasuk.text: That You perform judgment upon the nations.
You who are building it.
Heb. ספרו, an expression of counting. You should know how many towers it requires.
Heb. לחילה, to its walls, as (Lam. 2: 8): “rampart (חיל) and wall.”
Heb. פסגו, raise its palaces, as (Deut. 3:17): “beneath the rapids of the elevation,” which is translated רָמָתָא, the high place.

text.title: in order that you may tell:

pasuk.text: its height and its beauty to the generation after you.
Heb. על-מות, as a man who leads his young son slowly. Menachem (p. 133) interpreted it as an expression of eternity, and so is its interpretation: will lead us to eternity.
Because this psalm is based on people who rely on their riches, he says, “all you peoples,” for they all require admonition.

Heb. חלוד. That [term] is [used to describe] the earth because it is old and rusty (חלודה), rodile in Old French, rust, rouille in modern French. But our Sages explained that it is because of the weasel (חֻלְדָה) , which frequents the dry land but is not found in the sea, for the Rabbis taught (Hul. 127a): Whatever is on the dry land is found in the sea, except the weasel.
The sons of Abraham, who was called (Josh. 14:15): “the greatest man (האדם) among the giants” ; the sons of Ishmael and the sons of Keturah.
The sons of Noah, who was called (Gen. 6:9): “a righteous man צדיק) (איש.”

text.title: and the thoughts of my heart are understanding:

pasuk.text: The thoughts of my heart are understanding.

text.title: I will bend my ear to a parable:

pasuk.text: To the words of Torah, which is called (I Sam. 24: 13), “the parable of the Ancient One.”

this my riddle for you with a lyre. And this is the riddle: Why must I fear in days of misfortune, on the day of the visitation for iniquity? Because the iniquity of my heels surrounds me.
