The iniquities that I tread with my heels, that I treat lightly, that I view as minor sinsthey condemn me in judgment, and surely the wealthy.

text.title: Those who rely on their possessions:

pasuk.text: Of what use is their money? Is it not so that…
cannot ransom his brother with money because the ransom of their soul is dearer than any possession. Therefore, perforce, his redemption is forever unattainable.

that he will live forever and not see the Pit. Menachem (p. 158) associated it as an expression of withholding, as (Isa. 13:12): “I will make mortal man dearer (אוקיר) than fine gold” ; (Lev. 26:21), “I will go with them with wrath of withdrawal (קיר)” i.e., the ransom of their soul will be withheld.

text.title: For he sees that wise men die:

pasuk.text: and are not saved from death. So, perforce, he stops wearying himself and toiling for his brother’s ransom.

Heb. חילם, their money. Death is mentioned in reference to the wise men, because in this world they die only in the body, whereas concerning the fool and the boorish man, perishing is mentioned, because both body and soul perish.

text.title: In their heart, their houses are forever:

pasuk.text: Their thoughts are to build for themselves houses that will exist forever.
their houses that they build so that they will have a memorial. (Gen. 4:17): “and named the city after his son Enoch.” Antiochus built Antioch; Seleucus built Seleucia.
Heb. ביקר, an expression of glory and majesty.
Heb. נמשל, an expression of a parable (משל).
Heb. נדמו, an expression of silence.
Heb. כסל, madness.

text.title: and after them they will tell with their mouth forever:

pasuk.text: And those who come after them will speak of them and tell with their mouth what happened to the earlier ones.

Heb. ירצו, an expression of narration, retreyront in Old French, But our Sages (Shab. 32b) explained: This is the way of the wicked: they perish in the end but כֶסֶל is theirs. They have fat on their flanks (כסליהם), which covers their kidneys, and they [their kidneys] do not advise them to repent of their evil. Perhaps you will say that it is forgetfulness, that they have forgotten that ultimately they will die? Scripture therefore states: and their end they tell with their mouth; i.e., the day of their end is constantly in their mouth and they are not afraid of it.

text.title: Like sheep, they are destined to the grave:

pasuk.text: Like sheep that are gathered to the shed, so are they into the grave.

Heb. שתו. The “tav” is punctuated with a “dagesh,” in place of the second “tav.” שּׁוֹתתוּ into the midst of the foundations (שתותיה) of the nether world, to the lowest level. Likewise (above 73:9): “They have set their mouth against heaven,” is also an expression of foundations; they set their mouth in heaven; their slander.

Heb. ירעם. The angel of death will devour them. Do not wonder about this expression of eating because we find elsewhere (Job 18:13): “the prince of death shall devour his branches.” Another explanation: [It is] an expression of breaking, as (Jer. 15:12): “Will iron break (הירע) ?”

text.title: and the upright will rule over them in the morning:

pasuk.text: On the day of the redemption, when the morning of Israel shines, they will rule over them, as it is stated (Malachi 3:21): “And You shall crush the wicked, etc.”

text.title: and their form will outlast the grave:

pasuk.text: The form of the wicked will outlast the grave. Gehinnom will end, but they will not end.

From being a dwelling place for them. And the Holy One, blessed be He, takes the sun out of its case, and it will burn them up, as it is stated (Mal. 3:19, Ned. 8b). Our Sages, however, explained מִזְבֻל לוֹ to mean that because they stretched out their hand on His dwelling place, they destroyed the Temple (Mid. Ps. 49:3).

text.title: But God will redeem my soul:

pasuk.text: But I, who have bent my ear to the parableGod will redeem my soul so that I do not go to the grave, because He will take me in my lifetime to go in His ways.

text.title: Because in his lifetime he blesses himself:

pasuk.text: The wicked man blesses himself during his lifetime and says, “All will be well with you, my soul. No harm will befall you.” But others do not say so about him.

text.title: but [all] will praise you, for you will benefit yourself:

pasuk.text: But you, if you hearken to my words, all will praise you, for you will benefit your soul by straightening your way.

text.title: You shall come to the generation of his forefathers:

pasuk.text: When you complete your days and die, you will come and see the generation of the wicked man being judged in Gehinnom, so that they will not see light to eternity.

text.title: Man is in his glory but he does not understand:

pasuk.text: The way of life is placed before him; if he follows it, he will be honored, but he does not understand the good [resulting therefrom].

text.title: God of gods is the Lord:

pasuk.text: I shall call (the God of godsYHWH is His name).

text.title: spoke and called to the earth:

pasuk.text: The entire earth, but He appeared from Zion, which is the adornment of beauty. מִכְלַל is a noun, parement in Old French, adornment. He [Asaph] prophesies concerning the future redemption.

text.title: Our God shall come and not be silent:

pasuk.text: any longer concerning the spilt blood of His servants.

text.title: He shall call to the heavens:

pasuk.text: to visit upon the celestial princes of the peoples.
to visit upon the kings of the earth.
Heb. לדין, to avenge the vengeance of His people, as (Deut. 32:36): “For the Lord shall judge His people, and He shall avenge the blood of His servants.”

text.title: Gather to Me My devoted ones:

pasuk.text: And He will further call to the heavens and the earth that they gather the exiles to Him, as the matter that is stated (Song 4:16): “Awake, O north wind, and come, O south wind.”

text.title: who made a covenant with Me over a sacrifice:

pasuk.text: Who received the Torah with a covenant and a sacrifice, as it is stated (Exod. 24: 8): “Behold the blood of the covenant, which the Lord has made with you.”

text.title: I will not reprove you concerning your sacrifices:

pasuk.text: If you do not bring Me sacrifices, and your burnt offerings are not before Me constantly. I do not set My eyes and My heart on that.

text.title: I will not take from your household a bull:

pasuk.text: They are not yours but Mine.
Heb. ממכלאתיך. That is a sheepfold, as (Habakkuk 3:17): “the flock shall be cut off from the fold (ממכלה).” Parc in French, pen.

text.title: the behemoth of the thousand mountains:

pasuk.text: That is (the bull) destined for the future feast [of the righteous], which grazes on a thousand mountains daily, and every day they grow back. Others explain this to mean one thousand mountains or one thousand parasangs (i.e., one mountain that is 1, 000 parasangs long, or perhaps it should read: 1,000 bulls. The plural “mountains” indicates that there were many mountains of that type.[Shem Ephraim]) Others explain that this is like (Deut. 7: 13): “the litter of your cattle (אלפיך).” i.e., mountains full of cattle, because he says, “I will not take from your household a bull.”

text.title: and the creeping things of the field are with me:

pasuk.text: Heb. זיז, the creeping things of the field. They are called זִיז because they move (זזים) from place to place; esmoubemant in Old French, movement.
I know them all.

text.title: Will I eat the flesh of bulls:

pasuk.text: I did not order you to bring a sacrifice because I need to eat, but it is My pleasure that I spoke and My will was performed.
Confess your deeds and return to Me. That is the sacrifice that I desire, and afterwards pay the Most High your vows, for then they will be accepted willingly.
For this is My honor, that I will save those who trust in Me.

text.title: and bring up My covenant on your mouth:

pasuk.text: My Torah.
You agreed to go with him.

text.title: you accustomed your tongue to deceit:

pasuk.text: Heb. תצמיד. You accustom deceit to be with you; to speak evil. תצמיד is ajouter in French, to join, as (Num. 19:15): “a cover (צמיד) bound.”
in the company of the scorners.
with whom you have no [legal] quarrel, since he does not inherit with you.
Heb. דפי, defamation to cast him off, an expression of (Num. 35:20): “he pushes him off (יהדפנו).”
You thought that I would be like you, to condone your evil deeds; (and others explain: you thought that I do not know what is hidden.)

text.title: One who slaughters a confession sacrifice:

pasuk.text: [One] who brings Me a sacrifice of repentance and confession for his iniquities, honors Me.
for the one who returns to Me. I teach and prepare the way for sinners to return to Me (and he who returns to MeShem Ephraim), I will show him My salvation.

text.title: and my sin is always before me:

pasuk.text: Since I regret [my sin] and worry about it, it is as though it is constantly before me, always.

text.title: Against You alone have I sinned:

pasuk.text: Therefore, it is in Your power to forgive [me]. Even in my sin against Uriah, I sinned against You, for You warned against the matter.

text.title: in order that You be justified in Your conduct:

pasuk.text: like במנהגך, in Your conduct. I had the strength to overpower my evil inclination, but, so that they should not say, “The servant overpowered his master,” for I said to You (Ps. 26:2), “Test me, O Lord, and try me,” and You tested me and I was not found perfect, in order that You should be justified and not I (Sanh. 107a). Another explanation:

text.title: in order that You be justified in Your conduct:

pasuk.text: If You forgive me, You will be justified in Your judgment against all the wicked who do not repent, so that they will not be able to say, “If we had repented, it would not have availed us.”

text.title: Behold, with iniquity I was formed:

pasuk.text: Now how could I not sin when the main part of my creation was through coitus, the source of many iniquities? Another explanation: The main part of my creation is from a male and a female, both of whom are full of iniquity. There are many midrashim to this verse, but they do not fit the context of the psalm.
Heb. יחמתני, an expression of heat, as (Gen. 30:38): “And they came into heat (ויחמנה) when they came to drink.”

text.title: Behold, You desired that truth be in the hidden places:

pasuk.text: and behold, I confess to the truth, that I sinned.

Heb. בטחות. These are the reins, which are smooth. Menachem (p. 97), however, associated it with (Gen. 21: 16): “as it were a bowshot (כמטחוי קשת) ” ; and so (Job 38: 36): “Who placed wisdom in the inward parts (בטחות).” And their interpretation is an expression of drawing, for just as a bow is drawn, so is their yearning for knowledge.

text.title: and in the concealed part You teach me wisdom:

pasuk.text: And in the heart, which is concealed, You have taught me wisdom to confess.
As one purifies the “mezora” and the one who became unclean through contact with a corpse.

text.title: Make me hear joy and gladness:

pasuk.text: The forgiveness of the sin.
when You were wroth with me.

text.title: Create for me a pure heart, O God:

pasuk.text: so that I do not stumble again.

text.title: and do not take Your holy spirit from me:

pasuk.text: that the holy spirit should not be withdrawn from me.

text.title: Restore to me the joy of Your salvation:

pasuk.text: The holy spirit, which has left me.
Heb. נדיבה, an expression of nobility and leadership.

text.title: I will teach transgressors Your ways:

pasuk.text: and they will learn from me. They will repent if they see that You forgive me.
that I should not die by the sword as a punishment for Uriah, whom I killed.

text.title: O Lord, You shall open my lips:

pasuk.text: Forgive me so that I will be able to open my lips to recite Your praise.

text.title: For You do not wish a sacrifice:

pasuk.text: Because a sacrifice of a sin offering is not brought for a willful transgression.
For if You desired it, I would give it to You.
to build Your Temple in its midst in the days of my son, Solomon.

text.title: Why do you boast of evil, you mighty man?:

pasuk.text: Why do you boast and brag of the evil that you do, you who are mighty in Torah?

to rescue the one whom you pursue. Another explanation: God’s kindness is constant. Had Abimelech not given me bread, do you think that I would have died of hunger? God always shows kindness toward Israel, and if he had not given me [to eat], others would have given me.
Heb. מְלֻטֳשּׁ.
Cutting the flesh with the hair.
Heb. יתצך, an expression of demolition (נתיצה).
Heb. יחתך, an expression of breaking.
Heb. ויסחך, and shall tear you out.
He shall uproot after you, to tear out all the roots; esraciner or esraziner in Old French, to uproot, deraciner in modern French.
And this is the ridicule they will say about him: “Behold! This is the man who does not place his trust in the Holy One, blessed be He. See what happened to him.”

text.title: he strengthened himself in his wickedness:

pasuk.text: Heb. יעז בהותו.
who am now being pursued by you, will be like an olive tree, fresh with children and grandchildren, in the house of the Holy One, blessed be He.
When You do this for me. This verse is addressed to the Holy One, blessed be He.

The name of a musical instrument. Another explanation: concerning the malady (מחלתן) of Israel when the Temple will be destroyed. He already recited another psalm resembling this one (above 14): “The fool said in his heart, ‘there is no God, etc.’”, One relates to the destruction of the First Temple and this one, to the Second Temple.

text.title: The fool said in his heart:

pasuk.text: This is Titus; when he cut into the curtain and his sword was dripping with blood, he said that he had killed [God] Himself.
Heb. סג, an expression of סיגים, dross.
of all his armies will protest against his deeds.
Should not those who devour My people like a meal of bread, and who did not call upon the Lord, know that ultimately they will experience there a great fear at the end of days?

This fear was not like the first fear that came over Belshazzar, for in this redemption the Holy One, blessed be He, scattered the bones of חוֹנָ, those who camp around you, Jerusalem, as the matter that is stated (Zech. 14:12): “His flesh will waste away, etc.” Menachem (p. 91) interpreted it that way, but Dunash (pp. 63f.) interpreted it as (Prov. 22:6): “Train (חנך) a child according to his way” ; the “chaph” of חוֹנָ is a radical as the “chaph” of חֲנֹ, train.

text.title: You have put them to shame:

pasuk.text: You, O Lord, have put all my enemies to shame, for You have rejected them.

text.title: and with Your might, avenge me:

pasuk.text: Heb. תדינני, Wreak my vengeance, as (Deut. 32:36): “When the Lord will avenge (ידין) His people.”

text.title: to those who lie in wait for me:

pasuk.text: Heb. לשררי, those who eye me, an expression of (Num. 24:17): “I see him (אשורנו), but not near.”
Since You are truthful, and You said that You would wreak vengeance upon talebearers and those who pursue to kill, therefore, cut them off.

Heb. אריד, I will lament of my pain, as (Lam. 3:19): “Remember my affliction and my misery (ומרודי).” Also (Jud. 11:37): “and wail (וירדתי) upon the mountains.” Menachem (p. 162) interpreted אריד as an expression of ruling, as (Gen. 1:28): “and rule (ורדו) over the fish of the sea.” שּׂיחי is an expression of speech (Prov. 23:29): “He who talks too much (שיח).”
Heb. עקת, an expression of distress.

text.title: for they accuse me of iniquity:

pasuk.text: Doeg and Ahithophel accuse me of iniquities that overweigh [the scale] to demonstrate that I am liable to death, and they sanction [the shedding of] my blood.
Heb. יחיל, worries.

text.title: Behold I would wander far away…:

pasuk.text: and…

text.title: I would quickly find myself a refuge:

pasuk.text: If I had wings, I would wander far away and hasten to save my soul from their hands, for they are like a sweeping wind, a storm wind, which uproots trees, as (Job 19:10): “He has uprooted (ויסע) like a tree.” But Menachem (p. 127) associated it with (Exod.12:37): "And the children of Israel traveled (ויסעו).
Divide it so that no one should pay them heed. And Menachem (p. 142) interpreted פלג as an expression of division.
(Defey or defay in Old French, destroy, defais in modern French,) like (Lam. 2: 8): “He did not restrain his hand from destroying (מבלע).” So did Menachem interpret it [p. 46].

text.title: for I have seen violence and strife in the city:

pasuk.text: through them.
i.e., the violence and the strife.
Heb. הוות.
Heb. תוֹ.
all my life that I should bear my vilification, but I rose up against him and slew him.

text.title: my enemy did not open his mouth:

pasuk.text: that I should flee and hide from him, but now I bear the abuse with which you reviled me because you are a man who is great in Torah.
A man as important as I.

Heb. ומידעי, like אלוּפי, my prince, an expression of (Exod. 33: 17): “and I recognized you (ואדעך),” which is translated וְרַבִּיתָ “and I made you great.” Menachem (p. 94), however, explained that “For no enemy would revile me that I should bear” is connected to (verse 7): “If only I had wings like a dove! I would fly away and be at rest.” If I could raise my wings, I would fly away and wander on account of the distress of the wicked [inflicted upon me], for when I would leave the midst of the assembly of the profligate to lodge in the desert forever, then no enemy would revile me; I would not [have to] bear my disgrace and my shame, and I would not hide from him as I hid from them when I was among them. However, this interpretation is impossible, because of the verses following it, namely: And you are a man of my equal, my prince, and my esteemed one (verse 14); that together we would devise counsel; in the house of God we would walk with a multitude (verse 15). Therefore, Dunash (p. 94) interprets it in another manner, and this is its interpretation: For it is not an enemy who reviles me that I should bear my abuse, and it is not my enemy who opens his mouth wide against me, but my prince and my esteemed one, that together we would take counsel; in the house of God we would walk with a multitude. This thing is known, that the abuse of a friend is harder for a person [to bear] than the abuse of an enemy. Moreover, one can hide from his enemy, but one cannot hide from his friend when he tells him all that is in his heart. The context corroborates this [interpretation].
we used to devise counsel in the Torah and in the house of God we would walk בְרָגֶשּׁ, with a multitude.
In the study-halls.

text.title: May He incite Death upon them:

pasuk.text: May the Holy One, blessed be He, incite the Angel of Death upon them. Heb. יַשִּׁיא, incite and entice, an expression of (Gen. 3:13): “The serpent enticed me and I ate.” Menachem (p. 101) interpreted יַשִּׁיא, as an expression of יש, there is, as (Gen. 24:49): “If you wish (ישכם) to do kindness” ; (Deut. 29:14), “who is (ישנו) here.”
במגורם, in their lodging.
The evening prayer, the morning prayer, and the afternoon prayer, three prayers.

text.title: from the battle that came upon me:

pasuk.text: from the war that came upon me.

text.title: because of the many [people who] were with me:

pasuk.text: For He did this because of the many people who came to my aid to pray on my behalf, as it is stated (I Sam. 18:16): “And all Israel and Judah loved David.”
the prayer of those many people.
the King, Who dwells from time immemorial.

text.title: for there is no passing for them:

pasuk.text: For those wicked men who pursue me. They do not pay heed to the day of their passing, and they do not quake from the day of death.
This refers to Ahithophel the wicked.
Heb. שלח, tandit or tondet in Old French, stretched forth, tendait in modern French.

text.title: against him who was at peace with him:

pasuk.text: Heb. בשלמיו, against him who was tranquil and at peace with him.
Heb. חלקו, an expression of (above 35:6): “and slippery (וחלקלקות).”

text.title: the buttery words of his mouth:

pasuk.text: Heb. מחמאת, an expression of חמאה butter. The first “mem” is a defective radical in the word, like the “mem” of מעשה and the “mem” of מאמר.

text.title: but his heart was set on war:

pasuk.text: Heb. וקרב, to war.

Heb. פתחות. Menachem (p. 147) interpreted it as an expression of swords, as (Micah 5:5): “and the land of Nimrod with its swords (בפתחיה),” with the edges of the sword. I say, however, that it is an expression of curse in Aramaic, as the Talmud (R.H. 31b) states: Amemar wrote a pethicha on her, which is a warrant decreeing excommunication.
Heb. יהבך, your burden. The Holy Spirit answers him thus.

Heb. יכלכלך. He will bear your burden, as (I Kings 8: 27): "the heaven and the heaven of heavens cannot contain You (יכלכלוך). The expression of כלכול is rendered מסובר, bearing, in Targum Jonathan ben Uzziel.
Heb. מוט, the faltering of the foot.

He said this concerning himself, for he was with Achish, far from the land of Israel, and Goliath’s brothers were requesting permission from Achish to kill him, as it is said (I Sam. 21:12): “Is this not David, the king of the land?” And he was among them as a mute dove.
Heb. שאפנו, yearn to swallow me up, goloseir or goloser, to long, to be impatient. (Cf. Rashi to Amos 2:7.) As (Jer. 2:24): “that snuffs up (שאפה) the wind.”
Heb. לחם, an expression of war (מלחמה).
The Holy One blessed be He, Who dwells on High.

text.title: With God, I will praise His word:

pasuk.text: Even when He deals with me with the Divine standard of justice I will praise His word and trust in Him.

text.title: All day long, my words grieve [me]:

pasuk.text: My pursuers grieve me until all the words of my mouth are grief and cries.

They lurk and lodge in the place they hope I will go, and they watch my steps (traces in French, tracks, explained in Gen. 49:19, Song of Songs 1:8) to spy on me and to lead pursuers there. All this he would complain about the wicked of Israel: that they would lie in wait for him and out of fear of them he had fled to Achish.
They lurk.

text.title: when they hope for my life:

pasuk.text: When they know [that I will pass] and hope for me, “He will go this way.”
To find rescue and riches for a matter of iniquity and wickedness. And פַלֶט is like לפלט, to rescue. They expect reward from Saul for that.
With Your anger, bring down this nation in whose midst I am, from their wisdom and from the plots that they devise to kill me.
You know the number of the places to which I wandered, to flee.

text.title: place my tears in Your flask:

pasuk.text: Place my tears in Your flask, and let them be preserved before You.

text.title: Is it not in Your accounting:

pasuk.text: Place them in Your accounting, to count them with the rest of my troubles. Menachem, however, associated it (p. 128) as an expression of an actual book.

text.title: With God I will praise a word; with the Lord I will praise:

pasuk.text: For the Divine standard of justice and for the Divine standard of mercy I will praise.
To return to the Land of Israel.
David called this psalm by this name because he was near death, and he established this psalm, saying, “Do not destroy me, O Lord.”

text.title: Be gracious to me, etc., be gracious to me:

pasuk.text: that I should neither kill nor be killed.
Heb. הוות, until the evil passes.

text.title: from the disgrace of him who yearns to swallow me up:

pasuk.text: And He will save me from the disgrace of ֹשֹאַפִי, who says to swallow me up, golosa moy in Old French, longs to swallow me up. (See above 56:2.)
Abner and Amassa, who were “lions” [leaders] the in Torah, and who do not protest against Saul.

text.title: I lie among men who are aflame:

pasuk.text: En flanboyanz, or enflamoyonz, among those who are flaming. Among the Ziphim, who are aflame after slander.
Withdraw from the earthlings, who are unworthy of having Your Shechinah rest among them, and on the earth You shall be honored by this.
i.e., the enemy.
They will ultimately fall into it. כפף is cline, or clina in Old French, bent, bent down, an expression of (below 145:14): “and straightens all who are bent down (הכפופים).”

text.title: My heart is steadfast with God, my heart is steadfast:

pasuk.text: Faithful to You in the Divine standard of justice and faithful to You in the Divine standard of mercy.
and let me not sleep until three hours [of the day have passed], as other kings do.
Awaken me, you lyre and harp hanging on my bed, open to the north side. And as soon as midnight arrived, the north wind would blow on it, and David would get up and engage in Torah.
I awaken the dawn; the dawn does not awaken me.
The name of the melody of a song.
Heb. האמנם. This is an expression of truth.

text.title: Is it true that you were silent about the righteousness that you should have spoken, etc.:

pasuk.text: He recited this psalm concerning [the incident] when he entered the barricade where Saul was lying, took the spear and the jug, went away, and called, “Will you not answer, Abner?” (I Sam. 26:14). That is to say, “Shouldn’t you now prove to Saul and show him that he pursues me for no reason? For had I wished, I would have killed him.” And so did he say in his song: Is it true that the righteousness that you should have said and the equities with which you should have judged have been silenced from your mouth? The righteousness that you should have spoken.

text.title: Even in your heart, you plot injustice:

pasuk.text: And not only that, but in your heart you plot evil, to do injustice.
lit. wrongs, like עַוָלוֹת as one says from שוֹר, שורים, and from עיר, עירים (Jud. 10:4): “and they had thirty cities (עירים),” which is an expression of עיר, a city.

text.title: in the earth, you weigh down the violence of your hands:

pasuk.text: Inside the earth, you weigh down the violence of your hands until it is very heavy. תְפַלֵּסוּן is contrepesez or contrepezeres in Old French, you outweigh. (See Isa. 26:7.)

text.title: The wicked become estranged [even] from the womb:

pasuk.text: From their mother’s womb they become strange to the Holy One, blessed be He, in the way that Esau did (Gen. 25:22): “And the children moved violently against each other in her womb.”

Heb. זֹרו, like נזורוּ, the same construction as (Jer. 2:12): “O heavens (שֹמו) , be astonished” ; (Gen. 49:23), “they heaped bitter abuse upon him and became [his] opponents (ורֹבו) ” ; (Job 24:24), “They are taken away (רוֹמוּ) in a second.” All these are in the passive voice.
They have venom to kill people, like the venom of a serpent.

text.title: like a deaf cobra that closes its ear:

pasuk.text: When the snake ages, it becomes deaf in one ear, and closes the other ear with dust so that it should not hear the incantation of the charmer, adjuring it not to cause injury.
This is connected to the preceding verse: “and it closes its ear in order not to hear the voice of charmers.”
who knows how to charm snakes.
The inner teeth, called messelers in Old French, molars, grinders.
by themselves, that they will be rejected in their own eyes from worry, and as [if] in water let them walk. Similar to this is (Ezek. 7:17): “and all knees will go [as in] water,” from tears.
i.e., the Holy One, blessed be He, so that they will be cut off. יתמֹללוּ is soyent preciz, let them be cut off.

Heb. שבלול. Some interpret it as limace in Old French, a snail (as in Lev. 11:30). Others interpret it as שבֹּלת, a current of water (below 69:16). The “lammed” is doubled, as from (Job 18:16): “his branch will be cut off (ימל) ; (below 90:6),” will be cut off (ימולל) and will dry up."
it continuously melts. תֶּמֶס is a noun, the “mem” being the fundamental radical and the “tav” a defective radical, like the “tav” of (Lev. 20:12): “they committed a disgraceful act (תבל).”

Heb. נפל אשת, talpe in Old French, which has no eyes. It is identified as תִּנְשֶׁמֶת (in Lev. 11:30), translated [by Onkelos] as אשותא. So did our Sages explain it (M.K. 6b). Others explain it as a stillbirth of a woman. אשת is like (Ezek. 23:44): “women of (אשת) lewdness.” There is a “tav” without the construct state, as (Prov. 4:9): “she will transmit to you, a crown of glory תפארת) (עטרת,” like “a stillbirth of a woman (אשה),” for the stillbirths born did not see the sun. According to the former explanation, it is like נפל ואשת, a stillbirth and a mole, as (Jer. 11:19): “And I was like a lamb a bull (ככבש אלוף),” which Menachem explained: like a lamb and a bull (ככבש ואלוף). That is, a bull; here too, a stillbirth and a mole נפל ואשת. It is proper to emend.

text.title: Before your tender briars develop into hardened thorns:

pasuk.text: lit. before your tender briars know hardened thorns. That before your tender briars know to be hardened thorns, i.e., before the children of the wicked grow up.
i.e., with might, with strength, and with wrath will the Holy One, blessed be He, drive them away as [with] a storm wind.
חי is an expression of might.

text.title: And man will say, “Truly, the righteous man has reward”:

pasuk.text: Then people will say, “Surely there is reward and recompense in the deeds of the righteous, since the Holy One, blessed be He, avenged their wrongs.”
A Judge, Who judges the wicked on the earth.
He called the psalm by this name because he was close to dying and to being destroyed, and he begged for mercy in the matter.
when Michal told them that he was ill (I Sam. 19:14) and she allowed him to flee at night.
to enter my house, to guard me.
I did not sin against them.
Ready to kill.

text.title: arise to visit upon all the nations:

pasuk.text: And judge these wicked men according to the statutes of the nations. Do not be gracious to them.

text.title: They return in the evening, etc… Behold, they spew forth with their mouth:

pasuk.text: The interpretation of these two verses connects one to the other.

What they did by day does not suffice them; in the evening they repeat their evil: guarding me that I do not escape and leave the city Now what did they do by day? Behold, all day they spew forth with their mouth, to spy on me to Saul.
and they think to themselves, “Who hears?”
Who will scoff at all the nations, will mock these wicked men as well.
The strength and might of my enemy, who is stronger than I.
and I wait [for You] to rescue me from him.
He will give me His help before the hand of my enemy overwhelms me.

text.title: will allow me to see in those who watch me:

pasuk.text: what I long to see.
because this is not recognizable [as] revenge.
because all the dead are forgotten. Instead, deprive them of their possessions, so that they are impoverished. That is the revenge that will be long remembered.
of their mouth is the word of their lips, and the poor who are pursued by them because of the curse and the lies that they tell, are seized through their haughtiness.
Destroy them with Your wrath, O King Who judges, and let them know that You rule over Jacob.

text.title: And they will return in the evening:

pasuk.text: This is attached to the preceding verse. The sin of their mouth they speak by day, and in the evening, they return to ambush those whom they slandered.

text.title: They will roam about to eat:

pasuk.text: as the dogs do all night if they are not sated, so that they can lodge out of satiety, and sleep.
when I escape them, I will sing of Your power in the morning.
To You, Who are my strength and my stronghold, to You I will sing.

text.title: on shushan eduth, a michtam of David, to teach:

pasuk.text: (Addendum: Michtam is an expression of (Song 5:11), “as finest gold (כתם פז),” a coveted thing. Our Sages, however, expounded this as referring to David, who behaved as a humble (מך) and innocent man, even when he occupied the throne. Another Aggadah explains that his wound (מכתו) was perfect (תמה), i.e., he was born circumcised (Sotah 10b). Michtam of David concerning the testimony of the Sanhedrin, who were compared to a rose (שושן) , as it is stated (Song 7:3): “Your navel is like a round basin, etc., fenced in with roses,” when he required that they teach him what to do. When he fought with Aram Naharaim and sent Joab against them, they said to Joab, “Aren’t you of the sons of Jacob? Where is the oath that he swore to Laban, ‘this pile is a witness’” (Gen. 31:52)? And he did not know what to answer. He came to David and said to David, “This is what the Arameans said to me.” They went and asked the Sanhedrin, [who] replied to them, “Did they not transgress the oath first, as it is stated (Num. 23:7): ‘From Aram has Balak king of Moab brought me’? Moreover, Cushan- Rishathaim was an Aramean.”

text.title: and Joab returned and smote of Edom, etc.:

pasuk.text: [of] the eighteen thousand stated in Scripture (II Sam. 8:13, I Chron. 18:12), Abishai slew six thousand the first time, and Joab slew twelve thousand when he returned from battling Aram.
Heb. בהצותו, as (Num. 26:9): “when they quarreled (בהצותם) with the Lord,” that he fought with them because they aided the Ammonites.

text.title: You have forsaken us; You have breached us:

pasuk.text: When Edom fell into his hand, he foresaw with the holy spirit that they are destined to rule over Israel and to levy evil decrees upon Israel. He stood up and begged for mercy on account of the subjugation of the exile.“We suffered many troubles in the time of the Judges from the enemies around us.”
You were angry with us. From now on, restore Your goodwill upon us.
our land, with many troops.

Heb. פצמתה, You broke it. I saw in Dunash’s writings (p. 68) that it is Arabic, but he did not explain it. In the works of Rabbi Moshe Hadarshan, he explains it as an expression of tearing and cites evidence for that assertion (from Jer. 22:14): “And he cuts out windows,” which Jonathan translates, וּפצים. But I say that וּפצים, as Jonathan translated, is an expression of the construction of a window, as “all the entrances that have door frames (פצימין).”

text.title: heal its breaches for it has faltered:

pasuk.text: Heb. רפה, an expression of healing. Although it is spelled with a “hey,” many words are used in this manner.
An expression of lowliness.

Heb. תרעלה. [Wine] that stops up the heart and envelops it. רַעַל is an expression of envelopment, as (Nahum 2:4): “and the cypresses are enwrapped (הרעלו) ,” and the language of the Mishnah (Shab. 6:6): “Median women shawled (רעולות).”

text.title: You have given those who fear You trials:

pasuk.text: Trials of many troubles.
With which to be tested whether they would stand [steadfast] in awe of You.

To beautify Your standards in the world, so that when You give them goodness, the gentiles will not criticize You, but they will beautify Your judgments and say that He justly did good to them because they passed many tests for Him.
Should be saved from harm.
which You brought back so that their enemies should overpower them.
For, if You answer me, they will be rescued, because I fight against them [the enemies] for them [Israel].
that He would gather the exiles and his [David’s] seed would rule over them. Another explanation: God spoke in His Sanctuary [saying] that I would be king over them.

in His salvation. In another explanation, I found: God spoke in His Sanctuaryto help me, as it is written (II Sam. 3: 18): “For (sic) by the hand of My bondsman David shall I deliver My people Israel.”
I will divide for them a portion of the property of their enemies.

text.title: and I will measure the valley of Succoth:

pasuk.text: I do not know of what nation this Succoth is, and I do not know where the Succoth is that Israel came to when they traveled from Rameses. In other commentaries I found (this is not in all editions): I will divide ShechemI will restore to them the heritage of their father Jacob. Another explanation:

text.title: And I will measure the valley of Succoth:

pasuk.text: when I divide it for Israel. Shechem and Succoth were at the edge of the land of Canaan, as we find Jacob’s entry to the land through Succoth and Shechem. Another explanation:

text.title: and I will measure the valley of Succoth:

pasuk.text: Succoth is an expression of shapes and imaginations, as is written (II Kings 17:30): “Succoth-Benoth.”
I measure their form, as is written (II Sam. 8:2): “two cord-lengths to put to death and one full cord-length to keep alive.”
to reign over them.

My ministers. מחקקי is an expression of administration, that he makes the law and sends scrolls and commands, as (Gen. 49:10): “The scepter will not turn away from Judah, nor the lawgiver from between his feet.”
I will use them as a copper pot prepared for washing therein.
Heb. נעלי, my imprisonment.
Join my kingdom to be subordinate to me, for Gath, and also Gaza, which David vanquished, are of the land of the Philistines.

text.title: Who will bring me to a fortified city:

pasuk.text: then to a fortified city, to conquer the city of Rome; if You will not help me against the fortress of Edom, who will bring me and who will lead me upon them? (Shem Ephraim suggests this emendation: If You will not help me now to conquer Edom, upon which You have now led me.) In other commentaries, I found as follows: upon the fortresses of Edom, upon whom You have led me now.
and You do not go forth.
[as translated.]

text.title: From the end of the earth:

pasuk.text: although I am far from my men whom I send against my enemies in battle.

text.title: I call out to You when my heart becomes faint:

pasuk.text: because of them. Now, about what do I call out to You? That You lead me on a rock, which is higher and stronger than I.

text.title: I shall dwell in Your tent to eternity:

pasuk.text: Grant me the privilege in this world and in the world to come.

text.title: You have given the heritage of those who fear Your name:

pasuk.text: You have restored the cities of their heritage through me.

text.title: Add days to the days of the king:

pasuk.text: If it has been decreed upon me to die young, add days to my days until my years will equal seventy years, as the years of every generation.
[May] the king dwell forever before God.
with which he engages himself will be prepared to guard him.
Heb. מן. Preparation, as (Jonah 4:6): “And the Lord… appointed (וימן) a kikayon.”
Just as You will benefit me, so will I sing praises to Your name by paying my vows every day.
The name of a musical instrument. The Midrash Aggadah, though, [explains it to mean]: concerning the ordinances (דתות) and laws that are decreed upon Israel by their enemies.
Heb. דומיה. My soul hopes, as (above 37: 7): “Wait (דום) for the Lord and hope for Him.”
Great falterings. According to the Midrash Aggadah (Mid. Ps. 62:2), “greatly” refers to Gehinnom.

Heb. תהותתו. Menachem (p. 69) explained it as derived from (Jer. 12:9): “come (התיו) to eat” ; (Deut. 33:21), “He came (ויתא) to the head of the people.” How long will you gather against a man? But it appears to me that it should be interpreted as an expression of הַוּוֹת destruction, and the “hey” and “tav” are the radical. As one says from מֵת, מוֹת, so shall we say from the root הֵת, הוֹת, and the plural is הוּוֹת. It is an expression of a destructive and deceitful plot. Others explain תְּהוֹתֲתוּ as “you extend.” i.e., you extend your tongue on the sons of men with evil, and they compared it to Arabic, when one speaks overly much.
which is ready to fall upon the sons of men.
Because you are afraid of people (sic) perhaps he will reign and repay you your recompense, and your counsel is to cause harm to fall upon him.
of each of them they bless.
But in their thoughts they curse forever.

text.title: The sons of men are but vanity:

pasuk.text: Do not fear them, since God is forever our shelter in time of trouble.

text.title: were they to be put on a scale:

pasuk.text: If they came to go up on a scale, they and their vanities would be equal. This is the simple meaning, but midrashically, it is interpreted as concerning couples (Lev. Rabbah 29:8).
If you see wicked men whose money prospers and increases, pay it no heed. חיל is money.
Heb. ינוב, grows, an expression of produce (תנובה).

I heard two things from it, and what are the two things? First, that God has strength to repay a man according to his deed. Second, that You, O Lord, have kindness. Now, from which statement do we derive this? From the second commandment of the Decalogue. We derive from it that the Holy One, blessed be He, punishes iniquity and preserves kindness, as it is stated therein: “I visit the iniquity of the fathers upon the children, etc.” Therefore, I am confident that He will pay a good reward to the righteous and punishment to the wicked. I learned from the work of Rabbi Moshe Hadarshan, but our Sages interpreted it as referring to [the maxim that] “Remember” and “Keep” were stated in a single utterance.

text.title: And You, O Lord, have kindness:

pasuk.text: And what is the kindness? That You repay a man according to his deed; not really his deed but part of it, as the matter that is stated (Ezra 9:13): “for You, our God, have punished us less than our iniquities [deserve].” In this manner it is interpreted in Aggadath Tehillim (Mid. Ps. 62:4). It may also be interpreted: And You, O Lord, have kindness because You have the power to repay a man according to his deed.
when he was fleeing from Saul.
Heb. אשחרך, I seek and search for You, as (Job 7:21): “and You shall seek me (ושחרתני) , but I am not here” ; (Job 8:5), “If you seek (תשחר) God.”
I thirst and long to come to You in Your house of prayer.
Heb. כמה, an expression of desire. There is no similar [Scriptural expression].
in the desert.

text.title: As I saw You in the Sanctuary, etc.:

pasuk.text: Heb. כן, like כאשר, as. I thirst to see Your strength and Your glory as I saw You in the Sanctuary, the Tabernacle of Shiloh. My soul will be sated with the visions of Your strength and Your glory.

text.title: Then I shall bless You in my lifetime:

pasuk.text: Heb. כן, like אָז, then, because אָז is translated ובכן. That is to say: Then, when I come before You, I shall bless You all the days of my life.

text.title: in Your name I shall lift my hands:

pasuk.text: to pray and laud.

text.title: when my mouth praises with expressions of song:

pasuk.text: Heb. ושפתי, languages of songs, as (Gen. 11:1): “And all the earth was of one language (שפה),” which is translated: לישן חד.
When I lie on my couch, I remember Your love.
of the night.
Heb. אהגה. I think about You.

text.title: Your right hand has supported me:

pasuk.text: that I should not fall.
My enemies.

text.title: seek my soul to make it desolate:

pasuk.text: They come upon me in ambush on a dark day so that I should not sense their presence.

text.title: may they come into the depths of the earth:

pasuk.text: In a low place; let them come and fall into the grave and the pit.

text.title: May he be dragged by the sword:

pasuk.text: May enemies come upon my pursuers and drag each one of them with a sword, killing him. This is an elliptical verse, since it does not explain who will drag him. יגירהוּ is an expression of dragging, as (Micah 1:4): “as water poured down (המוגרים) a steep place” ; (Job. 28:4), “A stream bursts forth from the place of its flow (גר).”
(I found: the portion of foxes May their dwellings be destroyed, that foxes should walk there.)
He says this about himself because he had already been anointed.

text.title: may all who swear by Him boast:

pasuk.text: When they see that You will save me, all those who cleave to You and swear by Your name will boast and praise themselves.
Heb. יסכר, will be closed up, as (Gen. 8:2).“The fountains of the great deep… were closed (ויסכרו).”

text.title: Hear, O God, my voice in my prayer:

pasuk.text: The authors of Aggadoth Tehllim (Mid. Ps.) interpreted this psalm as referring to Daniel, who was cast into the lions’ den. The language of the psalm fits the Aggadah very well. David foresaw with the holy spirit all that would happen to him [Daniel], and prayed for him, because Daniel was his descendant. As was said to Hezekiah (Isa. 39:7): “And they shall take [some] of your sons, etc., whom you shall beget, and they shall be officers in the palace of the king of Babylon.” These are Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah.
These are the satraps, who plotted against him, as it is stated (Dan. 6:5): “Then the viziers and the satraps sought to find a pretext against Daniel.”

text.title: from the gathering of workers of iniquity:

pasuk.text: For they gather seeking against him a pretext of death, as it is written (Dan. 6:7): “… assembled about the king, etc.”
That is their slander.

text.title: To shoot at the innocent in secret places:

pasuk.text: They will shoot him with their arrows.

They speak cunningly to the king secret words, for even the king did not know why they were doing this. But they intended to hide snares to entrap Daniel, for they said to Darius, “All the viziers of the kingdom, etc., have conferred to establish the king’s law, etc.” [stating] that no one should offer up prayer to any god except you until thirty days [have passed].
Heb. עולות. They seek pretexts (עלילות) , as it is stated (Dan. 6: 5): “sought to find a pretext against Daniel.”
Heb. טמנו. They hid their thoughts in their heart and did not reveal the search for a pretext, which was searched out through them, and the midst of their thoughts and the depth of their heart.
Each man of them. Each one concealed his thought.
He cast them into the lions’ den, as it is written (Dan. 6:25): “And the king commanded, and they brought these men who had slandered Daniel, and they cast them into the lions’ den, etc.”

text.title: That which they hoped would make him stumble, their tongue brought upon them:

pasuk.text: The stumbling they planned to inflict on him, their tongue turned over upon them.
Heb. יתנודדו, will shake their head; all who see them should nod their head and laugh about them.
This is Daniel.

text.title: and all upright of heart will boast:

pasuk.text: They will boast about the uprightness of their heart, and they will praise themselves because they are confident that the Holy One, blessed be He, will help them.
Silence is praise to You; because there is no end to Your praise, the more one praises, the more one detracts.
God, Who dwells in Zion. [I found the following:

Not effusion, but silence is praise. It appears that דמיה means “praise God with awe,” with the expression “praise Ya-h.” The name consisting of two letters is translated (Exod. 15:2) as, the fear of God, for “My strength and my praise is God (י-ה).” Also (Exod. 17:16), “For a hand is on the throne of God (י-ה).” And the expression (above 2:11): “and rejoice with quaking” resembles this. Shem Ephraim comments: It appears to me that Rashi should read as follows:

But silence to God is praise, and its interpretation is: Praise Him with awe, etc.“ The intention is that the word דמיה is divided into two words. For it was difficult for him to understand why it should appear that one is to recite any praise of the Holy One, blessed be He. Therefore he says, ” Make glorious His praise, “ but not excessively, for that is equivalent to detracting. Therefore he says,” To You is silence (דום), “ meaning that silence is fitting, but י-ה is praise, i.e., with the name consisting of two letters. His statement that the expression, ” rejoice with quaking “ resembles this, should read: ” Worship the Lord with awe and rejoice with quaking.“ His intention is that both verses mean that one may worship the Lord with awe; that is, one may worship the Holy One, blessed be He, with the name י-ה. Otherwise, worship with love is superior. It is also possible that the reading, ” and it appears that, etc.“ is a copyist’s error. It should read instead: ” But be silent and praise Him with the name י-ה, in the expression Hallelujah. But this needs study. Later I found (below 68:5) that Rashi writes something similar. There, for him to write that the expression “and rejoice with quaking” resembles this is more appropriate, because there it says: “and rejoice before Him.” Compare. Therefore, it appears to me that this entire statement was erroneously copied here.) The gloss belongs below 66:2.] Another explanation:

text.title: To You is silence praise, O God, in Zion:

pasuk.text: That You were silent and still concerning Your enemies’ deeds in Zion is praise to You, for You are able to take revenge, yet You are slow to anger.

text.title: Words of iniquities have overcome me:

pasuk.text: and we cannot manage to arrange them all before You because they are many. However, we offer a general prayer before You that You atone for our transgressions.
he whom You choose and draw near, who will dwell in Your courts.

text.title: let us be sated with the goodness:

pasuk.text: that is in Your house and of the sanctity of Your Temple, in which Your Shechinah dwells.

text.title: With awesome deeds, through [Your] charity You shall answer us:

pasuk.text: Through Your charity, You shall answer us by performing awesome deeds upon the heathens.
You are [the trust] and the refuge of all the dwellers of the ends of the earth, from one end of the earth to the other.
Even to the distant ones in the sea You are the trust, for Your rule is everywhere.

text.title: Who sets mountains with His strength:

pasuk.text: With His strength, He makes the mountainswhich are hardsprout, and He prepares and readies food through them and prepares rain, as it is written (below 147:8): “Who prepares rain for the earth, Who makes the mountains grow grass.”
Because he wishes to mention the mighty deeds of the rains, he says, “Who is girded with might.”
Heb. משביח, He humbles. Similarly (Prov. 29:11): “but afterwards, a wise man will quiet it (ישבחנה) ; (below 89:10),” When it raises its waves, You humble them (תשבחם)."

text.title: with the emergence of the morning and evening, You cause [them] to sing praises:

pasuk.text: [You cause] the creatures who dwell at the extremes to sing praises. In the morning, they say, “Blessed is He Who formed the luminaries,” and in the evening “Blessed is He Who brings about evening.”
When You wish to do good, You remember the earth and water it.
You enrich it greatly from Your stream, which is full of water, and You prepare therewith the corn of the dwellers of “the ends,” for therewith You prepare it.
Heb. תלמיה. They are the rows of the plowshare.
Heb. רוה, like לרוה.

text.title: to afford pleasure to its troops:

pasuk.text: Heb. נחתגדודה, like לְנַחֵתגְדוּדֶהָ, to give rest to its troops. To afford pleasure to its creatures, You dissolve it with drops of rain.
Heb. תמגגנה, an expression of melting.

text.title: You crowned a year of Your goodness:

pasuk.text: Through the rains, You crown with total goodness the year that You wish to benefit.
They are the heavens, which are the dust of Your feet.
The heavens [drip] upon the dwellings of the desert.
The Sharon and the Arabah are clothed with the flocks that come to graze on the grass that the rain causes to grow.

text.title: and valleys are enwrapped with corn:

pasuk.text: Through the rain, the valleys will be enwrapped with grain. Then the creatures will shout with shouts of joy and sing because of the abundant blessing.

text.title: Sing the glory of His name:

pasuk.text: Sing in honor of His name. Or: Recite the glory of His name with music and song.
is each one of Your deeds!

text.title: Through the greatness of Your might:

pasuk.text: When You show the world Your mightthrough pestilence, sword, famine, or lightningYour enemies, the wicked, confess their lies and sins because of their great fear.
Feared by mankind, lest He find a transgression in them, for all their deeds are revealed to You.

text.title: He turned the sea into dry land:

pasuk.text: The Sea of Reeds.
I found: There was a thing with which the sea rejoiced, i.e., that the sea saw the Holy One, blessed be He.
Their hand will not be high.
for His wonders, that He kept our soul alive in exile, and you cannot annihilate us.
with distress in the exile.
to remove the dross from us when we repent before You, as they refine silver to remove its dross.

text.title: You brought us into a trap:

pasuk.text: A narrow place, like in a prison.
Heb. מועקה, an expression of locking up, and every [expression of] מֵעִיק and מֵצִיק is like it.

text.title: You caused man to ride at our head:

pasuk.text: The kings of all the heathen nations.

text.title: I shall come to Your house:

pasuk.text: when You build the Temple, we shall pay our vows that we vowed in exile.
Heb. מיחים, fat, an expression of מוֹחַ, marrow.
They are the proselytes who became converted.

text.title: My mouth called out to Him:

pasuk.text: When we were in exile, we called out to Him, and we recited His exaltation with our tongue.

Heb. ורומם, like ונתרומם, and He was exalted. I found: With my mouth, I called out to Him. ורומם is a noun. His exaltation is ready under my tongue to be let out of my mouth, as (Job 20:12): “though he hide it under his tongue.”
He did not deal with us according to our sins, but He made Himself as though He neither saw nor heard the iniquity that was in our hearts.
indeed you should know.

text.title: Who did not remove my prayer:

pasuk.text: from before Him, and He did not remove His kindness from me.

text.title: He will cause His countenance to shine:

pasuk.text: To show a laughing countenance, to give dew and rain.

text.title: That Your way should be known on earth:

pasuk.text: To make known that Your trait is to benefit Your people, and because of this, kingdoms will rejoice and sing praises.

text.title: for You will judge peoples fairly:

pasuk.text: Favorably.
You will lead them in a fair way; therefore, all peoples will thank You.

text.title: The earth gave forth its produce:

pasuk.text: Also for the earth, which gave forth its produce, and because God will bless us.

text.title: and all the ends of the earth will fear Him:

pasuk.text: for they will say, “See these people, who feared the Lord, how He blessed them and magnified them.”

text.title: May God rise; His enemies scatter:

pasuk.text: Amalek and his ilk.
as it is driven away. As the smoke is driven away so will You drive [them] away.

From before the Ark in the days of Moses. (And it came to pass when the Ark traveled, that Moses said, “Arise, O Lord, and Your enemies will scatter.” Shem Ephraim) And when it rested, he would say, “Return, O Lord, etc.”

text.title: and they will delight with joy:

pasuk.text: And this is the joy, and so will they say, “Sing to God, etc.”
Heb. סולו, an expression of praise. Similarly (Job 28:16): “It cannot be praised (תסלה) with the jewelry of Ophir” ; (Lam. 4:2), “worth their weight (המסלאים) in fine gold.”

By the name י-ה, which is an expression of fear, as we translate it דחילא, fear (below 118: 14): “My might and my praise is the fear of the Lord (י-ה).” Likewise (Exod. 17:16): “For a hand is on the throne of the Lord (י-ה) ,” in the Targum: [And he said, “This is stated with an oath from below the fear of the Shechinah on the throne of His glory, etc.] Similarly (Isa. 26:4): ” for in Yah the Lord, “ is paraphrased by the Targum: for then You will be redeemed by the word of the fear of the Lord, the Strongest of the world.” The Psalmist says, “Praise Him, fear Him, and rejoice.” This resembles what is said elsewhere (above 2: 11): “and rejoice with quaking.”
And this is the praise that You shall praise before Him: the entire matter until the end of the psalm.
Who became a father to Israel, who are orphans, as it is said (Lam. 5:3): “We were orphans without a father.”
Who performed the judgment of Jerusalem, concerning which it says (Lam. 1:1): “was like a widow.”

text.title: settles the solitary in a house:

pasuk.text: Israel, who were spread out. He gathered together each one from the place where he was lost and settled them in a complete household and a complete nation.

text.title: He takes the prisoners out at the most opportune time:

pasuk.text: He took Israel out of Egypt in the month that is best suited for travelers, neither hot nor cold.
The Egyptians.
Their land remained arid and thirsty. I found [this].
When You stepped with your step.
There You showed me that this is Your way forever: for every distress, redemption.
That too quaked because of the Lord God of Israel.
This too You did for us: if we needed rain, You lifted them and poured upon us constantly rains of generosity and blessing.

text.title: Your heritage, which was weary, You established:

pasuk.text: When the heritage of Your land was weary and thirsty for rain, You established it [Your heritage]. I found:
Which is called your heritage, and which is weary; i.e., sometimes it is so.

Heb. (חיתך). Your congregation has dwelt therein, as (II Sam. 23:11): “and the Philistines gathered together their camp (sic) into a troop (לחיה).” Another explanation: The congregation of Israel is known as the animal and the beast of the Holy One, blessed be He.

When they left Egypt, You led them around in the desert for forty years because the Canaanites rose and cut down the trees. During the interim, when they tarried in the desert, they rose and rectified it all.

text.title: The Lord will give out a word; they will announce it to a great multitude:

pasuk.text: Heb. אמר, [like] מאמר, statement. He will yet roar with [His] voice to allow the hosts of the great nations to hear it. Now what is the word? The kings of the hosts of nations will wander, yea they will wander. They will wander and be cast out of the land of Israel, and the congregation of Israel, who is the dweller of the house, will divide their spoils, as it is said (Isa. 23:18): “And her commerce and her hire shall be holy, etc.”

text.title: If you lie between the borders, etc.:

pasuk.text: All this is the word. He says to them, “If you had lain between your borders and had enjoyed pleasures, this My dove, My congregation, whose feathers are covered with silver.” Now what is the silver, and what is the gold?

text.title: (15) When the Almighty spreads out, etc.:

pasuk.text: When the Holy One, blessed be He, explained His Torah, with which the kings are “snowed and whitened” in a land of the Shadow of Death and darkness then its feathers (dove’s feathers) were covered with the desire and yearning for the Torah and [its] Commandments.
Plumes in French.
Its wings, with which it flies.

Heb. בירקרק חרוץ. Dunash the son of Labrat interpreted חרוּץ as gold. Therefore, the Psalmist juxtaposed it to silver, and ירקרק חרוץ is the gold brought from the land of Havilah and from the land of Cush; very good gold, neither yellow nor red. Therefore, it is called ירקרק, as (Lev. 13: 42): “reddish white (לבן אדמדם),” which is neither white nor red. Therefore, it is doubled: אדמדם, ירקרק.
These are the Torah scholars, as it is said (Prov. 8:15): “Kings reign with me.”
Heb. בפרש, an expression of (Deut. 22: 17): “and they will spread out (ופרשו) the garment”; they clarify the matter as a new garment.

text.title: The mountain of God is the mountain of Bashan:

pasuk.text: And where did He spread it out? On Mt. Sinai, which is the mountain of God and is near Bashan on the eastern side of the Jordan.
The special mountain among the mountains.
Heb. גבננים, an expression of mountains, because of their height, as (Ezek. 16:24): “and you built for yourself a platform (גב).” Any high thing is called גַב.

text.title: Why do you lurk, you lofty mountains:

pasuk.text: All this refers back to “The Lord will give out a word.” He says further to them, “Why do you lurk (תרצדון), you lofty mountains?” Why do you lurk, you lofty mountains, to destroy the mountain that God desired for His dwelling, to cause His Shechinah to rest upon it? That is the Temple Mount. Even He will dwell there forever. Its sanctity is a perpetual sanctity. After it was chosen for His dwelling, the Shechinah did not rest elsewhere. I saw in the works of Rabbi Moshe Hadarshan that רצד is “ambush” in Arabic. But Menachem (p. 166) explained תרצדוּן like תרקדוּן, you prance. That expression, too, fits the context.

This too refers back to the “The Lord will give forth a word,” to mention the love of His people. Even when God’s chariot of “twice ten thousand times thousands of” brilliant “sharpened” angels appeared, and the Lord was among them at Sinai with His holiness, there too, you, the leader of His people, Moses the son of Amram ascended on high and took captives.

text.title: and also rebellious ones for Yah God to dwell:

pasuk.text: Also you brought about that the Holy One, blessed be He, rested in the Tabernacle of the Torah, and you took gifts from the celestial beings to give them to the sons of men, also among a people who were rebellious and were rebelling against Him and provoking Him.
This is part of the song mentioned above: “Sing to God.”
He will give us a great salvation, [greater] than any burden, as much as we can carry. (I found:
He always behaves in this manner to us, that for every distress there is a salvation.)

text.title: God is to us the God of salvations:

pasuk.text: God is our Savior, but He has many paths, i.e., kinds of death. תוצאות means, ways to death. However, He does not lay them upon us, but with them He wounds the head of His enemies.
The pate of Esau, who is a “hairy man,” and who always goes with his guilt.

text.title: The Lord said, “I shall restore from Bashan”:

pasuk.text: For so He promised to restore us from the mighty ones of Bashan and from the islands of the sea.

text.title: In order that your foot may wade through blood:

pasuk.text: When He crushes the head of the enemy, our feet will wade through their blood. תִּמְחַץ is an expression of splitting into the blood, as (Jud. 5:26): “she split (ומחצה) and penetrated his temple,” like בָּקְעָה, she split. This is Mishnaic Hebrew: “and the pilgrims were wading (בוקעים) up to their knees in blood.” Another explanation: תִּמְחַץ The name of a vessel with which they draw wine from the pit is called מַחַץ, in Tractate Avodah Zarah (72b).
From the blood of the enemies.
Heb. מנהו, its sustenance will be, as we say (Suc. 39b): “How do we know that מן is an expression of food?” For it is written (Dan. 1:10): “who appointed (מנה) your food, etc.”

text.title: They saw Your ways, O God:

pasuk.text: That is to say, it is fitting that You save these people, for when they saw Your ways in Your sanctity in the sea, singers came first to sing before You the Song of the Sea, and after them came the minstrelsthese are the angels.

text.title: in the midst of maidens playing timbrels:

pasuk.text: With Miriam and her maidens, who took the timbrel in her hand, and they said with their praise…

text.title: In congregations bless God, the Lord, from the womb of Israel:

pasuk.text: Even the fetuses in their mothers’ wombs recited the Song.
the youngest became the ruler over them.

Heb. רֹדֵם, like רֹדָם, with a “kamatz.” From there, he merited to become king because he descended first into the sea, and so did Samuel say to Saul (I Sam. 15:17): “Even if you are small in your own eyes, are you not the head of the tribes of Israel?” which Jonathan paraphrases: The tribe of Benjamin crossed the sea at the head of all the other tribes.

text.title: the princes of Judah pelt them with stones:

pasuk.text: They envy them and throw stones at them, and so do the princes of Zebulun and the princes of Naftali. So, he says to him, “Your God has commanded your strength.” Another explanation: רִגְמָתָם is the equivalent of רִקְמָתָם, their embroidery, their embroidered garments, an expression of purple (ארגמן). In this way Menachem associated it (p. 161).

text.title: 29 show this strength, O God, etc.:

pasuk.text: Now the Psalmist returns to his prayer that he prayed, “Let God rise, and let His enemies scatter.” Show Your strength, O God, and strengthen Yourself, for You have wrought all these for us.

text.title: From Your Temple, which is over Jerusalem, etc.:

pasuk.text: And since the kings will see the glory of Your temple, which is over Jerusalem, they will bring You a gift and a tribute.

text.title: Rebuke the people of the forest:

pasuk.text: This is Ishmael [Esau], who is compared to the “boar from the forest,” which dwells among the reeds (below 80:14).

text.title: the congregation of mighty bulls, among peoples like calves:

pasuk.text: A people that has become fat and thick like mighty bulls among the other nations, which are merely like calves as compared to them.

text.title: submitting himself for pieces of silver:

pasuk.text: They do not submit themselves to any person unless he persuades them with money.
They scattered the tribes, as it is said: (Deut. 33: 3): “Also He loves the peoples,” and they always desire battles. They want to fight with us.

(Then, when You destroy Esau and the King Messiah arises, they will bring you gifts from Egypt and from Cush.Parshandatha) Then, when You scatter the enemy, and the King Messiah arises in the future, they will bring you gifts from Egypt and from Cush. Menachem interpreted חשמנים as the name of a province, the dwellers of Hashmonah (p. 96), but the commentators interpret it as an expression of a gift.
Who showed His greatness and redeemed His people.
Heb. יתן, behold He gives.

text.title: You are feared, O God, from Your Sanctuary:

pasuk.text: Because You destroyed it, You are feared. If He did not show favoritism to His [own] Sanctuary, surely [He will] not [show favoritism] to the wicked of the heathens. The Midrash Aggadah explains: Do not read: מִמִּקְדָּשֶׁי, “from Your Sanctuaries,” but מִמְּקֻדְּשֶׁי, “from Your hallowed ones.” When the Holy One, blessed be He, executes justice upon the righteous, He is feared, elevated, and praised. Similarly, it is said (Lev. 10: 3): “Through those near to me I will be sanctified.” [Also] (Exod. 29: 43), “and it will be sanctified with My honor” [i.e., with My honored ones]. With the death of Aaron’s two sons (Zev. 115b). Our Rabbis, however, expounded on the entire psalm until (verse 20): “Blessed is the Lord; every day” as referring to the giving of the Torah; (verse 10) “generous rain” refers to the giving of the Torah, and (verse 11) “Your congregation dwelt therein,” means that they became engrossed in Torah (Mid. Ps. 68 with variations). But as for me I feel uncertain in explaining the expression ישבוּ as meaning that they became engrossed in Torah. Also, my heart is uneasy at explaining (verse 17) “the mountain that God desired for His dwelling” as referring to Mt. Sinai, because He did not desire it for His dwelling and [did] not [want] to dwell there forever, whereas here it is written: “Even the Lord will dwell there forever.” Likewise (verse 13): “Kings (מלכי) of hosts,” he explained as “angels (מלאכי) of hosts,” which is not the language of Scripture.
Concerning Israel, who are like a rose (שושנה) among the thorns, pricked by the thorns, and he prayed for them.
the nations.
In the mire, the mud of the deep.
That is the flood of the strength of the river, fil in Old French, current.
Heb. נחר, dry, as (Job 30:30): “are burned (חרה) with heat.”

Any drawn-out hope is called “failure of the eyes,” as (Deut. 28:32): “and pine after them all day” . [Similarly] (Lev. 26:16): “that cause the eyes to pine away” ; (Job 11:20), “and the eyes of the wicked will pine away.”

text.title: who are my enemies because of lies:

pasuk.text: They hate me because of a lie, because I do not pursue their lies to adopt their error.
When they gather against me, I bribe them with money that I did not steal from them.

text.title: Do not let those who hope for You be shamed:

pasuk.text: Do not leave me in their hands lest those who hope for You be shamed by what happens to me and say, “Didn’t that happen to one who hopes to the Holy One, blessed be He?”
To Esau.
They saw the love that You showed us when Your house was still existing, and they envied me.

text.title: And I bewailed my soul in fast:

pasuk.text: In my fast.

text.title: and it was a disgrace for me:

pasuk.text: When I weep and fast before You, they mock me.
they made of me for those who imbibe strong drink.

text.title: But, as for me, may my prayer to You, O Lord, be:

pasuk.text: may the time of my prayer be a desirable time.
And let it not close over me.
This strange trouble [shall not close] its mouth to swallow me up.
Heb. תאטר, as (Jud. 3:15): “with a shriveled (אטר) right hand” that he does not use it.
(Come close to me.)
Heb. גאלה, [equivalent to] גְאוֹל אוֹתָה.

Heb. ואנושה, I am ailing and sick, as (Micah 1:9): “For she is mortally ill (אנושה) [from] her wounds,” and as (II Sam. 12:15): “and the child (sic) became mortally ill (ויאנש) ,” of Bathsheba. Now if you ask how this “aleph” serves as a radical and also as a prefix denoting the first person, this is the way of a word beginning with “aleph.” For example, (Mal. 1:2): “and I loved (וָאֹהַב) Jacob” ; (Prov. 8:17), “I will love (אֵהָב) those who love me.” It is equivalent to וָאֶאֶהַב Similarly, (Zeph. 1:2): “I will totally destroy (אָסֹף אָסֵף),” like אֶאֶסֹף.
Heb. לנוד, to shake. That friends should come to me to shake [their heads] over me and to comfort me.
Heb. בברותי, into my food, as (II Sam. 13:6): “Let my sister Tamar come now, etc., that I may eat (ואברה) from her hand.”
When they hope for peace, may their peace be turned into a snare.
this nation, which You smote.
For You were a little angry, and they helped cause harm.

text.title: and about the pain of those whom You wounded they tell:

pasuk.text: their words, to plot: “Let us destroy them while they are in pain.”

text.title: And it will appeal to the Lord:

pasuk.text: My praise to the Lord.

text.title: more than a young bull that is mature:

pasuk.text: That is the bull sacrificed by Adam, which was created at its height. On the day it was called שּׁוֹר, on that very day, he brought it, for a bull on day of its birth is called שּׁוֹר, as it is said (Lev. 22:27): “A bull (שור), a lamb, or a goat, that is born.” On that very day, it resembled a פַּר, which is a three-year old.

Its horns preceded its hooves, because it was created at its height with its horns, and its head emerged from the ground first; the earth thrust them forth in the manner in which all creatures are born, so that its horns preceded its feet.

This is an expression of prayer, as (above 20:8): “but we pray (נזכיר) in the name of the Lord our God.” Similarly, in (I) Chronicles (16:4): “to invoke (להזכיר) and to give thanks to the Lord.” In Midrash Psalms (70:1) I saw: This is comparable to a king who became wroth with his flock, and demolished the sheepcote and took out the flock and the shepherd. Sometime later, he restored the flock and rebuilt the sheepcote, but he did not mention the shepherd. Said the shepherd, “Behold, the flock is restored and the sheepcote is rebuilt, but I am not mentioned.” Similarly, in the preceding chapter it says: “When God saves Zion, etc., and those who love His name dwell therein.” Behold the sheepcote is built and the flock is brought into it, but I am not mentioned. Therefore it says: “Of David, to make mention. O God, to save me.”

text.title: Let them return in the path of their shame:

pasuk.text: Measure for measure, as they did to me.
In that very same path, en ses trazes, on (their) its footsteps.
about me.
An expression of joy, when one sees that his wishes concerning his enemy have been fulfilled.
to aid [me].
into that shelter, to save myself within it from the pursuer.
You saved me many times through Your messengers.
Heb. וחומץ, like וחומס. Similarly (Isa. 1:17): “strengthen the robbed (חמוץ) ” ; the robbed.
You drew me and caused me to pass, as (Num. 11:31): “and drove up (ויגז) quails” ; (below 90: 10), “for it is cut off (גז) swiftly and we fly away.”

text.title: I was as an example for the multitude:

pasuk.text: Many saw my troubles and worried lest an example of my trouble befall them; lest I be an example for them: “just as happened to this one, so will happen to us.” As the matter is said (Ezek. 24:24): “and Ezekiel will be an example to you.”

text.title: at the time of old age:

pasuk.text: If I have aged with sins, meaning, I have sinned exceedingly.

text.title: For my enemies said of me:

pasuk.text: My enemies said of me, and took counsel together, saying, “God has forsaken him.” We shall not be punished because of him since he has already stumbled in sin.

text.title: As for me, I shall constantly hope:

pasuk.text: for Your salvation, and when You save me, I will add to Your praise.

text.title: I do not know their number:

pasuk.text: of the righteousness and the salvations that You have done for me.
to thank and praise for Your mighty deeds.
Until this day, with what passed over me, and until old age and hoary hairwhen I reach sixty and seventydo not forsake me.

text.title: to everyone who comes Your might:

pasuk.text: To everyone who approaches me, I will tell of Your might.
which is up to the heights. The two verses are connected by “I shall tell [of] Your strength to the generation.”
with the music of the harp when I play to You on the harp.

He prayed this prayer on behalf of his son Solomon, for he foresaw with the holy spirit that he [Solomon] was destined to request of the Holy One, blessed be He, “a heart to understand, to hear judgment.”
the wisdom of Your laws, which You commanded in the Torah.
to judge justly.

text.title: to a king, etc., to a king’s son:

pasuk.text: Both refer to Solomon. Another explanation:

text.title: Give Your judgments to a king:

pasuk.text: The chastisements should end with me, and the charity You should bestow upon my son; viz. that there be peace in his days.

peace for the people in his days. Now what is the peace that the mountains bear? When they produce fruit, people will not be jealous, and “each man will call his neighbor [to come] under [his] vine and under [his] fig tree.”
And the hills will bear peace for them through the righteousness that they will perform.

text.title: May they fear You in the presence of the sun:

pasuk.text: All Israel will learn from him to fear You all the days of the sun and moon, generations upon generations.

As long as the moon exists for generations, when they are before it [i.e., during its existence]. There are many such expressions in the language of the Mishnah. Before the Temple and not before the Temple [i.e., when the Temple existed and when it no longer exists].

text.title: May it descend as rain upon cut vegetation:

pasuk.text: May his word descend into the midst of Your people and into their heart as the rain that falls on the cut vegetation, which requires rain after being cut. As the matter is stated (Amos 7:1): “and behold the latter growth after the king’s mowings.”
Heb. זרזיף, an expression of drops. In Aramaic, in Tractate Yoma (87a): “Drops (זרזיפי) of water hit him.”

text.title: May the righteous flourish in his days:

pasuk.text: Israel.

will flourish in his days, and this peace will last forever. Now all this prayer was fulfilled except this thing, because Solomon sinned. Therefore his kingdom did not endure, for the kingship was given to David on this condition (I Kings 2:4): “If your children take heed to their way,” but Israel sinned in his days. As it is said (ibid. 4:20): “Judah and Israel [were] many, as the sand, etc.” And Israel flourished in his days, as it is said… And there was much peace, as it is said (ibid. 5:5): “And Judah and Israel dwelt safely, every man under his vine and under his fig tree, etc., all the days of Solomon.”

text.title: And may he reign from sea to sea:

pasuk.text: All of the land of Israel is from the Sea of Reeds to the Sea of the Philistines [the Mediterranean].

text.title: and from the river to the ends of the land:

pasuk.text: (I Kings 5:4): “For he had dominion over all [the inhabitants of] this side of the river, etc.”
Heb. ציים, companies of nobles, as (Num. 24:24): “and nobles (וצים) from the Kittites,” which the Targum renders: And companies will come around from the Romans.

text.title: May the kings of Tarshish and the isles return tribute:

pasuk.text: (I Kings 10:23): “For the king had at sea, ships of Tarshish with Aliram’s ships; once every three years the ships of Tarshish would come, etc.”
The queen of Sheba.
Heb. אֶשְׁכָּר, a gift.
(I Kings 10:24f.): “And all the [inhabitants of] the earth sought Solomon’s presence etc. And each one would bring his gift.”

Heb. מתוך ומחמס, from blows and from robbery. I found [the following]: מִתּוֹ is an expression of “his innermost midst (תּוֹ) ,” men of plots, who plot iniquity, as (Prov. 29:13): “a man of deep thoughts (תככים).”
through the justice and righteousness that he will perform for them.
Solomon.
The Holy One, blessed be He.
And so it was (I Kings 3:13): “both riches and honor, so that there shall not be any among the kings like you.”

text.title: and may He pray for him constantly, etc.:

pasuk.text: The prayer and the blessing are identical. When the Holy One, blessed be He, says to a man, “You shall be blessed,” it is an expression of prayer.

text.title: May there be an abundance of grain:

pasuk.text: Heb. פסת, an expression of spreading (פסיון), increase and abundance. Our Sages, however, explained this as an expression of loaves of white bread during the messianic era (Keth. 111b, Shab. 30b), and the entire psalm as referring to the messianic era. Another explanation: פִּסַת is an expression of good will, like פִּיוּס, placating; the people are appeased and accepted by the Holy One, blessed be He, when He gives plenty in the world.

text.title: may its fruit rustle like Lebanon:

pasuk.text: May the wheat kernels be as thick as the kidneys of a large ox, as happened in the days of Shimon ben Shatach.
Israel.
From the midst of Jerusalem like the grass of the earth.
[May] Solomon’s name be remembered forever for his riches and his wisdom.

text.title: before the sun, his name will be magnified:

pasuk.text: All the days of the sun, his name will be magnified.

Heb. ינון, an expression of kingdom and dominion, as (Prov. 29:21): “he will ultimately be a ruler (מנון) ; (Gen. 21:23),” and to my son (ולניני) , “ who rules over my property after me; (below 74:8),” They said in their heart, their rulers (נינם) together" ; their kings together.
A person will say to his son, “May you be wise and rich like Solomon.”

text.title: Blessed is the Lord, etc., Who performs wonders alone:

pasuk.text: When the fire descended from the heavens through Solomon, his son.

text.title: The prayers of David… are completed:

pasuk.text: Heb. כלו. Our sages expounded on כָּלוּ to mean כָּל אֵלוּ, all these are the prayers of David son of Jesse, to include the entire Book on David’s nameeven what the sons of Korah and the ten elders said because he was known as (II Sam. 23:1) “the sweet singer of Israel.” כָּלוּ may also be interpreted as “were completed.” The construction of כָּלוּ is like (Job 24:24): “They are taken away (רֹמוּ) in a second” ; (Jer. 2:12), “O heavens, be astonished (שֹׁמוּ).” If this is so, this psalm was not written in its place, and there is no chronological order in the Book. The [subject] matter indicates that he said this in his old age, when he enthroned Solomon.

text.title: A song of Asaph. Truly God is good to Israel, etc.:

pasuk.text: Since the topic of this psalm deals with the troubles that befall Israel, he commences it in this manner.
