And this is the meaning: Although I cry out and am dismayed at Israel’s troubles, I knew that the Holy One, blessed be He, is good to them, and that He brings evil upon them for their own good, in order to give them merit in the life of the world to come.
before I laid this to my heart.

text.title: my feet had almost turned away:

pasuk.text: and my steps swept away to turn away from following the Omnipresent.
Those who pervert their ways, whose tranquility I would see.
Heb. בהוללים, mixed, as (Isa. 1:22): “your wine is diluted (מהול) with water.”

text.title: For there are no fetters to their death:

pasuk.text: Heb. חרצבות, an expression of tying, as (Isa. 58:6): “to undo the fetters (חרצבות) of wickedness,” meaning the locks of the fetters with which they bind the poor. Here, too, there are no pains to their death. Those who die among them die healthy, [strong as] a palace, without pains. But our Rabbis explained חַרְצֻבּוֹת as an abbreviation, meaning that they are not (שאין) frightened (חרדין) or saddened (עצבין) by the day of death (Shab. 31b). Another explanation: that the Holy One, blessed be He, does not delay (מאחר) their desire (צביונם).

text.title: Therefore, they wear pride as a necklace:

pasuk.text: Because of this, pride adorns them as a necklace, insofar as it ascends upon his neck.

text.title: the robbery that they commit envelopes their hips:

pasuk.text: The robbery they commit makes them fat, enveloping their buttocks and hips with thickness of fat and flesh.

text.title: Because of their fat, their eyes bulge:

pasuk.text: Their eyes bulge because of the abundant fat, for in an emaciated person, the eyes are sunken.

text.title: they surpassed the imaginings of their heart:

pasuk.text: More than what their heart hopes for and awaits, came to them. In the attainment of their hand, they surpassed the desire of their heart.
their neighbors.
To oppress the needy.

text.title: they speak about the Most High:

pasuk.text: e.g. Pharaoh, Sennacherib, and Nebuchadnezzar. [Pharaoh said] (Exod. 5:2): “Who is the Lord that I should obey Him?” [Sennacherib said] (Isa. 36:20), “Who are they among all the gods of the lands…?” [Nebuchadnezzar said] (Isa. 14:14), “I will ascend above the heights of the clouds.” That is the meaning of: “They have set their mouth against Heaven.”

text.title: Therefore, His people will return here:

pasuk.text: Since His people sees that the way of the wicked prospers, they will return on the way of the wicked, to adopt their ways.
Heb. הלם, as (Jud. 18:3): “Who brought you here (הלום) ?” [Equivalent to] פֹּה.

text.title: and the waters of the full are drain water to them:

pasuk.text: And the waters of the full streamthey are words of Torahare considered by them as water that drains out, and they despise them.

text.title: And they say, “How does God know”:

pasuk.text: How can we say that there is knowledge in the Holy One, blessed be He, and that His Torah is true?
They [are wicked] and transgress His Torah; yet they are tranquil in the world and increase power and wealth.

text.title: they are tranquil in the world:

pasuk.text: An expression of tranquility.

Heb. השגו, have increased. Menachem (p. 72) explains: יָשוּב עַמו ֹהֲלוֹם, the wicked will return to crush (להלם) the people of the Holy One, blessed be He. The first interpretation I learned from the words of Rabbi Meir the son of Isaac, the cantor, may the memory of the righteous be for a blessing.

text.title: But for nought I cleansed my heart:

pasuk.text: All this refers back to: “And they say, ‘How does God know?’ ” They also say, “But for nothing and in vain we keep the commandments of the Holy One, blessed be He, for behold, we are plagued all the days.”
appears all day; constantly, from morning to morning, new troubles are renewed.

text.title: If I said, “I shall tell it as it is”:

pasuk.text: Said Asaph, “If I said in my heart to tell everything as it is, all that His people say about this.”

text.title: behold I have made the generation of Your children into traitors:

pasuk.text: That is to say that I would make them into traitors and wicked men.
in my heart.
what the manner of the Holy One, blessed be He, is.

text.title: So it is iniquity in my eyes:

pasuk.text: This manner appeared to me as iniquity and not justice.

I came to the sanctuaries of God, which are in Jerusalem, and saw what happened to Sennacherib. Then I understood the end of the wicked, that it is to destruction. Then I said, “All the good that comes to them is only slippery places; for the Holy One, blessed be He, makes their way slippery, that it should be easy and smooth, so that they should not put their heart to return to Him, and they should perish.”

text.title: Only in slippery places do You set them:

pasuk.text: All the goodness that comes to them, for ultimately, You cast them down to ruin.
By demons.
As a sleep without end (without awakening), which is an eternal sleep, so did they have (Isa. 37:36): “And an angel of the Lord went forth and slew… of the camp of Assyria.”

text.title: O Lord, in the city You will despise their form:

pasuk.text: In Jerusalem, with which they dealt evilly, there the form of their image was despised, and they were all burnt.

text.title: For my heart was in ferment:

pasuk.text: Before I saw this downfall with the holy spirit, my heart was in ferment because the way of the wicked prospered, and my mind was on edge (אשתונן), an expression of a sharpened sword (שנון). When it is reflexive, the “tav” is placed in the middle of the radical, as is the case of every word whose radical commences with “shin.”
was brutish, and I did not know what this manner was, and I was as a beast with You.
Although I saw all this constantly, I was with You, and I did not move from fear of You.
to strengthen me in Your fear when my feet are about to turn from Your way, as it is stated above (verse 2): “my feet had almost turned away.”
Heb. תנחני, [like] נחיתני, You led me.

text.title: and after[wards], You took me [for] glory:

pasuk.text: If the cantillation sign were on כָּבוֹד, its interpretation would be: After You bestowed upon Sennacherib all the glory You had allotted to him, You will take me to You. You have performed wondrous miracles for Israel and have destroyed Sennacherib. Now that the cantillation sign is on ואחר, this is its interpretation: (and afterwards,) You took me to glory; You drew me to You for glory and beauty.

text.title: For whom do I have in heaven:

pasuk.text: [Was there] any angel that I chose for me as a god? I chose only You.
My flesh and my heart yearn for You.
Heb. כלה, an expression of desire, as (119:81): “My soul yearned (כלתה) for Your salvation.”
Who separates himself from You.
Your message; the holy spirit that comes into my heart to say it.
lit. do Your nostrils smoke. Whenever one is angry, the nostrils emit smoke.

text.title: which You acquired from time immemorial:

pasuk.text: Before the creation of the world, as it is said (below 90: 1,2): “You were a dwelling place for us, etc., before mountains were formed.”
Heb. זה שכנתבו, this upon which You dwelt. This is an improvement of the language, as (Isa. 42:24): “against whom (זו) we sinned.” It is like אשר שכנתבו, on which You dwelt.

text.title: Raise Your blows to inflict eternal ruin:

pasuk.text: Raise Your blows and Your terrors that Your enemies will experience as eternal ruin for every evil thing that the enemy did in the Temple. In this manner, Menachem (p. 144) associates it with (Gen. 41:8): “that his spirit was troubled (ותפעם).”
Heb. למשאות, an expression of destruction, as (Isa. 24: 12): “through desolation (שאיה) ” ; (Isa. 6:11), “and the ground lies waste (למשאות) and desolate.”
That is the Temple about which it is said (Exod. 25:22): וְנוֹעַדְתִּי לְ שָׁם, “There I will meet with you at appointed times.”

text.title: they made their signs for signs:

pasuk.text: When they became powerful enough to destroy it, then they themselves accepted that the signs of their divination were true signs. Now what were their divinations?“He shook the arrows, he consulted the terafim.”

text.title: May he be known as though bringing on high; the hatchets were in the thicket of the trees:

pasuk.text: The enemy knows that when he strikes the gates of the entrances of the Sanctuary, it was as though he was bringing his blows on high, even into the sky. Now how did he know it? For he would see that the trees would entangle, grasp, and swallow up the hatchets, as our Rabbis said (Sanh. 96b): One gate of Jerusalem swallowed them all up.

text.title: the hatchets were in the thicket of the trees:

pasuk.text: Heb. בסבך-עץ, an expression of (Gen. 22:13): “caught in the thicket (בסבך).” The tree entangles them, and they become entangled in it.
although he saw that this troubled the Holy One, blessed be He, he did not refrain from striking all its entrances and all its gates together.

They are tools of destruction used by carpenters (Jer. 46:22): “and will come against her with axes (ובקרדמות).” Jonathan renders: בּכשיליא. כֵּילַפּוֹת is Arabic. This is how Dunash (p. 34) explained it, and it is one of the carpenters’ tools.
The enemies [strike].

text.title: They said in their heart, their rulers together:

pasuk.text: Heb. נינם, their rulers, and similarly (above 72:17): “his name will be magnified (ינון) ; (Prov. 29:21),” he will ultimately be a ruler (מנון)." All their rulers devise one plot, the first as the last: namely, to get at the protector of Israel first and afterwards they would get at them [Israel], You should know this by the fact that they burned all the meeting places of God in the land, all His meeting houses. The Philistines destroyed Shiloh; Nebuchadnezzar destroyed the First Temple; Titus destroyed the Second Temple.
which You promised us through Your prophetswe have not seen them in the many days that we have been in exile. Asaph prophesied concerning the days of the (last) exile.
How long we will be in this trouble.

text.title: Draw it out from within Your bosom:

pasuk.text: Cast it and draw it out from within Your bosom and wage battle with Your enemies. כַּלֵה is an expression of driving out, as (Exod. 11:1): “he will drive you out completely (כלה).”

text.title: But God is my King from time immemorial:

pasuk.text: Behold, You were our salvation from time immemorial.

text.title: the beads of the sea monsters:

pasuk.text: They are the Egyptians, who are called sea monsters, as it is said (Ezek. 29: 3): “the great sea monster, etc.”
Pharaoh is called [by] this [name], as it is said (Isa. 27:1): “the Lord will visit with His hard… sword on leviathan, etc.”

text.title: You give it as food to the people in companies:

pasuk.text: You gave his money to the people of Israel to consume.
Heb. לציים. To the companies and hosts that You took out. ציים are companies, as (Num. 24:24): “And companies from the Kittites,” which is translated as וסיען, and companies.
for Israel fountains from the rock.
the Jordan, which is a mighty river.
The redemption of Israel.
And they were with You in the darkness of the night.

text.title: You established the luminary and the sun:

pasuk.text: You established the light of the Torah for them.
for them all the boundaries of their land with all good.
This is similar to (Jer. 5:24): “the weeks of the laws of harvest He keeps for us.” You did not alter for us the order of the years.
And since all our salvation is through You, remember how the enemy reviled You by destroying us.

text.title: Do not deliver to the company:

pasuk.text: To the companies of the nations, as (II Sam. 23:11): “Now the Philistines were gathered together into a troop (לחיה).”

Heb. תורך, Your turtledove. And Jonathan rendered this as (sic) an expression of turtledoves and young pigeons. This turtledoveas soon as the male recognizes its mate, it does not mate with another. So have Israel not exchanged You for another god, although You have distanced Yourself from them and they were like a widow.

text.title: the soul of Your poor ones:

pasuk.text: Heb. חיתענייך, the soul of Your poor ones.
which You formed with our forefathers.
Heb. נאותחמס, a dwelling of violence, an expression of a dwelling place.

text.title: Let not the poor turn back in disgrace:

pasuk.text: Let the poor not turn back from before You disgraced in his prayer.
Your blasphemies, as (verse 18): “Remember how the enemy reviled.”
[lit. do not destroy] Israel.

text.title: We have thanked You, O God:

pasuk.text: for the good; we have thanked also for the evil.
Your name is always near in our mouth.
Our generations [have] constantly [told] Your wonders.

text.title: When I take a festive day:

pasuk.text: When we have a festival, we do not engage in obscenity and levity, as [do] all the nations.
We take it to our heart to praise You and laud You according to the incident of that day.

text.title: When the earth and all its inhabitants were melting away, etc.:

pasuk.text: On the day of the giving of the Torah, when the earth and all its inhabitants were melting away because of the condition You made with the Creation: that if Israel did not accept the Torah, you would return it [the earth] to void and chaos.
Your people, Israel.
when I said, “We will do and we will hear.”
To the wicked, who confuse Israel.

text.title: For it is not from the east:

pasuk.text: of the sun or from its setting, and not from the deserts where you embark on a journey by caravan to increase [your] property; there is no power in any of these to raise [your] horn.
[you] for all the evil that you have done.

text.title: He humbles this one and elevated that one:

pasuk.text: The elevated one He lowers, and the lowly He elevates.
of weakness is in His hand.
Heb. חמר, strong. Vinos, or vinose, in Old French.
The cup is full of a mixture, to mix and give all the nations to drink.

text.title: and He pours out of this:

pasuk.text: Out of this cup, He will pour and cause to gush forth their drinks, an expression of (Micah 1:4): “as water poured (מגרים) down a steep place.”
From then on, [I will recite] His vengeance and His might.

text.title: And all the horns of the wicked:

pasuk.text: of Esau.

As the matter that is stated (Ezek. 29:14): “And I shall lay My vengeance against Edom by the hand of My people, Israel.” They will cut off the horn of Esau (the enemy), and then the horns of the Righteous One of the worldIsrael, who are the praise of the Holy One, blessed be Hewill be upraised.

text.title: There He broke the arrows of the bow:

pasuk.text: of Sennacherib and his hosts.

Heb. רשפי. רִשְׁפֵי is not an expression of sparks of fire, because sparks of fire are not appropriate to a bow. Moreover, this word has no “dagesh,” yet רִשְׁפֵּי does have a “dagesh.” Rather, רִשְׁפֵי is an expression of (Deut. 32:24): “fought by demons (רשף),” which is translated as עוֹף, flying creatures, as (Job 5:7): “but flying creatures fly (רשף) upward.” Similarly (below 78:48): “and their cattle to the flying creatures (לרשפים). to the birds. Similarly, בְּנֵי רֶשֶׁף are flying creatures, demons, who fly upward. This one too is an expression of arrows, which fly, as the matter that is stated (below 91: 5): ” from an arrow that flies by day." There He broke the arrows (רִשְׁפֵי) of the bow, the arrows that the bow lets fly, and this entire psalm speaks of the downfall of Sennacherib, for we find no enemy falling in Jerusalem but he.

Heb. נאור, an expression of (Lam. 2:7): “He destroyed His Sanctuary” ; (below 89:40), “You abolished the covenant of Your servant.” You destroy Your enemies and those who rise up against You and sweep them from the world. Because of His deeds, He is called נאור, destructive, like חנוּן, gracious; רחום, merciful; קנוא jealous, because He grants, because He pities, because He acts with zeal.

text.title: mightier than the mountains of prey:

pasuk.text: Stronger than the predatory giants, who are as tall as mountains, but against You, their might is not known.

Heb. אשתוללו, like השתוללוּ. As (II Chron. 20:35): “And afterwards, Jehoshaphat the king of Judah joined (אתחבר) Ahaziah the king of Israel,” like התחבר. [The word] אשתוללוּ is derived from (Job 12:17): “He leads counselors away with madness (שולל).” It is an expression of error and tranquility, as madmen err, and the “tav” falls into the middle of the word in the reflexive, as in every word beginning with “shin.”
They Heb. נמו. They fell into a deep sleep, an expression of תנוּמה slumber.
their hands and their strength when You came to punish them.
Heb. ורכב וסוס. The “vav” of ורכב is superfluous, as (Gen. 36:24): “These are the sons of Ziv’on: Ayyah (ואיה) and Anah.” The “vav” of ואיה is superfluous.
From the time You became angry.

text.title: From heaven, You let judgment be heard:

pasuk.text: When Isaiah prophesied concerning the retribution of Sennacherib and it was fulfilled in him, then Eretz Israel, which feared him and his hosts, became calm.
to execute judgment upon His enemies, to save Hezekiah and his company.

text.title: For man’s anger will thank you:

pasuk.text: The anger of the wicked results in the creatures thanking the Holy One, blessed be He. When they show their anger and the Holy One, blessed be He, punishes them, everyone praises Him when they see that their anger is of no avail. As we find (Dan. 3:28) concerning Nebuchadnezzar, when he cast Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah into the fiery furnace, what is said there?“Blessed be the God of Shadrach, etc.” And thereby…

text.title: it will prevent the residue of wrath:

pasuk.text: Heb. תחגר. It will prevent and stop; the remaining wicked men are prevented and restrained from showing their pride and their wrath. תחגר is an expression of restraint in the language of the Mishnah (Chul. 18a): “The nick in a knife must be deep enough to catch (תחגר) the nail to disqualify it from slaughtering].” I heard in the name of Rabbi Eleazar the Gaon, the son of Rabbi Isaac, who brought this verse as testimony to that Mishnah (sic). It is also possible to interpret this according to its usual meaning of an expression of girding, and can be explained as follows: It is fitting for You to gird Yourself with wrath and to enwrap Yourself with zeal, for strength and ability are Yours; the expression of “residue” is that since man’s wrath is of no account, the girding of all wrath is reserved for You.
your vows.
who hear of this salvation, and so they did, as it is stated (Isa. 19:18): “there will be five cities in the land of Egypt speaking the language of Canaan and swearing to the Lord of Hosts.”

text.title: will bring a gift to Him Who is to be feared:

pasuk.text: Why? Because at the time of His desire…

text.title: He will cut down the spirit:

pasuk.text: the spirit of haughtiness of the princes and lessen their arrogance. יבצֹר means “He will lessen,” as (Gen. 11:6): “will it not be withheld (יבצר) from them?”
Concerning the decrees and the laws that pass over Israel.
Heb. ידי, lit. my hand; my wound.
In this exile, which is like night, it oozes pus and gall.
Its oozing does not abate.
The kindness that He used to do for me in the days of my love.
about those acts of kindness and the favors.
Pasmer in Old French, to faint or swoon.

text.title: You held fast the awakenings of my eyes:

pasuk.text: Heb. שמרות, an expression of the watch (אשמרת) of the night, for [when] a person awakens from his sleep his mind is settled and his heart returns to him, but I am not like that. In this night of exile, my eyes are always stuck together, like a man sleeping from a clogged heart, and in the troubles that I see, my spirit throbs and I have no speech within me.

text.title: I think of the days of yore:

pasuk.text: to remember the kind acts that You performed for our forefathers.

text.title: I recall my music at night:

pasuk.text: In the days of this exile, which is like night, I remember my melodies that I used to play in days of yore in the Temple.
I think, and my spirit searches [to ascertain] what is the manner of the Holy One, blessed be He, and I wonder: will He forsake [me] forever?
Perhaps His kind acts have ended?
a perpetual decree that He will never again repent of His anger?
Heb. חנות, to be gracious, like עשוֹת, to do; ראוֹת, to see. Another explanation: חנות means gracious acts.

text.title: Has He, in anger, shut off His mercy forever:

pasuk.text: Heb. קפץ, an expression of (Deut. 15:7): “and do not close (תקפץ) your hand,” i.e., has He shut off the mercy forever because of the anger?

text.title: And I said, “This is to terrify me”:

pasuk.text: My thoughts tell me, “This is only to terrify me and frighten me into returning to Him.”
Heb. חלותי, like לחלוֹתי, to terrify me, an expression of sickness and terror.

text.title: the change of the right hand of the Most High:

pasuk.text: How the right hand of the Most High changed. It was mighty with strength and now He has withdrawn His right hand.

text.title: And I meditate over all Your works:

pasuk.text: that You have already done for us.
Your manner is to sanctify Your name in the world, to execute justice upon the wicked.
[The] mighty [waters perceived You] when You were revealed by the sea.
The skies poured forth a stream of thick waters.
Heb. חצציך, like חִצֶי.
Heb. בגלגל, like כגלגל. The sound of Your thunder [rolled] like a wheel on the sea to confuse the camp of the Egyptians.

text.title: and Your steps were not known:

pasuk.text: The steps are not recognizable on the water. [The word] ועקבותי means trazes in Old French, footprints.
They are the words of Torah.

text.title: We shall not hide from their sons:

pasuk.text: We, too, shall not hide [these words] from our fathers’ sons by not letting them know what they told us.
Heb. כסלם, their hope, and so (Job 31: 24): “If I made gold my hope (כסלי).”
who were in Egypt and in the desert.

who left Egypt forcefully before the end [of the exile] and trusted in their might and in their arrows. Ultimately, they retreated and fled on the day of battle, as is delineated (I Chron. 7:21): “and the men of Gath, who were born in the land, slew them.”
Heb. רומי, who cast and shoot, as (Exod. 15:1): “cast (רמה) into the sea.”

text.title: Before their forefathers He wrought wonders:

pasuk.text: (NeverthelessShem Ephraim) Afterwards, when the end arrived, they too “continued to sin against Him,” as he further concludes. (Another explanationShem Ephraim)
Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob came beside the sea, and the Holy One, blessed be He, showed them how He was redeeming their children.
Heb. נד, a tall heap, as Onkelos renders (Exod. 15: 8): “the flowing water stood up like a נֵד,” stood up like a wall.
(Exod. 17:6): “and you shall strike the rock.”

text.title: and He gave them to drink as [from] great deeps:

pasuk.text: in the great deeps. Even as they went through the midst of the sea, whose waters are salty, He sweetened fountains for them in the midst of the sea.

text.title: and brought down water like rivers:

pasuk.text: [Water] that was flowing from the well. The princes would make a line with their staffs and the water would be drawn after them to the encampment of each tribe, as the matter that is stated (Num. 21:18): “by the order of the lawgiver, with their staffs,” as is explained in tractate Makkoth.
Heb. למרות, to provoke, as (Deut. 9: 7): “you have been provoking (ממרים).”
Heb. שְׁאֵר, flesh.
Heb. נשקה, as (Ezek. 39: 9): “and make fires and heat up (והשיקו) ,” which is an expression of heating and burning. As it is written (Num. 11:1): “and God’s fire broke out against them.”
Bread of the angels. Another explanation: אַבִּירִים means אֵבָרִים, limbs, for it was absorbed into the limbs, and they did not have to excrete.

text.title: He caused the east wind to set forth:

pasuk.text: (Num. 11:31): “And a wind set forth from the Lord, and it made quails fly.”

text.title: They were not estranged from their desire:

pasuk.text: They did not become estranged from their desire, for they achieved all their desire. Another explanation: לא זרוּ מתאותם They were not distanced from their desire until the retribution came upon them.“While their food was still in their mouth, the wrath of the Lord (sic), etc.”
The chosen of them and the men of the assembly, הָאסַפסוּף (Num. 11:4). They are the elders, as it is said (Num. 11:16): “Assemble (אספו) to Me, etc.”
Yet all this was not in truth, but with guile in their mouth and by lying with their tongue.
was not sincere as with their mouth.
to them and constantly expiates their iniquity, and He did not destroy them.

Many times He withdraws His wrath from them, and even if He punishes them, He does not arouse all His anger but little by little, because He remembers that they are flesh and that the evil inclination is hidden in their heart. That is a spirit that goes away when they die, and that spirit does not return to them in the world to come. When they are resurrected, the evil inclination will have no control over them.“A spirit that goes away and does not return” cannot be explained to mean their spirit of life, because if you say so, you have denied the resurrection of the dead. In this manner, it is explained in Aggadath Tehillim (Mid Ps. 78:8).
[How many] times.
always in the desert.

Heb. התוו, an expression of a sign, as (Ezek. 9:4): “and set a mark (והתוית תו).” “A mark” is an expression of a wonder and a trial. They asked him for a sign and a mark (Exod. 17:7): “Is the Lord in our midst or not?”
They would pull off their testicles.

Heb. בחנמל, the name of the locust. According to the Midrash (Mid. Ps. 78:13) [it is composed of the following words]: בָּא חָן מָל, it comes, encamps, and cuts. It cut off the greens of the tree and the grass and ate it.

text.title: He gave over their animals to hail:

pasuk.text: When the hail began to fall, the Egyptian drove his sheep (his animal) into the house, and the hail came before him like a wall. The Egyptian slaughtered it [the animal] and put it on his shoulder, to take it to his house to eat it, but the birds came and took it from him. That is [the meaning of] “and their cattle to the birds (לרשפים) ,” as (Job. 5:7): “but flying creatures (בני רשף) fly upward.” This is its midrashic interpretation (Mid. Ps. 78:14), but according to its simple meaning, רשפים are bolts of fire, as it is written (Exod. 9:24): “and fire flaming within the hail.”

text.title: He leveled a path for His anger:

pasuk.text: Although the plagues were dispatched in anger, they performed only their orders; what they were commanded to kill, they killed, but nothing else. They went in their paths. In other commentaries I found as follows:

text.title: He leveled a path for His anger:

pasuk.text: When He smote every firstborn in Egypt, He showed the way for [the angel] who was destroying with anger to enter the houses of the Egyptians, but not the houses of the children of Israel.
Heb. וחיתם, their body.

text.title: He drove out… from before them:

pasuk.text: the seven nations.
of the nations.
during the days of the judges.
which does not shoot the arrow to the place the archer wishes.

text.title: He delivered His might into captivity:

pasuk.text: He delivered the Ark and the tablets into the hands of the Philistines.
[The fire of] His wrath.

Heb. לא הוללו. They were not married by being brought into a litter [under] a canopy because the youths died in battle. הוּלָלוּ is an expression of nuptials (הִלוּלָא) in Aramaic. Our Sages, however, explained it in reference to Nadab and Abihu (Mid. Ps. 78:18), but I feel uncertain about explaining it that way because he already commenced with the Tabernacle of Shiloh.

text.title: His priests fell by the sword:

pasuk.text: Hophni and Phinehas.

text.title: but his widows did not weep:

pasuk.text: Even his widow was not allowed to bewail him, for she too died on the day of the tidings, as it is said (I Sam. 4:19): “And she knelt and gave birth, for her pains had suddenly come upon her.”
Heb. מתרונן, awaking and strengthening himself with speech to awaken from his wine. מתרונן is an expression of רנה, shouting.

text.title: And He smote His adversaries from the rear:

pasuk.text: Plagues of the rear with hemorrhoids, which is a disgrace of perpetual ridicule for them.

text.title: He rejected the tent of Joseph:

pasuk.text: That is Shiloh, which is in Joseph’s territory.

text.title: And He built His Sanctuary like the high heavens, etc.:

pasuk.text: Like the heavens and the earth, about which two hands are mentioned, as it is stated (Isa. 48: 13): “Even My hand laid the foundation of the earth, and My right hand measured the heavens with handbreadths.” Also the Temple was with two hands, as it is said (Exod. 15:17): “Your hands established.” (Cf. Mechilta, Shirah 10, Keth. 5a, Rashi to Exod. 15: 17.) Another explanation:

text.title: And He built His Sanctuary like the high heavens, like the earth He established it:

pasuk.text: Just as heaven and earth have no substitute, neither does the Temple have a substitute in which to let the Shechinah rest.

text.title: and took him from the sheepcotes:

pasuk.text: Heb. ממכלאתצאן, from the stalls of the sheep, as (Hab. 3:16): “The flock will be cut off from the fold (ממכלה).”

text.title: From behind the nursing ewes He brought him:

pasuk.text: For he would shepherd the nursing ewes for his father, because he was merciful and would bring the kids first and feed them the upper tips of the grasses, which are tender. Then after them he would bring out the he-goats, who would eat the middle of the grasses, and afterwards, he would bring out the older ones, who would eat the roots. Said the Holy One, blessed be He, “This one is fit to shepherd My people.”

Now what is this song? Is it not a lamentation? But because it says (Lam. 4:11): “The Lord has spent His fury.” With what has He spent it? “He has kindled a fire in Zion.” This is a song and an occasion for singing, for He poured out His fury on the wood and stones and did not utterly destroy His children.

text.title: the flesh of Your pious ones:

pasuk.text: Now were they not wicked? But since they received their punishment, they are accounted as pious men. Similarly, Scripture states (Deut. 25:3): “your brother would be degraded before your eyes.” As soon as he is lashed, he is your brother. It is explained in this manner in the Aggadah (Mid. Ps. 79: 4).
Heb. וקלס, an expression of speech, to speak of them as for a byword.
Heb. עד מה [lit. until what.] Until when?
Your wrath, that You are jealous to wreak vengeance, an expression of (Exod. 20:5): “a jealous (קנא) God,” emportement or enprenemant in Old French, zealous anger.
Heb. הותר, release the prisoners from their prison, as (below 105:20): “A king sent and released him (ויתירהו) ” ; (146: 7), “sets loose (מתיר) the bound.”

text.title: the children of the mother who died:

pasuk.text: The children of her who was killed because of You; enmorinede in Old French, doomed to die. There is an example in the Sages’ language: “It is better that Jews eat the flesh of slaughtered dying beasts rather than eat the flesh of the carcasses of dying animals.” That means the flesh of a dying animal that was slaughtered, in tractate Kiddushin (21b).
To Israel.

text.title: a testimony, of Asaph, a song:

pasuk.text: A song of testimony in which he alluded to the three exiles and prayed about them. For it is mentioned in this psalm three times: “Return us, cause Your countenance to shine, and we shall be saved,” and in it, he alluded to the troubles that were destined to befall them in the days of the house of Jehu, from the kings of Aram. For it is stated (II Kings 13:7): “for the king of Aram had destroyed them and made them like dust to trample.”
Their leader and supporter.
All Israel are called by the name Joseph because he sustained and supported them in time of famine.

text.title: He Who dwells between the cherubim:

pasuk.text: As it is said (Exod. 25: 22): “There I shall meet with you at appointed times, etc.”
Demonstrate Your might.

when they need Your salvation. Although they are wicked and undeserving, arouse Your might for them. But why? Because it is for You to save us. It is fitting for You and it is incumbent upon You to save, whether guilty or innocent, as it was said to Moses in Egypt (Exod. 3:7): “I have seen the affliction of My people.” Why is the word for seeing repeated? I see that they are destined to provoke Me. Nevertheless, I have seen their affliction, because of the oath that I swore to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
in the war with Aram, when he besieged Samaria and sent emissaries to Ahab (I Kings 20:3): “Your silver and gold are mine; your beautiful wives and children are mine.”

in the days of Jehoash the son of Jehoahaz, as it is said (II Kings 13:4, 7): “for He saw Israel’s oppression, etc., for the king of Aram had destroyed them and made them like dust to trample.” And he beat him in war three times, as it is said (II Kings 13:25): “Joash overcame him three times and recovered the cities of Israel.”
in the time of Ahasuerus, when Mordechai and Esther were in danger, and all Israel depended on them.

text.title: and it is for You to save us:

pasuk.text: Heb. ולכה. This is not an expression of going, but is like לְ, and so it is in the Masorah of (Gen. 27:37): “and for you (ולכה) then,” of Jacob; (II Sam. 18:22) “since for you (ולכה) there is no [reward] given for news” ; (Isa. 3:6), “You have (לכה) a garment; be an officer to us, etc.”
from the Babylonian exile, where Mordechai was.

text.title: how long have You been wroth:

pasuk.text: [This refers to] the troubles brought about by the Greek kings, who harmed Israel considerably.

text.title: You have fed them bread of tears:

pasuk.text: in Egypt.

text.title: and You have given them to drink tears in large measure:

pasuk.text: Heb. שליש. In Babylon, where they were for seventy years, a third (שליש) of the two hundred and ten of Egypt. I learned this from the work of Rabbi Moshe Hadarshan. It may also be interpreted as regards the kingdom of Greece, which represents the third trouble. If you ask, is that [not] the fourth, because Persia and Media came before, all the seventy years of the Babylonian exile are only one exile. Menachem (p. 175) interprets שליש as the name of a drinking vessel. So he explained (Isa. 40:12): “and He measured with a ‘shalish’ the dust of the earth.” Our Sages explained it (Mid. Ps. 80:4) as referring to the three tears that Esau shed, concerning whom it is said (Gen. 27:34): “and he cried a cry.” That is one. “A great one.” That is two. “And a bitter one.” That is three. Because of them, he merited to live by his sword, as it is said (Gen. 27: 40): “and it will come to pass when you complain, etc.”

text.title: You have made us the target of strife:

pasuk.text: You have made us the target of strife to all our neighbors, for the Greeks have quarreled with us.

text.title: return us, etc., and we shall be saved:

pasuk.text: from the Greeks.

text.title: You uprooted a vine from Egypt:

pasuk.text: He went back and alluded to the exile of the Romans. The vine of Israel, which You uprooted from Egypt. You uprooted them from there, as (Job 19:10): “He has uprooted (ויסע) my hope like a tree.” Afterwards, You drove out the seven nations and planted Israel in their land.
those dwelling there.

text.title: and its branches were great cedars:

pasuk.text: Heb. ארזי אל, like strong cedars, i.e., mighty kings.
Heb. קצירה. It sent forth its branches, as (Job 14:9): “and it will produce a branch (קציר).”
Its boundary was until the Mediterranean Sea.

text.title: and to the river its tender shoots:

pasuk.text: The width of Eretz Israel is from the desert to the Euphrates River.
now?
of that vineyard?

text.title: so that all wayfarers have plucked its fruit:

pasuk.text: וארוה. All who came plucked it, as (Song 5:1): “I gathered (אריתי) my myrrh with my spices.” Similarly, in the language of the Mishnah (Shevi’ith 1:2): “as much space as is required by a picker (אורה) and his basket.”

text.title: The boar from the forest gnaws at it:

pasuk.text: Heb. יכרסמנה, as (Peah 2:7): “A field that the ants have nibbled (קרסמוה),” an expression of plucking out.

Heb. מיער. The “ayin” is suspended (as though it were written with an “aleph”). If Israel is worthy, the enemies are like the beasts of the river, which have no strength to climb out upon the dry land; but when retribution is decreed upon them, he (sic) grows strong as the beast of the forest, which destroys and kills. The boar of the forest is Esau, as is written (Dan. 7:7): “It devoured and broke in pieces and the rest it trampled with its feet.” And it (the swine) has some signs of purity. Esau, too, has the merit of his fathers.

text.title: and the creeping things of the field:

pasuk.text: Heb. זיז, all creeping things of the field. The expression זיז means anything that constantly moves from its place.
Graze upon it and its branches and eat them.

text.title: And of the foundation that Your right hand has planted:

pasuk.text: Which is founded and established, which Your right hand has planted, an expression of (Gen. 40:13): “and restore you to your office (כנך).”

text.title: and over the son You have strengthened for Yourself:

pasuk.text: And over Esau, who was a beloved son to this father, who would call him, “my son.” You strengthened the vine of Jacob for Yourself, as it is said (Gen. 27:40): “and You will serve your brother.” Now it is…
Heb. כסוחה, an expression of (Lev. 25:4): "You shall not prune (תזמר), which Onkelos renders: לא תכסח.
constantly; they continually perish from the rebuke of Your face and Your anger.

text.title: May Your hand be upon the man of Your right hand:

pasuk.text: Deliver Your blows upon the manviz. Esauwho is destined to receive retribution from Your right hand.
whom You strengthened for Yourself that his habitation should be the fat places of the earth.

text.title: And let us not withdraw from You:

pasuk.text: Do not cause us to withdraw from You.
from the exile, and we shall mention Your goodness and Your might, and then we shall call out in Your name.

Here are mentioned three holy names, yet in the middle case two names and in the first case one name. All this is according to the intensity of the exile, the trouble, and the redemption (which shall surely come).
A musical instrument that comes from Gath.
on Rosh Hashanah.

text.title: a pleasant harp with a lyre:

pasuk.text: Rabbi Chiyya bar Abba says: The “kinnor” and the “nevel” are the same. Rabbi Simon says: The [number of] strings distinguishes one from the other. Why is it called “nevel” ? Because it puts all other types of music to shame.
When the moon renews itself.
The appointed day for it, and so (Prov. 7:20): “on the appointed day (בכסה) he will come home”; to the appointed time that had been fixed.
According to whatever you ask I will fill.
for Israel from the Holy One, blessed be He, to sound the shofar on that day, the day of the judgment of the Holy One, blessed be He.

text.title: As a testimony for Jehoseph He ordained it:

pasuk.text: On Rosh Hashanah, Joseph went out of prison.

text.title: [when] I understood a language that I had not known:

pasuk.text: It is explained in tractate Sotah (36b) that [the angel] Gabriel taught him seventy languages.
From slave labor to cook the pots in the manner of other slaves.
Heb. מדוד, a pot, as (I Sam. 2: 14): “And he would thrust into the fire-pot or into the pot (הדוד).”
to Me, all of you. You called from the distress of the labor of the burdens of Egypt, and I released you.

text.title: I answered you in secret with thunder:

pasuk.text: You called in secret between Me and you, but I answered you with a voice of thunder; I made known My might and My awesome deeds in public.

text.title: I tried you by the waters of Meribah, forever:

pasuk.text: Although it was revealed and tried before Me that you were destined to provoke Me with the waters of Meribah. So it was taught in Mechilta (Exod. 19:2).
Since I did all this for you, it is fitting for you to hearken to Me.
to request of Me whatever your heart desires.
Heb. בשרירותלבם, after the views of their heart, as (above 5: 9): “because of those who lie in wait for me (שוררי).”

text.title: If only My people would hearken to Me:

pasuk.text: Still, if they desired to return to Me and to hearken to Me…

text.title: In a short time I would subdue their enemies:

pasuk.text: In a short time I would subdue their enemies.
I would return my blow from upon you to lay it upon them, and then…

text.title: The enemies of the Lord would lie to Him, and their time would be:

pasuk.text: [The time of] their retribution [would be] forever.
Israel.
He sated them with honey when they went in His ways, as the matter that is stated (Deut. 32:13): “He suckled them with honey from the rock.”

text.title: God stands in the congregation of God:

pasuk.text: to see whether they [the judges] judge fairly, and you judges, how long will you judge unjustly?
If he [the poor man] is right in his cause, do not reverse the verdict to condemn him in order to favor the wicked.
The judges who pervert justice.
that because of this iniquity, they will walk in the dark (on the order of [Exod. 23:8]: “for bribery blinds, etc.”), and all the foundations of the earth will totter because of it.
Angels. When I gave you the Torah, I gave it to you on the condition that the Angel of Death should not rule over you.

text.title: Indeed, as man, you will die:

pasuk.text: Indeed, as Adam, you will die since you corrupted your deeds as he did.

text.title: and as one of the princes:

pasuk.text: the first [princes], who died, so will you fall. The Midrash Aggadah (Mid. Ps. 82:3) [explains]: As one of the celestial princes, for it is said (Isa. 24:21): “the Lord will visit punishment upon the host of heaven on high.”
Asaph commences to pray that He rise and cut off from Israel those corrupt judges.
are the One Who inherits the nations, and everyone is in Your hands to judge.
Do not give silence to our wrongs, with which our enemies harm us.

text.title: against You they form a pact:

pasuk.text: This pact is only against You, to cause Your name to be forgotten, for You are called the God of Israel, and since Israel will not be remembered, even Your great name is not remembered. I found this.

Even Assyria, which until that day was careful of other foolish counsels and would not join evildoers, as it says (Gen. 10: 11): “From that land Asshur went forth,” that he left the counsel of the generation of dispersion [which built the tower], joined them here and assisted them for evil. (In other commentaries I found this:)

Also this one, who initially loved good deedsfor he separated from Nimrod’s counsel, as it is said: “From that land Asshur went forth” he too reverted to wickedness. Therefore, he participated in destroying Your temple. Genesis Rabbah 37:4.
All these gave strength and aid to Moab and Ammon, our neighbors, to come upon us.
through Gideon.
through Barak.
I do not know which of the wars took place in En-Dor, that of Gideon or that of Barak.
Heb. דמן, scattered dung, as translated by Jonathan.
These nations mentioned above: Edom, Ishmael, and all their allies.

text.title: “Let us inherit for ourselves the dwellings of God”:

pasuk.text: The dwelling of the house of God.

text.title: My God, make them like thistles, like stubble:

pasuk.text: which are driven away by the wind. Now what is גלגל ? It is the tips of the thorns of the field, which are called chardons in French, thistles. When winter arrives, they are plucked out and disintegrate, and little by little they fly [away]. The part that is plucked out of them resembles the wheels of a wagon, and the wind carries them.
Tourbillon in French, whirlwind.

text.title: How beloved are Your dwelling places:

pasuk.text: How beloved and dear are Your dwelling places!
Heb. נכספה Desires.
Heb. כלתה, desires, as (II Sam. 13:39): “And [the soul of] King David longed (ותכל) to go forth to Absalom.”

text.title: for the courts of the Lord:

pasuk.text: for they have been destroyed, and he says this regarding the exile.

text.title: my heart and my flesh pray fervently:

pasuk.text: They pray for this.

text.title: Even a bird found a house:

pasuk.text: In its ruins, the birds have nested. According to Midrash Aggadah (Mid. Ps. 84:2), it speaks of [the Temple] when it is built, and the bird is the nation of Israel.
is he who will yet merit to dwell in Your house, and they will yet praise you in its midst.
Who has made You the strength of his trust.

text.title: in whose heart are the highways:

pasuk.text: Who thinks in his heart the paving of his ways, to straighten his way.

text.title: Transgressors in the valley of weeping:

pasuk.text: Those who transgress Your law behold, they are in the depth of Gehinnom with weeping and wailing.
with the tears of their eyes.

text.title: also with blessings they enwrap [their] Teacher:

pasuk.text: They bless and thank His name and say, “He judged us fairly, and His judgment is true.” (Another explanation: Shem Ephraim) And the one who taught us to follow the good way enwraps us with blessings, but we did not obey him.

text.title: They go from host to host:

pasuk.text: Those mentioned above, who dwell in Your house, in whose heart are the highways.
From the study-hall to the synagogue, and their host and army will appear to the Hole One, blessed be He, in Zion.
to build Your house.
That is the Temple, which protects us.
David Your anointed, and ponder his acts of kindness and his toil, by which he toiled and wearied himself in its building.
[To live] one [day] in Your courts and die the next [is better than] to live a thousand years someplace else.

text.title: I chose to sit on the threshold:

pasuk.text: Heb. הסתופף, to sit habitually on the threshold and by the doorpost.

text.title: rather than dwell in tents of wickedness:

pasuk.text: rather than dwell tranquilly in the tents of the wicked Esau, to cleave to them.

text.title: For a sun and a shield:

pasuk.text: שמש may be interpreted according to its apparent meaning, but Midrash Psalms interprets it as an expression of the points of the wall.

text.title: O Lord, You have appeased Your land, etc.:

pasuk.text: If You have returned the captivity of Jacob and forgiven their iniquity, and have concealed their sin and withdrawn Your wrath from them and retreated from Your fierce anger, then You have appeased Your land, and Your world will be appeased. But as long as You do not do this, Your land and Your world will not be appeased.
You return and bring us back.
ultimately return and revive us, for [so] You promised us through Your prophet.

text.title: I shall hear what God will speak:

pasuk.text: I shall merit to hear what the Holy One, blessed be He, will speak when He speaks peace to His people.
Heb. לכסלה, to foolishness, to sin before Him.
That Israel will speak truth, and from heaven kindness will meet them.
The righteousness [or charity] that Israel was performing and the peace from the Holy One, blessed be He, will kiss one another, i.e., the act of charity will be peace (Isa. 32:12).

text.title: Truth will sprout from the earth, etc.:

pasuk.text: When Israel will speak truth, the charity that they perform on earth will look down from heaven.
He will open His treasury, the heavens, to give rain, in order that His land yield its produce.

text.title: and He will place it on the way of his steps:

pasuk.text: And the Holy One, blessed be He, will place the righteousness in the ways of his steps, with which he leads his sons.

text.title: for I am a pious man:

pasuk.text: that I hear my insults and my disgraces, and I am able to wreak vengeance; yet I remain silent. So it is in Aggadath Tehillim (Mid. Ps. 86:1). Another explanation: Our Sages explained in Berachoth (4a): [David said,] “Am I not a pious man, when all the kings of the Orient and the Occident sit in their glory, and Imy hands are sullied with blood, with the sac, and with the afterbirth?”
All the days of the exile, which is day for the wicked and night for the righteous. It is explained in this manner in Aggadath Tehillim (Mid. Ps. 86:2).
I direct my heart.
Who places the heavenly beings before the earthlings.

text.title: and perform wonders, You, O God, alone:

pasuk.text: Before the angels were created, heaven and earth were created. Therefore, all the nations will glorify Your name.

text.title: from the lowest depths of the grave:

pasuk.text: It is customary for adulterers to be put into the depth of the grave, and from there You saved me, for Nathan the prophet said to me (II Sam. 12:13): “Also the Lord has removed your sin.”

text.title: willful transgressors have risen against me:

pasuk.text: Doeg and Ahithophel.

text.title: and they did not place You before themselves:

pasuk.text: They did not remember what they saw, that Samuel anointed me on Your orders.
The son of the maidservant humbles himself before his master more than the slave purchased with money, because the son of the maidservant was born in the house and was raised in his master’s bosom.

text.title: Grant me a sign for good:

pasuk.text: so it may be apparent to others that You have forgiven me.

the sign and be ashamed. But the Holy One, blessed be He, did not listen to him to grant the sign during his lifetime. Instead, [it came] in his son Solomon’s lifetime when the gates clung to each other and did not open until he said (II Chron. 6:42): “Do not turn back the face of Your anointed; remember the kind deeds of David Your servant.”

text.title: whose foundation is on the mountains of the Sanctuary:

pasuk.text: The foundation of this psalm; the Psalmist founded it on the mountains of Zion and Jerusalem.

text.title: Glorious things are said about you:

pasuk.text: You, Jerusalemwords of glory were spoken about you from the mouth of the Holy One, blessed be He. Now what are the words of glory? That you are the city of God forever.

text.title: I will remind Rahab and Babylon of My beloved ones:

pasuk.text: This too He spoke of You: I shall remind Egypt and Babylon of My beloved ones, to bring them as a gift, as the matter that is stated (Isa. 66:20): “And they will bring all your brethren, etc., a tribute to the Lord.”

text.title: Behold Philistia and Tyre with Cush:

pasuk.text: They too, like Egypt and Babylon, will direct their attention to seek out and to remember each one.
This one was of a family of those born in Zion, as the matter that is stated (Isa. 27:12): “and you will be gathered one by one.”

text.title: And to Zion it will be said, “Man after man was born in her”:

pasuk.text: And when they bring them as a tribute to the Lord, it will be said to Zion concerning each one, “This is [one] of those who were exiled from you,” or “from their generations.” Another explanation: The Psalmist says, “I will mention to my people and to my beloved ones the greatness of Egypt and Babylon, whose greatness they now see. Behold Philistia and Tyre with Cush, because they are near Rahab and Babylon, all the nations exalt them [the Israelites] and say about them, ‘This one was born there,’ in Egypt or Babylon.”

text.title: And to Zion it will be said, “Man, etc.”:

pasuk.text: And this praise that is now [directed] to Rahab and Babylon will be turned around to Zion, and concerning it they will say, “So-and-so and so-and-so were born in her.”

text.title: and He will establish it on high:

pasuk.text: And the Holy One, blessed be He, will establish it above all the cities.

text.title: The Lord counts in the script of the peoples, “This one, etc.”:

pasuk.text: This is a transposed verse, and סלה, forever, which is said at the end, refers to the beginning: When the Lord counts in the script of the peoples forever. That means that in the future, when the Holy One, blessed be He, inscribes the nations for an abhorrence, He will count the Israelites who are assimilated among them and those who were coerced [to abandon Judaism] among them and extract them from their midst, and [He shall] say, “This one was born of those of Zion,” and He will choose them for Himself. This is what Isaiah says (66:21): “And from them, too, will I take for priests and for Levites.” From the nations bringing them for tribute, I shall take those assimilated among them. And there will be among them priests and Levites who are unrecognizable, but they are revealed to Me, says the Lord. Now where did He say it? (Deut. 29:28) “The secret things belong to the Lord, our God.”

text.title: And singers as well as flute players:

pasuk.text: concerning this.
With your salvation.
Heb. כחללים, an expression of (Jud. 21:21) בַּמְחֹלוֹת, musical instruments.

text.title: about the sick and afflicted one:

pasuk.text: Heb. על-מחלתלענות, concerning the one sick with love and afflicted, for she is afflicted with the pains of the exile.
One of the musicians who played a musical instrument, and the sons of Korah established this psalm that Heman should recite it on the “duchan” [the platform].

He was one of the sons of Zerah the son of Judah, for his lineage is delineated in (I Chron. 2:6): “And the sons of Zerah were Zimri, Ethan, Heman, Chalcol, and Darda [sic].” All five were great sages, as is said in reference to Solomon (I Kings 5: 11): “And he was wiser than all men, than Ethan the Ezraite, and Heman, and Chalcol, and Darda, the sons of Mahol,” and they established the Psalms, which were set down in the Book of Psalms. Therefore, they are called the sons of Mahol. So have I found in exact commentaries.

Wherever it says “maskil,” it was said through an interpreter. The prophet would set up an interpreter before him, and when he perceived a prophecy coming upon him, he would recite the prophecy to the interpreter, who would make it heard.

text.title: I cried by day; at night:

pasuk.text: And also at night I am ready before You.

text.title: For my soul is sated with troubles:

pasuk.text: He says this concerning the people of Israel.
Heb. איל, as (above 22:20): “My strength (אילותי), hasten to my assistance.”

text.title: among the dead, who are free:

pasuk.text: I am among the dead, free from the world, and like the slain, who are free from the world.

text.title: and who were cut off by Your hand:

pasuk.text: By Your blows, they were cut off from the world.

text.title: You have put me into the lowest pit:

pasuk.text: That is the exile.
leans and hangs [sic] on me.

text.title: and [with] all Your waves You have afflicted [me] constantly:

pasuk.text: Heb. משבריך, an expression of the waves of the sea. They are all the storms of Your wrath; with all of them have You constantly afflicted me.

text.title: You have made me an abomination to them:

pasuk.text: The nations, in whose eyes I was esteemednow I am repugnant to them.
Confined in a prison, and I cannot go out.

text.title: Will You perform a wonder for the dead?:

pasuk.text: Do You perform a wonder and miracles for the wicked, who are called dead even in their lifetime?

text.title: Will the shades rise and thank You:

pasuk.text: Heb. רפאים, lit. the weak. Will the nations that weakened their [Israel’s] hands from Your service rise and thank You? This is a wonder.

text.title: Will Your kindness be told in the grave:

pasuk.text: if we die in the hands of our enemies, will we be able to recite Your praise in the grave?

Heb. וגוע מנער, dying from the strangulation of sudden death, as (Exod. 14:27): “and the Lord strangled (וינער).” Menachem (p. 123) defines וינער as an expression of beating, as (Isa. 33: 15): “who shakes (נוער) his hands from taking hold of bribe” ; (Isa. 52:2), “Shake yourself (התנערי) from the dust, arise” ; (Isa. 1: 31), “And the[ir] strength will become as tow (לנערת) ” ; (Job 38: 13), “so that the wicked will be shaken (וינערו) from it” ; (Neh. 5: 13), “even thus may he be shaken out (נעור) and emptied.”
Heb. אפונה. Your fear is settled and based in my heart. אפוּנה is an expression of (Prov. 25:11): “a word spoken with proper basis (אפניו) ”; on its basis.

text.title: From my acquaintances, I am withdrawn:

pasuk.text: Heb. מחשך. I am withdrawn and withheld from them.
He, too, was one of the five musician brothers. [See above 88:1.] But our Sages (B.B. 15a) explained it as referring to our father Abraham, based on (Isa. 41:2): “Who aroused from the East (ממזרח).”

text.title: I shall make known Your faithfulness, with my mouth:

pasuk.text: What I know of You: that You keep Your promise and fulfill Your words.

text.title: For I said, “Forever will it be built with kindness”:

pasuk.text: For I said, “Forever the throne of David will be built with kindness,” as it is said (II Sam. 7:13): “and I shall establish the throne of his kingdom, etc.” Another explanation: I thought that the world would be built with Your kindness and that You would establish Your faithfulness in the heavens, to be established and made permanent. Now what is the faithfulness? That promise You promised David through Nathan the prophet, saying, “I formed a covenant with My chosen one to establish his seed until eternity.”

text.title: And the heavens acknowledge Your wonder:

pasuk.text: If You had kept Your promise.

text.title: and Your faithfulness in the congregation of the holy ones:

pasuk.text: The realization of Your words they will acknowledge in the congregation of the holy ones.
Can be evaluated like Him.

text.title: in the great council of the holy ones:

pasuk.text: In the great council of the angels.
When its waves are raised.
Heb. תשבחם, You humble them, and similarly, (Prov. 29:11): “but afterwards a wise man will quiet it (ושבחנה) ” ; and similarly (above 65:8): “Who humbles (משביח) the roaring of the seas.”
Egypt.

text.title: that know the blasting of the shofar:

pasuk.text: Who know how to appease their Creator on Rosh Hashanah with the blasts, upon which they arrange the blessings of “malchuyoth” (manifestations of God’s dominion), “zichronoth” (remembrances), and “shofaroth.”
that You are appeased by them (apayement in Old French), propitiation.
Nathan the prophet and Gad the seer.
on David, to help him constantly.

text.title: No enemy will exact from him:

pasuk.text: No enemy will overwhelm him to become as his creditor.
I shall make him great.

text.title: I shall punish their transgression with a rod:

pasuk.text: So did Nathan the prophet say to him concerning Solomon (II Sam. 7:14): “so that when he goes astray, I will chasten him with the rod of men.” This refers to Rezon the son of Eliada, who rose up as an adversary to him: “and with the stripes of the sons of Adam.” This refers to Ashmadai, according to the Sages of blessed memory.

text.title: that I will not fail David:

pasuk.text: Heb. אכזב, an expression of (Isa. 58: 11): “whose water does not fail (יכזבו) ,” faliance in Old French, failure; possibly from the Latin fallera, deception.

text.title: and it is a witness in the sky, true:

pasuk.text: The moon and the sun are witnesses to him that as long as they exist, his kingdom will exist, as it is written (Jer. 33:20f.): “If you break My covenant with the day and My covenant with the night, etc. Also My covenant with David will be broken.”
You dealt strictly with his children in counting their iniquity until You abandoned them and You rejected them in the days of Zedekiah.
You nullified.
which he built in Jerusalem.
The Temple Mount and the stronghold of Zion.

text.title: You even turned back the sharp edge of his sword:

pasuk.text: You turned back and reversed the sharp edge of his sword, as (Josh. 5: 2): “sharp (צרים) knives,” and likewise (Isa. 54:17): “Any weapon whetted (יוצר) against you.”

text.title: and You did not raise him up in battle:

pasuk.text: And You did not hold him upright so that he should not fall.

text.title: You have brought an end to his shining:

pasuk.text: Heb. מטהרו, his shining, as צהרים, noon, is translated טהרא, and like (Exod. 24: 10): “and like the appearance of the heaven for splendor (לטהר).”

text.title: You have cast down to the earth:

pasuk.text: Heb. מגרת. You have humbled and destroyed. Every expression of bending down is, in Targum Jonathan, מגר.

text.title: I am mindful what my old age is:

pasuk.text: Heb. חלד. What old age do I have? Are not my days few? It should suffice You to punish me with my premature death.
Heb. שוא. For nothing and for vanity have You created all the sons of man?

text.title: which I bear in my bosom, of all great nations:

pasuk.text: In exile I bear their burden and their load.

Heb. עקבות, the ends of the King Messiah. This is the language of the Mishnah (Sotah 49b): At the ends of the Messiah, audacity will increase; i.e., at the end of the exile, prior to the advent of the Messiah.
For all that He did for us.

Moses recited all the eleven psalms from here to (ch. 101) “Of David, a song.” Corresponding to them, he [Moses] blessed eleven tribes with eleven blessings, in (Deut. 33): “And this is the blessing.”

text.title: You have been our dwelling place:

pasuk.text: Heb. מעון, an abode and a refuge in which to enter. [That is what] You have been for us.
From time immemorial, for You preceded all.
[i.e., before they] were created, and before You brought forth the earth and the inhabited world, and from the first world to the last world, You are God.

text.title: You bring man to the crushing point:

pasuk.text: You bring agonies upon man until You reduce him to a weakened state, near death, and You tell him with these agonies, “Return, O sons of men from your evil ways.”

text.title: For a thousand years are in Your eyes:

pasuk.text: A thousand years of man are like one day of the Holy One, blessed be He, and part of the night with it; for one day of the Holy One, blessed He, and a little of the night of the Holy One, blessed be He, are a thousand years, for the text does not say that the day of the Holy One, blessed be He, is like a thousand years, but that when a little of the night elapses with it, then His day is complete, and it is a thousand years. Therefore, Adam died within a thousand [years] for had he lived a thousand [years] it would be more than the day of the Holy One, blessed be He. Perhaps the amount of that watch equals the time from the death of Adam until a thousand years, but we do not know how much that watch was, except from conjecture. I found [this]:

text.title: For a thousand years are in Your eyes, etc.:

pasuk.text: And when repentance came into Your thoughts from the beginning, You judged well and created it. Now those years were appropriate for it because people’s days were many, so that a thousand years were in Your eyes like one passing day, which passed and was gone, with a little of the night with it, for You said to Adam (Gen. 2:17): “for on the day you eat of it, you will surely die,” and he lived nine hundred and thirty years. We find that a thousand years equal one whole day and a little of the night with it.
Which already passed.

text.title: You carry them away as a flood; they are like a sleep:

pasuk.text: Now you have seized those years and had them become a few days, which are merely like a sleep of slumber, for the years of the generations are seventy years, as is explained at the end of the chapter: “The days of our years because of them are seventy years,” and they are regarded as one sleep. As the matter that is said (below 126:1) “When the Lord returns the returnees to Zion, we shall be like dreamers.” This was stated regarding the Babylonian exile, which lasted seventy years.

text.title: You carry them away as a flood:

pasuk.text: Heb. זרמתם, an expression of flooding, as (Hab. 3:10): “A stream (זרם) of water.”

text.title: in the morning, like grass it passes away:

pasuk.text: If one is born at night, he dies in the morning at the end of his sleep. And if,…
it passes away immediately, and when evening comes, it is cut off and withered. Why?

text.title: For we perish from Your wrath, and from Your anger, etc.:

pasuk.text: That is to say: And because of all this,…

text.title: You have placed our iniquities before You:

pasuk.text: and our youth, the sins of our youth, You have placed before the light of Your countenance.
Heb. עלמנו, our youth, as (I Sam. 17: 56): “whose son is this youth (העלם).”

text.title: before the light of Your countenance:

pasuk.text: opposite You and to look at them.

text.title: have passed away in Your anger:

pasuk.text: Have turned, have been cleared away, and have gone away in Your anger.
Like speech, which hastens to disappear.

text.title: The days of our years because of them are seventy years:

pasuk.text: The days of these years of ours, because of these iniquities of ours and because of these sins of our youth, are seventy years.
And if his days are much increased, they are eighty years.

text.title: but their pride is toil and pain:

pasuk.text: But all the greatness and the dominion that a person enjoys in these days are only toil and pain. Why? Because it passes quickly and we fly away. During its swift passing, we fly away and die.
Heb. גז, an expression of passing, as (Nahum 1:12): “they have crossed (נגוזו) ” ; (Num. 11:31), “and drove (ויגז) quails up from the sea.”

text.title: Who knows the might of Your wrath:

pasuk.text: In these few days, who can acquire intelligence to know the might of Your wrath and to fear You, and as for YouYour fear is Your anger. Just as You are feared, so is Your anger harsh, and You exact retribution from the sinners.

text.title: So teach the number of our days:

pasuk.text: And just as in the beginning, make known in the world the number of our long days, and since we enjoy longevity, we will be able to acquire intelligence, and we will acquire in them a heart of wisdom. The word נביא is an expression of bringing [rather than of a prophet. Cf. B.B. 12a, Targum ad. loc, Redak below]. (Some say: According to the number of our days כן, according to the numerical value of כן, seventy years. He says: According to the number of our years, which are few, so shall You chastise us, as [Jud. 8:16]: “and with them he chastised (ויודע) the men of Succoth.” This does not appear in all editions.)
from Your burning wrath.
Think well about Your servants.
On the day of the redemption and the salvation, which is the morning of the night of the trouble, the sighing, and the darkness.

text.title: and let us sing praises and rejoice with all our days:

pasuk.text: i.e., with all the troubles that passed over us in these days of ours.

text.title: Cause us to rejoice according to the days that You afflicted us:

pasuk.text: Cause us to rejoice in the days of our Messiah according to the number of days that You afflicted us in the exiles and according to the number of years that we experienced evil.

text.title: And may the pleasantness of the Lord our God be upon us:

pasuk.text: His presence and His consolations.

text.title: and the work of our hands establish for us:

pasuk.text: Heb. כוננה. This is an expression of supplication. כוֹננה is like שמרה, watch, שפטה, judge.

Establish it. The two times “and the work of our hands establish” [are mentioned are for the following purposes]: One is for the work of the Tabernacle, when he blessed Israel and prayed that the Shechinah should rest on the work of their hands in the Tabernacle, and one is that there should be a blessing in the work of their hands.

text.title: He who dwells in the covert of the Most High:

pasuk.text: He who takes shelter in the covert of the wings of the Shechinahhe will lodge in His shadow, for the Holy One, blessed be He, protects him. Moses, our teacher, hereby persuades people to take shelter in the wings of the Shechinah.
Heb. שדי, an expression of strength. “He who dwells in the covert of the Most High” is like (Song 2:3): “in His shadow I desired and sat.”

text.title: I shall say of the Lord [that He is] my shelter and my fortress:

pasuk.text: and all will learn from me. Now why do I say this?

text.title: For He will save you from the snare that traps, etc.:

pasuk.text: To everyone he says, “He who dwells in the covert of the Most High.”

text.title: With His wing He will cover… you will take refuge:

pasuk.text: You will be covered.
Heb. צנה וסחרה. This is a shield that encompasses a man closely on his four sides. וסֹחֵרָה is an expression of סְחוֹר סְחוֹר, around.
if you trust in Him.

text.title: the arrow that flies by day:

pasuk.text: the demon that flies like an arrow.
These are names of demons; one destroys at night, and one destroys at noon.
Heb. יָשוּד, [equivalent to] יְשוֹדֵד.

text.title: A thousand will be stationed at your side:

pasuk.text: Heb. יפל, an expression of encamping, as (Gen. 25:18): “before the face of all his brothers did he settle (נפל).”
At your left a thousand demons will be stationed, and they will not approach you to harm [you].
Heb. ושלמת, complete destruction. And why?
You said, “The Lord is my refuge.” This is an elliptical verse.

text.title: the Most High you made your dwelling:

pasuk.text: You made the Holy One, blessed be He, the seat of your trust.
Heb. לא תאנה, will not happen. Similarly, (Exod. 21:13): “and God allowed it to happen (אנה) to his hand.”
Heb. תגף, lest it [your foot] stumble, and so every expression of נְגִפָה, acupir, azoper, to hit, strike against.
of the Levites.
that they would recite on Sabbaths, and it deals with the world to come, which is entirely Sabbath.

text.title: To declare in the morning Your kindness:

pasuk.text: At the time of the Redemption.
And during the distress of the exile, to believe in You that You will keep Your promise, all this is splendid and good.

text.title: Upon a ten-stringed harp and upon a psaltery:

pasuk.text: Heb. עשור, a harp of ten strings.

text.title: A boorish man does not know:

pasuk.text: What is stated below.

text.title: When the wicked flourish like grass:

pasuk.text: they do not know that their flourishing is only to destroy them to eternity, for He recompenses His enemies to their face to destroy them.
In all Your judgments, You have the upper hand, for all justify Your judgments.

text.title: to soak me with fresh oil:

pasuk.text: Heb. בלתי. To soak me with the oil of dominion. בַלֹתִי is like (Num. 15:9): “mingled (בלולה) with oil.”

text.title: upon those who stare at me:

pasuk.text: Heb. בשורי, at those who stare at me, as (5:9): “those who lie in wait for me (בשוררי).”

text.title: when evildoers rise up against me:

pasuk.text: About the wicked who rise up against me, my ears heard from behind the “veil” that they will not succeed in destroying us [perhaps, David and his men]. So I heard.

text.title: The righteous one flourishes like the palm, etc.:

pasuk.text: Like the palm that produces fruit, and like the cedar insofar as its trunk renews itself.
The righteous will be [planted] in the house of the Lord.
Heb. ישגה, will grow.
Heb. דשנים, They will be fat and fresh, and then they will declare that the Lord is upright.
They will say in the future.
When He reigns, the earth will rejoice.

text.title: The rivers have raised, O Lord:

pasuk.text: This is an expression of a cry and a plaint: Woe, O Lord, behold! Your enemies, who flood like rivers, have raised their voice and roar, and the lowness of the depths of their locks they will raise and lift on high constantly to be haughty against You. Every expression of דכא is an expression of depth and lowness.

text.title: More than the voices of great waters, etc.:

pasuk.text: I know that more than the voices of great waters, which roar over us, and more than the mightiest breakers of this sea, You are mighty, O Lord, and Your hand is powerful over them.
which Your prophets prophesied and promised concerning Your house, which is the dwelling of holiness.

text.title: are very faithful to Your house:

pasuk.text: and to the length of days He looks forward to them, and although it has been a long time, they are very faithful to God.

Heb. נאוה, like (83:13): “the dwellings נְאוֹת of God,” an expression of נָוֶה. You should know [that this is so] because no instance of נָאוָה has a pronounced “aleph,” for they are an expression of נוֹי beauty, but this one has an “aleph” which is pronounced.
Heb. הופיע, show and reveal to us Your vengeance.
Heb. יתאמרו. They praise themselves, as (Deut. 26: 17f.): “you praised (האמרת) ,” and “praised you (האמירך).”

text.title: Understand, [you] most boorish of the people:

pasuk.text: the most foolish peoples in the world.

text.title: Will He Who implants the ear:

pasuk.text: Is it possible that the Holy One, blessed be He, Who implanted the ear, should not hear the cry of His people and their affliction?
and chastise you for that?
your thoughts, that you are thinking to be haughty with the crown of the kingdom, and you should know that they [your thoughts] are vanity.
Fortunate are the righteous who are afflicted under Your hands, provided that they engage in Torah and mitzvoth.

text.title: To grant him peace from days of evil:

pasuk.text: For the chastisements cause him to have peace from the days of the judgment of Gehinnom.
he sees that a pit is dug for the wicked man.

text.title: For until righteousness will judgment return:

pasuk.text: [i. e., the judgment of] their chastisements [will persist] until they become righteous because of them. And after the judgment, all those upright in heart will gather, for they will receive their reward.

text.title: Who will rise up for me:

pasuk.text: Whose merit will stand up for us among these evildoers?

text.title: Who will rise up for me:

pasuk.text: Whose merit will stand up for us among these evildoers?

text.title: Will the throne of evil join You:

pasuk.text: Will it be able to compare to You?
for the sake of a statue, to be for them as the statute of their worship.
Troops gather upon a Jewish soul to kill [him].
Heb. ירשיעו. They condemn in judgment to kill him.
Heb. אונם, their violence, as (Job 21: 19): “Should God lay away his violence (אונו) for his sons?”
An expression of height, like a bird that flies [up high].
Heb. נברכה, an expression of (Gen. 24: 11): “He made the camels kneel (ויברך).”
In this world.
for nothing.

text.title: even though they had seen My work:

pasuk.text: in Egypt.

I quarreled with them and contended with them. [אקוט is] an expression of (Job 10:1): “My soul quarrels (נקטה) with my life.” I strove with them for forty years to kill them in the desert, because I said, “They are of erring heart.”
[In] to the land of Israel and Jerusalem, which I called “resting place,” as it says (below 132:14): “This is my resting place forever.”
This song deals with the future, as is proven by the final verse, “for He has come to judge the earth.” Any reference to a “new song” deals with the future.

text.title: Ascribe to the Lord, families of peoples:

pasuk.text: And what shall you ascribe to Him? Ascribe to the Lord glory and might.
This song will be [sung] in the future.

text.title: He will judge peoples with equity:

pasuk.text: Those whom he will turn into a clear tongue (Zeph. 3:9).
with merits.
to raise its voice in praise.
All the rulers of the nations.
when He takes the kingdom from Amalek and from his descendants.
This is what Ezekiel said (35:14): “When the whole earth rejoices, I shall make you desolate.” He prophesied this concerning Amalek.

in the war of Gog and Magog, for it is written concerning his war (Ezek. 38:22): “And I shall plead against him with pestilence and with blood, and rain bringing floods and great hailstones, fire and brimstone.”
His brilliant lights, an expression of (Ezek. 21:15): “It is polished that it may glitter (ברק).”

“Surely there will be a great earthquake on that day in the land of Israel. And at My presence, the fishes of the sea… will quake.” [The word] וַתָּחֵל is an expression of (above 48: 7): “pangs (חיל) like [those of] a woman in confinement.”
Heb. כדונג, as it is written (Ezek. 38:20): “and the mountains will be thrown down, and the cliffs will fall.”

text.title: All worshippers of graven images will be ashamed:

pasuk.text: as it is written (Isa. 2:18): “And the idols will completely pass away.”
Who praise themselves with their worship.
Your vengeance.

text.title: A light is sown for the righteous:

pasuk.text: A real sowing is prepared to grow for them.
All these are for the future.
The prophets spoke in a language that the ear can hear; not that the rivers have a hand, but it is an expression of joy and gladness.
[This] deals with the war of Gog and Magog. Then the nations will quake, as the matter that is said (Zech. 14: 12): “And this shall be the plague, etc.”
Heb. תנוט, an expression of (73:2): “my feet faltered (נטוי).”
They will acknowledge the might of the King Who loves judgment.

text.title: and the might of the King Who loves judgment:

pasuk.text: This refers back to the preceding verse.

You founded compromise and peacemaking between persons, by Your statement (Exod. 23:5): “Should you see your enemy’s donkey lying etc.” ; (ibid. verse 4), “Should you come upon Your enemy’s ox, etc.” Now who is it who sees his enemy being kind to him, whose heart will not be inspired to embrace him and kiss him? (Tanchuma).

text.title: In a pillar of cloud He would speak to them:

pasuk.text: Even with Samuel. This is what is stated (I Sam. 9:11f.): “and they said to them, Is the seer here? and they answered them and said, He is (יֵש).” You will see a cloud attached to his doorway, as Scripture says (Num. 9:20): “And sometimes the cloud would be…”

text.title: they kept His testimonies and the statute He gave them:

pasuk.text: The statute that He gave them.
[Forgiving] the iniquity of Israel.
Heb. להם, for their sake.
You were vengeful for their misdeeds: Moses and Aaron for “Hear now, you rebels!” As for Samuel, because he did not direct his sons in the good way, he died young.

text.title: for the Lord our God is holy:

pasuk.text: because He is strict with the righteous, He is sanctified in the world, and so He says (Exod. 29: 43): “and it will be sanctified with My glory,” meaning “with those glorified by Me.”

text.title: A song for a thanksgiving offering:

pasuk.text: For thanksgiving, to recite it over thanksgiving offerings.
Now why so much? You should know the Lord is God, Who recompenses you with reward for your work, but the heathens need not worship with joy because their deities do not give them any reward.

text.title: He made us and we are His:

pasuk.text: When we were not in the world.
His faith will endure. Every expression of truth (אמת) and faith (אמונה) means the realization of a promise, that He makes true and assures His promise.

text.title: I shall sing of kindness and judgment:

pasuk.text: when You bestow kindness upon me, I will praise you [with the blessing:] “Blessed be He Who is good and does good,” and when You perform judgment upon me, I will sing, “Blessed be the true Judge.” In either case, to You, O Lord, I shall sing.
I shall direct my thoughts to the way of integrity.

text.title: When will it come to me:

pasuk.text: The straight path, to walk upon it, and I shall walk with the integrity of my heart even within my house, in private as well as in public.
Heb. סטים, an expression of (Num. 5:12): “whose wife strays (תשטה) from the right path,” to turn away from the road, destolemant in Old French, to swerve.
I love no [evil] (Another explanation: [Shem Ephraim]) I recognize no evil thing.
that he should be my friend, lest I learn from his deeds.
Every day, I cut down the wicked of Israel little by little, those who are condemned to death.

text.title: A prayer for a poor man:

pasuk.text: Israel, who is a poor people.
when their soul is enwrapped in distress.
