Heb. נחרו. The “nun” serves as a prefix, as: נַעֲשׂוּ, they were made, נִקְנוּ, they were acquired; and it is an expression of dryness, as (Job 30:30): “and my bones dried out (חרה) from the heat” ; (Jer. 6:29), “the bellows is heated (נחר).”
Heb. לקאת. It is the name of a bird.

text.title: Like an owl of the wasteland:

pasuk.text: Heb. ככוס, the name of a bird, as (Lev. 11:17): “The owl (הכוס), the cormorant, and the night owl.”
deserts. I was like a bird of the desert. So do we wander from our place to go into exile.
I pondered about myself, and behold I am like a lonely bird on a roof, sitting alone without a mate.
Heb. בודד, sitting alone.
Heb. מהוללי, those who scorn me, an expression of mockery.
They saw my misfortune and they swear by me and say, “If it is not so, what happened to Israel should happen to me.” “So may the Lord do to me as to Israel.”
I mixed with tears.
First You picked me up and now You cast me down from heaven to the earth, and if You had not picked me up first, my disgrace would not be so great.
At eventide, when the shadows lengthen, and when it becomes dark, they are not recognizable, but progressively disappear.
Who will be enthroned forever, and Who swore to us by Yourself, just as You exist, it is incumbent upon You to fulfill it. Therefore…

text.title: You will rise, You will have mercy on Zion for it is time to favor it:

pasuk.text: For so You promised (Deut. 32:36): “When He sees that their power is gone,” and it is indeed gone.

They loved even its stones and its earth. [According to] Midrash Aggadah, when Jeconiah and his exile left, they carried with them some of the stones and the earth of Jerusalem to build a synagogue for themselves there in Babylon.
Your name when You save Your people.

text.title: He has turned to the prayer of those who cried out:

pasuk.text: Heb. הערער, who cries out, as (Isa. 15:5): “a cry of destruction they will raise (יעוערו).” Another explanation: ערער means devastated and destroyed, as (below 137: 7) “who say, ‘Raze it, raze it.’ ”
So will those who see the salvation say, “let this salvation be inscribed for the latest generation.”
that became a new creature to emerge from slavery to freedom and from darkness to a great light.
to see the affliction of His people.
Heb. תמותה, mortally ill, enmorindes in Old French (as above 79:11).

text.title: He has afflicted my strength on the way:

pasuk.text: He returns to his original complaint, “for You picked me up and cast me down. My days are like a lengthening shadow.” My enemy afflicted my strength on the way.
to the Lord, “You are my God.”

text.title: do not take me away in the middle of my days:

pasuk.text: Do not take us away to destroy us from the earth in the hands of our enemies in the middle of our days. And what are our days? All the days of all generations, of Your years, You promised to keep us alive before You, as he says at the end of the psalm, “and Your years do not end… and their seed will be established before You.”
Heb. לפנים, from the beginning.

text.title: like raiment You will turn them over:

pasuk.text: like a person who turns his garment inside out to take it off.
Who stands and exists.

There are five mentions of “My soul, bless” here, corresponding to the five worlds in which man lives, as our Sages said in Tractate Berachoth (10a): “He lived in his mother’s womb, he sucked his mother’s breasts, and so all of them.”

text.title: that your youth renews itself like the eagle:

pasuk.text: Like this eagle, which renews its wings and feathers from year to year. There is a Midrash Aggadah about a kind of eagle that returns to its youth when it becomes old.
He makes His ways known to Moses.

text.title: He remembers that we are dust:

pasuk.text: He remembers and has not forgotten that we are dust and He knows that: “As for manhis days, etc.”

text.title: For a wind passes over him:

pasuk.text: If mortal illness passes over him.

text.title: Bless the Lord, all His works:

pasuk.text: who are in all the places of His dominion.
in the sky like a garment.
lit. He makes His messengers winds. He makes the wind His messengers.

text.title: You covered the deep as [with] a garment:

pasuk.text: This is similar to what is said elsewhere (Job 38:9): “When I made the cloud its raiment, etc.”
That is the sea.

text.title: the waters stand on the mountains:

pasuk.text: The waters of the ocean are higher than the whole world. They stand on the mountains, and so Scripture states (Amos 5:8, 9:6): “He who calls the water of the sea and pours it upon the face of the earth.” Pouring denotes only [pouring] from above downward.
When You said (Gen. 1:9): “Let the waters gather.” And from that voice they hastened away and gathered in the place that You founded for them.
for them, viz. the sand that is around its shore.

text.title: Beside them the fowl of the heavens dwell:

pasuk.text: Beside the springs.
Heb. עפאים, the branches of the trees, and so (Dan. 4:11): “its branches were (עפיה) beautiful.”
which cheers man’s heart, that too He brings forth from the earth, and oil to cause the face to radiate.
which sustains man’s heart.
in the Garden of Eden.
Israel will dwell there. יְקַנֵנוּ is an expression of a bird’s nest (קן צפור).
He created for the ibexes.
Every expression of מַחְסֶה is an expression of a shadow and a hiding place, where a person covers himself from flood and rain.

text.title: He made the moon for the appointed seasons:

pasuk.text: To count with it the times and the festivals.
But the moon does not know its setting, because sometimes it comes through a long way and sometimes it comes through a short way.

text.title: You make darkness and it is night:

pasuk.text: Every day You darken and block out the sun and it becomes night, when all the beasts of the forest move about.

text.title: When the sun rises they gather in:

pasuk.text: into the secret places and hide there from the sons of men; then every man goes forth to his work.
Heb. קנינך, the acquisition that you have acquired, like (Gen. 14:19): “Owner (קנה) of heaven and earth.” All is acquired by You.
Heb. ורחב ידים. Wide of place, large in French, broad.
three hours during the day. So did our Sages say in tractate Avodah Zarah (3b), and so it is written explicitly in the Book of Job (40:29): “Will you play with him like a bird?”
Heb. תסף, an expression of destruction, as (above 73:19): “They were completely consumed (ספו).”

text.title: You will send forth Your spirit:

pasuk.text: with the resurrection of the dead.

text.title: He touches the mountains and they emit smoke:

pasuk.text: as is depicted of Sinai (Exod. 19:18): “And Mount Sinai was all in smoke.”
Heb. בעדי, like (Deut. 31:27): “When I am still (בעודני) alive.”
Heb. חטאים, sinners [rather than sins, but see Tal. Ber. 10a].
Heb. עלילותיו, His deeds.
Boast of the stronghold of His holy name that you have a patron like Him. התהללוּ is “porvontez vous” in Old French, [vantez vous in modern French, boast].

text.title: the word He had commanded to the thousandth generation:

pasuk.text: The Torah, which He commanded to make known in the world after a thousand generations, but He saw that the world could not exist without Torah, so he skipped 974 generations of them. It may also be interpreted according to its simple meaning: He remembered for Israel His covenant, which He commanded and promised to keep for them for a thousand generations, as the matter of (Deut. 7:9): “Who keeps the covenant and the kindness for those who love Him and who keep His commandments, to a thousand generations.”

text.title: Saying, “To you I shall give, etc.”:

pasuk.text: That is the covenant that He made for them.

text.title: And they walked from nation to nation:

pasuk.text: Abraham sojourned in the land of the Philistines, in Egypt, and in the land of Canaan, and so Isaac, and so Jacobthey all were exiled from one strange place to another strange place.

text.title: and He reproved kings on their account:

pasuk.text: (Gen. 12:17): “And the Lord plagued Pharaoh” ; (ibid. 20: 18), “For the Lord had closed up every womb of the house of Abimelech.”
My great ones. Every [expression of] anointing is an expression of rulership and greatness.
in order to exile them to Egypt (I found).

text.title: He sent a man before them:

pasuk.text: (Gen. 45:5): “And God sent me before you.” Now who was the man? Joseph, who was sold.

text.title: his soul was placed in irons:

pasuk.text: Said Rav Huna the son of Idi: She [Potiphar’s wife] made him a “shirtua” under his beard, so that if he bent his face over, the “shirtua” would wound him. שרתוע means a forked, suspended spear.
[The word] of the Holy One, blessed be He, to fulfill His decree that the matter should “roll” and Israel should descend to Egypt.

text.title: the saying of the Lord purified him:

pasuk.text: It tried Joseph, for he was tested and he overcame the temptation [to sin] with his master’s wife, and he was tortured because of her and purified with tortures to place him in the dungeon.

text.title: A king sent and released him:

pasuk.text: Pharaoh, king of Egypt, sent his messengers and released him. A ruler of peoples, viz. Pharaoh, [sent] and loosed his bonds.

text.title: To bind up his princes with his soul:

pasuk.text: This is an expression of endearment, as (I Sam. 18:1): “that Jonathan’s soul had become attached to David’s soul.” When he interpreted the dream, they all loved him. Said Rabbi Idi: It is written שָׂרוֹ, his prince. This was Potiphar.
The Holy One, blessed be He, [made] His people [fruitful]. He made them fruitful and caused them to multiply.

text.title: And they did not disobey His word:

pasuk.text: The plagues, that He commanded upon them, came according to His commandments and did not deviate from His word.
Said Rabbi Johanan: Wherever water would lie, frogs would lie.

text.title: They asked, and He brought quails:

pasuk.text: Israel asked for meat, and the Holy One, blessed be He, brought them quails.
Rivers flowed from the well in an arid land.

The Holy One, blessed be He, [remembered] His holy word, which was with Abraham His servant, which He promised him (Gen. 15:14, 17): “and afterwards they will go out with many possessions… and a fourth generation will return here.”
When You show goodwill to Your people.

text.title: and they were rebellious by the sea:

pasuk.text: They had little faith; they said, “Just as we ascend from here, from this side, the Egyptians also are ascending from another side, and they will come after us,” until the Holy One, blessed be He, hinted to the sea, and it vomited them out onto the dry land. Then (Exod. 15:30) “Israel saw the Egyptians dead on the seashore.” Therefore (ibid. verse 31) “they believed in the Lord,” but in the beginning, they did not believe. I found this.

text.title: and He led them in the depths in the desert:

pasuk.text: The Sea of Reeds was in the desert, for it is written (Exod. 14:13): “the desert has closed upon them, etc.” ; (Exod. 3: 18): “three days’ journey in the desert.”

text.title: they did not await His counsel:

pasuk.text: They did not hope for Him.
(Num. 11:4) “Who will give us meat to eat?”

text.title: but He sent emaciation into their soul:

pasuk.text: (Num. 11:33) “and the Lord’s wrath was kindled against the people.”
Heb. ויקנאו. In the desert they angered him, like (Deut. 32:21): “They angered Me (קנאוני) with a no-god.” I found this.
It appears that [the Psalmist] bestowed honor upon the sons of Korah [by refraining] from mentioning their father. He attributed the sin to Dathan and Abiram.
(Num. 16: 35) “and consumed the two hundred and fifty men who burnt the incense. ”
There is nothing as disgusting and repugnant as an ox. When it eats grass, it emits much dung, with which it sullies itself. Other books read: its saliva.
when the spies were sent out, and they brought calumny on the land (Num. 13:32).
with an oath.

text.title: And to cast their seed among the nations:

pasuk.text: From that time, the destruction of the Temple was decreed upon them, for on the night of the ninth of Ab they went, and the Holy One, blessed be He, said, “They wept for nothing, and I shall establish for them weeping for generations.”
Moses and Aaron.
with (Num. 20:10) “Hear now, you rebels!”

text.title: and He uttered with His lips:

pasuk.text: an oath (Num. 20: 12): “Therefore you shall not bring this community, etc.”
in the days of Joshua.

text.title: the peoples whom the Lord had told them:

pasuk.text: (Deut. 20:16): “You shall not allow a soul to remain alive” ; (Exod. 23:33), “They shall not remain as residents in your land,” but they allowed them to dwell in their midst, paying tribute.

text.title: And He delivered them into the hands of nations:

pasuk.text: in the days of the Judges between one judge and another, e.g. Eglon, Cushan-rishathaim, Sisera, the Philistines, and Midian. (I found.)
Many times they provoked Him; yet He was slow to anger and saved them.

text.title: and they were humbled because of their iniquity:

pasuk.text: Heb. וימכו, and they were humbled because of their iniquity.

text.title: But He looked upon their distress:

pasuk.text: On account of prayer.
On account of the merit of the Patriarchs.
On account of repentance.

text.title: and He relented in accordance with His abundant kindness:

pasuk.text: On account of the end, when He heard, “Save us, etc.” Moses, too, included them in one verse (Deut. 4:30): “In this distress that will befall you etc.”
now also, O Lord, our God.
From this world to the world to come.

pasuk.title: Give thanks to the Lord because He is good, etc.:

text.title: Those redeemed by the Lord shall say it:

pasuk.text: when He redeems them from the hands of an oppressor.

text.title: They strayed in the desert, on a road of desolation, etc.:

pasuk.text: Those who travel in the deserts must also give thanks because sometimes they stray and suffer from hunger and thirst.
And He led them; therefore, they shall give thanks to the Lord for His kindness.

text.title: Those who sit in darkness and the shadow of death:

pasuk.text: Also those imprisoned in a dungeon are required to give thanks when they emerge from their prison.

text.title: For they rebelled against the words of God:

pasuk.text: Trouble does not befall a person except because of his iniquity.
that were shut before them.

text.title: Fools, because of the way of their transgression and because of their iniquities, are afflicted:

pasuk.text: with the agonies of illnesses. They too are among those who are required to give thanks. There are markers in this chapter (i.e., six inverted “nuns” are written) and they come to be expounded upon instead of “buts” and “onlys” to limit [the power of the verse] meaning that if they [the prisoners] cry out before the verdict has been promulgated, they are answered; after the verdict has been promulgated, they are not answered.
Heb. יחוגו. This is an expression of breaking. Similarly (Song 2:14): “in the clefts of (בחגוי) the rock” ; and similarly (Isa. l9:17), “And the land of Judah will be to Egypt for a dread (לחגא).”

text.title: They rejoiced that they were stilled:

pasuk.text: The waves.

Heb. מחוז, an expression of a border, and Menachem (p. 86) associated it with (Isa. 28:18): “and your limit (וחזותכם) with the grave,” your limit, that it should not enter our boundary. Similarly (I Kings 7:4): “an edge (מחזה מול מחזה) opposite an edge,” three times. In Tanchuma, I found [this].

text.title: And they shall exalt Him in an assembly of people:

pasuk.text: He must give thanks in the presence of ten.

text.title: and in a sitting of elders:

pasuk.text: And two of them must be rabbinical scholars.

text.title: He makes rivers into a desert:

pasuk.text: That is to say that He makes the settlements of the nations into ruins.
To be like a salty land insofar as it does not produce fruit.

text.title: He makes a desert into a pool of water:

pasuk.text: He makes a ruined settlement into a building and restores it to its original state.

text.title: Whereas they were few and they sank down:

pasuk.text: But they, from the beginning, sank down and were few because of dominion, trouble, and sorrow.

text.title: and made him families like flocks:

pasuk.text: He made [for] the needy the families of his children as numerous as flocks.
Heb. קפצה, closes up, like (Deut. 15:7): “and not close up (תקפץ) your hand.”
faithful with You.
Even my glory is what I sing to You. Another explanation:
Even according to my honor, I shall not hesitate to sing to Him, and I shall not take glory for myself.

It is the custom of other kings that the dawn awakens them, but I awaken the dawn, for I rise at midnight, when the psaltery and the harp awaken me, as our Rabbis said (Ber. 3b): A harp was suspended above David’s bed. As soon as midnight arrived, the north wind would blow on it and it would play by itself.

and one verse says (above 57:11): “is up to the heavens.” Our Rabbis explained: This one speaks of those who perform [a commandment] for its sake [i.e., for the sole purpose of obeying the Torah], and that one deals with those who perform [the commandments] with ulterior motives.
for all Your people and Your beloved ones are dependent upon me.
that I would reign and that the time would come that I would rejoice in His word.

text.title: that I would allot a portion:

pasuk.text: I shall divide the land of my enemies to Israel, like (Gen. 48:22): “one portion (שכם) more than your brethren.”
i.e., my slaves and my servants, like a utensil that people use.
my servitude, that their kings should put my shoes on my feet.
I shall raise my voice to them to frighten them.

text.title: and may He cut off their remembrance from the earth:

pasuk.text: [the remembrance] of Esau and his chieftains.
in the time of the Messiah, to stretch forth my hand upon Esau in his fortified cities?
Who led us already upon Edom, that I smote them in the Valley of Salt, eighteen thousand.

text.title: O God of my praise, be not silent:

pasuk.text: This was said regarding all Israel.

text.title: For the mouth of a wicked man:

pasuk.text: Ishmael.
for You, they hinder me.
But I pray to You constantly. I found:
I sacrifice seventy bulls every year for the seventy nations, and we request rain, yet they harm us. Shocher Tov (109:4).
before You, may he emerge from Your judgment guilty and wicked.
Heb. פקדתו, his greatness, provostie or pruvote in Old French, like (Esther 2:3): “And let the king appoint officers (פקידים).”

text.title: and [people] should ask and search from their ruins:

pasuk.text: Everyone will ask about them, what happened to So-and-so and So-and-so, because of the rumor of ruin that emerged about them. And “search” (וְדָרְשוּ) means from others, because it is vowelized with a short “kamatz,” and וְשִׁאֵלוּ also means from others, that others should ask about them. This can also be interpreted as וְשִׁאֵלוּ, of the intensive conjugation, meaning that they will go around by the doors [to beg for alms].

text.title: May a creditor search out all he has:

pasuk.text: Heb. ינקש. A person who toils and searches, and longs passionately to do something is described by the expression מִתְנַקֵשׁ, i.e., shaken and going from place to place, like (Dan. 5:6): “and his knees knocked (נקשן) against each other.”

that will come after his being cut off, his name and his fame will be blotted out so that not even a remembrance will remain of him in the mouth of the generation that is born in the world after his name will be destroyed, sa retremure in Old French, its extirpation.
The iniquity that he sinned against his forebears, to Abraham, whose life he shortened by five years, and to his father he caused blindness.

text.title: and the sin against his mother:

pasuk.text: that he destroyed her womb, and that he caused the day of her burial to be concealed from the people, lest they curse her for Esau emerged from her womb, as it is said (Gen. 35:8): “Deborah, Rebecca’s nurse, died… the Plain of Weeping.” In Greek, another is called “allon,” for Jacob had another mourning along with that of Deborah, for his mother died and they concealed her death.
[May] these iniquities [be] before the Lord constantly.

text.title: Because he did not remember to do kindness:

pasuk.text: to engage in the mourning of his father, as Jacob had made a pottage of lentils to console Isaac, for on that day Abraham had died.
Israel.
[Esau loved] the curse of the Holy One, blessed be He, Whose existence he denied.
He brought himself into a curse and was satisfied with breaking off the yoke of the sacrifice and the priestly blessing and the curse of the heathens.
[May] the curse [be to him] as an envelopment like a garment. [This] I found.
Heb. ולמזח, a girdle, and so, (Job 12:21): “and loosens the belt (מזיח) of the strong.” He loosens the belt of the strong.

text.title: Like a shadow when it lengthens:

pasuk.text: at eventide.
an expression of stirring and mixing and astonishment, like a locust, which wanders to and fro and is stirred up. [This] I found:

text.title: and enwrap themselves… like a cloak:

pasuk.text: which enwraps and envelops the entire body.

text.title: The word of the Lord to my master:

pasuk.text: Our Rabbis interpreted it as referring to Abraham our father, and I shall explain it according to their words (Mid. Ps. 110:1): The word of the Lord to Abraham, whom the world called “my master,” as it is written (Gen. 23: 6): “Hearken to us, my master.”
Wait for My salvation and hope for the Lord. [The root] ישיבה means only waiting, as Scripture states (Deut. 1:46): “And you stayed (ותשבו) in Kadesh for many days.”
For the salvation of My right hand.
Amraphel and his allies.
[This is] an expression of support, as (above 105:16): “every staff of bread.”

text.title: The staff of your might the Lord will send from Zion:

pasuk.text: When you return from the war and your men are weary and in pursuit, the Lord will send you Malchizedek, king of Salem, to bring out bread and wine (Gen. 14: 14).
in the war.

text.title: in the midst of your enemies:

pasuk.text: safely.

text.title: Your people will volunteer on the day of your host:

pasuk.text: When you gather an army to pursue them, your people and your friends will volunteer to go out with you, as we find (Gen. 14:14): “and he armed his trained men, those born in his house,” and no more; and Aner, Eshkol, and Mamre volunteered by themselves to go out to his aid.

text.title: because of the beauty of holiness when you fell from the womb:

pasuk.text: And this will be to you in the merit of the beauty of holiness that was in you from your mother’s womb, for he recognized his Creator at the age of three.

text.title: when you fell from the womb:

pasuk.text: Heb. משחר, when you fell from the womb, like (Beizah 35b): “We may let fruit down (משילין) through a skylight on a festival,” and some learn משחירין.

text.title: for you, your youth is like dew:

pasuk.text: For you will be considered your youth, the ways of uprightness with which you conducted yourself in your youth will be for you as pleasantness, like this dew, which is pleasant and comforting.

text.title: The Lord swore and will not repent:

pasuk.text: Since Abraham was afraid lest he be punished for the troops that he had killed, it was said to him (Gen. 15: 1): “Fear not, Abraham, etc.”
over the good that He spoke about you.

text.title: you are a priest forever because of the speech of Malchizedek:

pasuk.text: From you will emerge the priesthood and the kingship that your children will inherit from Shem your progenitor, the priesthood and the kingship, which were given to him. דִבְרָתִי מלכי-צדק. The “yud” is superfluous, like (Lam. 1: 1): “the city that was once so populous (רבתי).” Because of the speech of Malchizedek, because of the command of Malchizedek. You are a priest, Heb. כהן. The word כהן bears the connotation of priesthood and rulership, as (II Sam. 8:18): “and David’s sons were chief officers.”
Who was on your right hand in battle.

text.title: has crushed kings on the day of His wrath:

pasuk.text: The four kings. He…

text.title: will execute justice upon the nations [into] a heap of corpses:

pasuk.text: This is the tidings of the ‘covenant between the segments,’ [in] which was stated to him concerning Egypt (Gen. 15:14): “But also that nation whom they will serve do I judge.”

Heb. מלא, a heap of corpses. מלא is an expression of gathering, as (Jer. 12:6): “have called a gang (מלא) after you” ; (Isa. 31: 4), “although a band (מלא) of shepherds gather against him.” Now where did He execute justice, making them a heap of corpses? (Exod. 14:30), “the Egyptians dead on the seashore.”

text.title: He crushed the head on a great land:

pasuk.text: This resembles the prophecy of Habakkuk (3:12): “You have crushed the head of the house of the wicked.” [This refers to] the head of Pharaoh, who was the head and the prince of a land greater and more esteemed than all the lands, as is said (above 102:20): “a ruler of peoples [sent] and loosed his bonds,” for all the nations were under the rule of Egypt.

text.title: From the stream on the way he would drink, etc.:

pasuk.text: From the Nile River, on the way of its course, his land would drink, and it was not in need of rain water. Therefore, he would raise his head and boast (Ezek. 29:3): “My river is my own, and I made myself.” In another manner, this psalm can be explained regarding David: [1]

text.title: The word of the Lord about my master:

pasuk.text: Concerning my master, Saul, when I was pursued by him.
Heb. לאדני, about my master, as (Exod. 14:3): “Then Pharaoh will say concerning the children of (לבני) Israel” ; (Gen. 26:7), “The people of the place asked him about his wife (לאשתו).”
Stay and wait for My salvation. [2]

text.title: The staff of your might the Lord will send from Zion:

pasuk.text: The exceptional good deeds in your hand. Another explanation: You will yet reign in Zion, and there a staff of might will be sent to you, and then you will rule in the midst of your enemies. [3]

text.title: Your people will volunteer on the day of your host:

pasuk.text: The people of Israel will volunteer to your aid on the day that you form an army, as it is delineated in (I) Chronicles (12:21); that they were joining him from every tribe: “When he went to Ziklag, there deserted to him of Manasseh, etc.” ; (ibid. verse 8): “And from the Gadites there separated themselves to David, etc.”

text.title: because of the beauty of holiness when you fell from the womb:

pasuk.text: Because of the beauty of holiness that was in you from your youth.
A good youth and a good period of maturity that you had will be to you like dew, which is pleasant and sweet, and will produce fruit for you to make you prosper. [4]
that the kingdom will be yours forever.
And which of the priesthoods? A priesthood that is above the priesthood of Malchizedek, and that is the kingdom, which is above the high priesthood in thirty steps.

above the priesthood (Some mss. read: above the charge) of Malchizedek, who was a priest to the Most High God. Now if you challenge that he too was a king, [we answer that] the kingdom over the nations was not an esteemed kingdom when compared to Israel. [5]
will always be on your right hand to save you, Who…

text.title: crushed kings on the day of His wrath:

pasuk.text: Those who fought with Abraham and with Joshua and with Barak. [6]

text.title: He will execute justice upon the nations [into] a heap of corpses:

pasuk.text: And further, in the days of Hezekiah your son, He will execute justice upon the armies of Sennacherib [making them] a heap of dead corpses, and He will crush Sennacherib, who is the head of Nineveh and Assyria, which is a great land, who… [7]

text.title: From the stream on the way:

pasuk.text: he was drinking, for he boasted that his armies drank from the waters of the Jordan, as it is said (Isa. 37:25): “I dug and drank water, and I dry up, etc.”
He praised himself and boasted of his greatness.

This psalm was based on the alphabet, one letter at the beginning of the verse and one in the middle of it, and so all of them [this psalm’s verses are] from “aleph” to “tav,” and so too is the second psalm. The first one speaks in praises of the Holy One, blessed be He, and the second one speaks in praise of a righteous, God-fearing person.

He set down for Israel Sabbaths and festivals and commandments, of which was stated (Deut. 5:15): “And remember that you were a slave in the land of Egypt,” because He is gracious and merciful to His children, and He wishes to make them righteous.
Heb. טֶרֶף, food.

text.title: The strength of His works He related to His people:

pasuk.text: When He gave them the inheritance of the nations, He let them know His strength and His might. And Midrash Tanchuma (Buber, Bereishith 11): He wrote for Israel [about] the Creation to let them know that the earth is His and that it is in His power to settle in it anyone He wishes, and to move these out and settle others, so that the nations will not be able to say to Israel, “You are thieves, for you conquered the land of the seven nations.”

are His commandments, supported by might, strengthened with punishments and warnings, and the chapters are set one next to the other in sequence and to expound on them. This is what Solomon said (Song 5:15): “His thighs are pillars of marble, etc.”
which will be blessed, will be his seed.

text.title: He shone a light in the darkness:

pasuk.text: Heb. זרח [the “kal” conjugation], like הזריח, [the “hiph’il” or causative conjugation]. Its midrashic interpretation is that He Himself, so to speak, becomes a light for them, as (above 27:1): “The Lord is my light and my salvation.”

text.title: Good is the man who is gracious, etc.:

pasuk.text: who is gracious to the poor and lends [to] them, and is not strict, saying, “I cannot afford it,” but [instead] his things, which he needs for himself, in food, drink, and clothing, he conducts with moderation and with a measure, and he spares his property.
His heart is faithful to His Maker.
He leans on and trusts in the Holy One, blessed be He.

text.title: A wicked man will see and become angry:

pasuk.text: Heb. וכעס, an expression of a verb in the past tense, equivalent to ויכעס [i.e., the “vav” converts the past tense to the future]. Therefore, it is vowelized half with a “kamatz” and half with a “pattah,” and the accent is at the end of the word.

text.title: Who is like the Lord, our God:

pasuk.text: in heaven and earth, who dwells on high and lowers His eyes to see? מושיבי, להושיבי, מקימי, משפילי, מגביהי, all have a superfluous “yud.”

text.title: the barren woman of the house:

pasuk.text: Zion, which is like a barren womanHe will seat her.

text.title: as a happy mother of children:

pasuk.text: (Isa. 66:8): “that Zion both experienced birth pangs and bore her children.”

text.title: a people of a strange tongue:

pasuk.text: With another language, which is not the Holy Tongue. A similar expression is (Isa. 33:19): “A people of a strange tongue you shall not see, a people of speech too obscure, etc.” The “nun” and the “lammed” are interchangeable, like נִשְׁכָּה, chamber, which is [equivalent to] לִשְׁכָּה, in the Book of Ezra (Neh. 13:7).

He took Judah as the lot of His portion and His sanctity, and even they sanctified His name when they descended into the sea, as the matter that is stated (above 68: 28): “the princes of Judah pelt them with stones.” Similarly, this verse is explained in the Aggadah (Mid. Ps. 114:8): Judah became His holy people, for Nahshon sprang into the sea and said, “I shall descend first,” and that is what [the Psalmist] says: Judah became His holy people.
because all the water of Creation split.
Heb. חולי, Who created the earth. The “yud” is superfluous as מגביהי, משפילי and ההוֹפכי.
Heb. למעינו. The “vav” is superfluous, as the “vav” in (above 104:11, 20) “the beasts (חיתו) of the forest.”
Not for us or for the fitness of our deeds shall You do [this] for us.

text.title: but for Your name give honor:

pasuk.text: So that they should not say, “Where is their God now?”
Heb. ימישון, an expression of (Gen. 27:12): “Perhaps my father will feel me (ימשני).”
These are the proselytes.

text.title: I wished that the Lord would hear my voice:

pasuk.text: So did David say after Saul’s demise, when he became king, “Return, my soul, to your resting place, for the Lord has bestowed kindness upon you.” And to You, my Master, I pine, for You extricated my soul from death.

text.title: I wished that the Lord would hear:

pasuk.text: Heb. אהבתי, I wished (תאבתי) that God would hear my voice.

text.title: and I shall call out in my days:

pasuk.text: In the days of my distress I shall call Him, and in the days of my redemption I shall praise Him.
Heb. חבלי, bands of enemies who sought to kill me. [The expressions] חבלי מות, שאוֹל חבלי, are all an expression of bands, like (I Sam. 10:5): “a band of (חבל) prophets.”

text.title: in the lands of the living:

pasuk.text: The land of Israel, for my enemies and my pursuers chased me out of it in the days of Saul, and against their will, I returned.

text.title: I believed so that I spoke:

pasuk.text: I believed the words of Ziba which he spoke about Mephibosheth, so that I should say (II Sam. 16:4), “Behold, all that belongs to Mephibosheth is yours.” Then I humbled myself exceedingly. I had spoken harshly, and I submitted myself to you [Mephibosheth].
to flee from before Absalom.

Heb. כזב, [meaning that one] betrays his friend, for I saw my son betray me and seek my life, and [I saw] all Israel repay me with evil for good; therefore, I believed Ziba and said that Mephibosheth also lies and betrays me. Every expression of כָּזָב is purely an expression of lack of trust that they trusted in him; falenze in Old French, betrayal, deceit, like (Isa. 58:11): “whose water does not fail (יכזבו).” Others interpret it:
at the Rock of the Divisions, when Saul and his men were encircling me and my men, to seize me, and there it says (I Sam. 23:26): “and David was hastening to get away.”
Even the prophet Samuel, who is faithful as a prophet, even he is a deceiver, for he anointed me king.

text.title: I shall lift up a cup of salvations:

pasuk.text: I shall bring the libations for the thanksgiving offerings that I vowed, as he says, “To You I shall slaughter a thanksgiving offering,” and on that cup I shall call out about this salvation, for the Levite does not recite a song unless over the wine [libations].

text.title: in the presence of all His people:

pasuk.text: Heb. נגדה, in the presence of (נגד) all His people.

text.title: Difficult in the eyes of the Lord:

pasuk.text: The Holy One, blessed be He, showed me that it is a difficult thing and heavy in His eyes to kill His pious ones.
המותה, the death (המות) , [the final “hey” being superfluous] like (Gen. 39: 11, 12): “into the house (הביתה) … outside (החוצה).”

text.title: Your servant the son of Your maidservant:

pasuk.text: There is no comparison between the training of a slave who was bought in the market and one who was born to a maidservant in the house.
You untied from my neck the bars and the thongs.
Sacrifices of thanksgiving for the miracles that You performed for me.
The sacrifices that I vowed.
Heb. בתוככי, like בְּתוֹכֵ.

text.title: For His kindness has overwhelmed us:

pasuk.text: That is to say: and surely we [must praise Him], for His kindness has overwhelmed us.

text.title: and the truth of the Lord is eternal:

pasuk.text: For He kept His promise that He promised the Patriarchs.

pasuk.title: Give thanks to the Lord, etc.:

pasuk.text: because His kindness is eternal.

These are the Levites, about whom it is written (Exod. 32:26): “Whoever is the Lord’s, let him come to me! And all the sons of Levi gathered around him,” in the episode of the [Golden] Calf, and they fought with Israel when they said (Num. 14:4), “Let us appoint a leader and return to Egypt.”

text.title: It is better to take shelter in the Lord:

pasuk.text: Heb. לחסות. This shelter (חסיון) is only an expression of the shelter of a shadow, a small thing. Trust (מבטח) is a stout and strong support. Nevertheless, to take shelter in the Lord is better than the promises of human beings.
This speaks about the war of Gog and Magog, when all the nations will be there, as it is said (Zech. 14:2): “And I shall gather all the nations to Jerusalem to wage war.”
Heb. אמלים, I shall cut them off, an expression of (above 90:6): “it is cut off (ימולל) and withers.”

text.title: they were extinguished like a thorn fire:

pasuk.text: Every expression of דעיכה coincides with an expression of springing and skipping. It hastens to spring and skip from its place. Therefore, it fits with an expression of fire or with an expression of water, like (Job 6:17): “they jump (נדעכו) from their place.” Similarly (Job 17:1), “my days flicker (נדעכו) ” ; similarly (Job 18:6), “and his candle that is over him shall go out (ידעך),” in the way that the flame springs from the wick and ascends upward when it is extinguished.
You, my enemy.

text.title: The might and the cutting power of God was my salvation:

pasuk.text: Heb. עזי וזמרת, the might of the Holy One, blessed be He, was my salvation. עזי has a superfluous “yud” because we do not [usually] find עזי vowelized with a short “kamatz” instead of a “shuruk,” except in three places, where it is next to וזמרת, and perforce is attached to the word denoting the name of God. You cannot explain it as “my praise.” Do not wonder about ויהי לי, that he did not say היה לי לישועה, for there are many like these in Scripture, [e.g.] (Exod. 9:21): “And whoever did not pay attention… left (ויעזב) his slaves, etc.” He should have written עַזָב.

text.title: A voice of singing praises and salvation:

pasuk.text: will in the future be in the tents of the righteous, and what is that voice of singing praises? “The right hand of the Lord deals valiantly.” They will sing, “The right hand of the Lord is exalted, etc.”

text.title: The right hand of the Lord is exalted:

pasuk.text: The Midrash Aggadah states: The Holy One, blessed be He, created the celestial beings with His right hand; therefore, death has no power over them; as it says (Isa. 48:13): “Even my hand laid the foundation of the earth.” This is the left hand. “And My right hand measured the heavens with handbreadths.” This is the right hand. Similarly, the Psalmist says: “The right hand of the Lord is exalted,” that created those [that are] in the heights of the world. That is the right hand of the Lord that will make armies of righteous men in the future, and also with it [the right hand] He will resurrect them and they will live forever. And then, I shall not die, but I shall live forever.
I, the congregation of Israel, [shall not die] like the other peoples an eternal death, but I shall live, etc.
in exile, and there all my iniquities were expiated, and You did not deliver me to death.

text.title: Open for me the gates of righteousness:

pasuk.text: And these are the gates of righteousness.
of the Temple, which is the Lord’s, and the righteous will enter therein and there…

text.title: I shall thank You because You answered me:

pasuk.text: from the exile.

text.title: The stone that the builders rejected:

pasuk.text: A people that was humble among the peoples.
So will everyone say.

text.title: Blessed be he who has come in the name of the Lord:

pasuk.text: They will say to those who bring the first fruits and to those who perform the pilgrimages.
we have blessed you.

The sacrifices and the festival offerings, which were clean and examined for a blemish, they would bind to the feet of their beds until they brought them to the Temple court at the corners of the altar. It is also possible to interpret the entire end of this psalm from (verse 17), “I shall not die but I shall live,” as referring to David himself: [18]
For the episode of Bath sheba with torments, e.g. (II Sam. 12:6): “And the ewe-lamb he shall repay fourfold.” David was stricken with zaraath for six months.

text.title: but He has not delivered me to death:

pasuk.text: (II Sam. 13) “Also the Lord has removed your sin; you shall not die.” [19]

text.title: Open for me the gates of righteousness:

pasuk.text: And these are the gates of righteousnessthose gates of synagogues and study halls, which are the Lord’sand the righteous enter through them. [21]

text.title: I shall thank You because You have answered me:

pasuk.text: From here on, David, Samuel, Jesse, and David’s brothers recited this, as is delineated in [the chapter entitled] “The eves of Passovers,” (Pes. 119a). He who said this did not say the other.

text.title: Not only have they committed no injustice:

pasuk.text: They are praiseworthy if all this is in them.

Although they committed no injustice, their reward is incomplete unless they walked in His ways. And so he says (above 43: 15): “Shun evil and do good.” Even though you shun evil, everything is not complete unless you do good. Midrash Aggadah.

text.title: My prayers are that my ways should be established:

pasuk.text: Heb. אחלי. The “aleph” is a radical that is sometimes dropped, like the “aleph” in (Job 13:17): “and my speech (ואחותי) in your ears,” and the “aleph” of (II Kings 4:2): “a jug (אסוך) of oil.”

These prayers of mine are that my ways should be established Likewise (II Kings 5:3): “The supplications (אחלי) for my master should be that he go before the prophet who is in Samaria, etc.” The supplications of those who pray should be that he go before the prophet who is in Samaria, and it is an expression of wishes, souhait in French, as a person says, “If only I were a prophet and a sage.”
I did not allow myself to forget it.
Heb. אשתעשע, I shall engage, like (Isa. 17:7): “man shall turn to his Maker” ; (Exod. 5:9) “and let them not engage (ישעו) in useless things.”
A thing with which I shall be able to live, through the bestowal of your kindness.
Hidden things in it, which are not explained therein.
Wonders from the explanations of your Torah which are not explained therein.

text.title: I am a stranger in the land:

pasuk.text: for a short time.

text.title: do not hide Your commandments from me:

pasuk.text: The hidden ones, so that I should be able to fulfill them, for if not now, when?

Heb. גרסה. My soul breaks because of longing, as (Lev. 2:14): “crushed kernels (גרשׂ) of the fresh ears.” Menachem (p. 183), however, associated “from longing” (לתאבה) with (Amos 6:8) “I destroy (מתאב) the pride of Jacob,” and both are an expression of breaking.
Heb. גל, an expression of rolling, like (Gen. 29:10): “and he rolled (ויגל) the stone.”
Although the kings of the heathens scorn me because I engage in the Torah.
to You, [of] my needs and my sin, and You answered me.
Heb. דלפה, drips; i.e., it is becoming less and less.
I applied myself to your judgments and I clung to your testimony, to choose the way of faith. Therefore, I ask, “Remove from me the way of falsehood.”

text.title: and I shall keep it at every step:

pasuk.text: Heb. עקב. I shall keep it in all its paths and the steps of its paths, an expression of “heels” (עקבים) , traces in French, footsteps.

text.title: Fulfill for Your servant Your word:

pasuk.text: that You promised me.
That I and my children shall fear Your name, for on that condition You promised me (I Kings 2:4): “if your children take heed in their way, etc.”
Forgive me for that sin [with Bath-sheba], and my enemies will no longer be able to disgrace me with it.
and I already accept upon myself “to repay the ewe-lamb fourfold.”
May Your salvation befall me according to Your word which You promised me.

text.title: And do not take… from my mouth a word of truth:

pasuk.text: Heb. תצל. Do not separate from my mouth a word of truth, as (Gen. 31:9): “And God separated (ויצל) your father’s property and gave it to me.” I found this.
in all my instructions [regarding ritual law] and in all my legal decisions, that I should not stumble over them.

text.title: And I shall walk in widely accepted ways:

pasuk.text: in the halachah that is widely accepted and widespread in Israel.
through which You gave me hope, through Nathan the prophet to your servant.
that You bring sufferings and You repent of your anger and forgive. Therefore, I was consoled.
At a time of distress and darkness.
A crown that fits me [was given] to me as a testimony and to my children who are fit to reign, as a reward for my having kept Your precepts. So did the Sages of Israel explain it. I found this:
the fulfillment of your words, with which You gave me hope, in that You are my portion.
Heb. חליתי, from the expression of (Lam. 3: 24): “‘The Lord is my portion,’ says my soul; ‘therefore, I will hope (אוחיל) to Him.’”

The loss of a commandment as compared to its gain, and the gain of a transgression as compared to its loss. Therefore, “I returned my feet to Your testimonies,” because I saw that it [Your way] is the best of all of them.

text.title: Bands of wicked men robbed me:

pasuk.text: Heb. עודני. Bands of wicked men plundered me, like (Gen. 49:27): “in the morning he will eat plunder (עד).” In this manner, Menachem (p. 131) associated it. It may also be interpreted as an expression of עוֹד, more, i.e., increased and outnumbered me.

to You about Your commandments, before I uttered them in the study halls, I erred in them and sinned. But now that I have recited them, I kept your Torah, for study teaches me to turn away from sin: therefore, I beg of You, “Teach me the best of reason and knowledge.”

Heb. אענה, an expression of studying and reciting in the study hall, like (verse 172): “My tongue will utter (תען) Your word.” Similarly (Mal. 2:12): “From the man who commits it, the Lord shall cut off one of acuity or erudition (ועונה) from the tents of Jacob.” An ingenious one among the sages, and one who can answer among the students.

text.title: Willful sinners have heaped false accusations upon me:

pasuk.text: Heb. טפלו, they joined upon me, and similarly (Job 14:17): “and You have attached Yourself (ותטפל) to my iniquity.”

text.title: It is good for me that I was afflicted:

pasuk.text: That I was chastised and afflicted in order that I repent of the evil way and keep Your statutes. In other commentaries I found the following:

text.title: It is good for me that I was afflicted, etc.:

pasuk.text: It appeared good to me when I suffered privations in order to learn Your statutes, when I learned the Torah in pain.

text.title: Those who fear You will see me:

pasuk.text: in prosperity and rejoice, because what was bestowed upon me will be bestowed upon them, for I am among those who fear You, and I hoped for Your word.
With justice, You afflicted me.

For no reason they condemned me. (I found:) I say that this deals with the embarrassment [of David] when they would say to him, “If one is intimate with a married woman, with what [method] is his death penalty?” when he [David] had not sinned.

text.title: May those who fear You… return to me:

pasuk.text: For the Sanhedrin separated from him when he became a mezora because of that iniquity [with Bath- sheba]. Even if she was divorced, whoever puts his eyes on her, anyone who touches her, will not be guiltless.
Heb. כלתה, desires.
Heb. כלו, lit. fail. My eyes look constantly until they fail.
Like a flask of skin that dries in smoke.
that I might see it in my days.

text.title: Willful sinners have dug pits for me:

pasuk.text: Those who come to disqualify me do not do so according to the Torah.
A Moabite and not a Moabitess; but they pursue [me] to prohibit me [from entering the congregation of the Lord].
My enemies pursued me in vain.

I was on the earth as nothing, but I stood with my strength. Likewise (verse 95): “Concerning me, the wicked hoped to destroy me” from entering the congregation, and so (above 116:16): “You loosed my thongs.”
to search them and to debate about them.
To every conclusion of a thing there is an end and a boundary, but Your commandments have no end or boundary to their conclusion.

text.title: Each of Your commandments makes me wiser than my enemies:

pasuk.text: Concerning Doeg and Ahithophel they [the Rabbis] said that their final conclusions did not agree with adopted practice. The secret of the Torah is in my hands forever, for I gained understanding from all my teachers; I learned a little from this one and I learned a little from that one (after I learned from my distinguished teacher).
All my conversation was about them.
Heb. כלאתי, I restrained, as (I Sam. 25: 33): “who have restrained me (כלתני) this day from coming into bloodshed.”

text.title: Your words are a lamp for my foot:

pasuk.text: When I come to promulgate a decision of law, I look in the Torah and it separates me from [transgressing] the prohibition, like a lamp which saves a man from [falling into] the pits.

Heb. נעניתי, I have been made poor and humble, like (Exod. 10): “to humble Yourself from before Me” ; (Hos. 5: 5), “And the pride of Israel shall be humbled before them,” which Jonathan renders: וימא. And a poor man is accounted as dead. Therefore, revive me according to Your words.
Heb. נעניתי. This is a sickness that deranges the mind, and it is called עֲוִית convulsion, in the language of the Mishnah (Chul. 60b).

text.title: The freewill offering of my mouth:

pasuk.text: Words of appeasement that my mouth offers You. Every נדבה, is an expression of appeasement.

text.title: My soul is constantly in my hand:

pasuk.text: I have very often been in serious danger, close to death, but nonetheless, I have not forgotten Your Torah (following the pattern of “Whoever has a headache should engage in the Torah”).
On their paths and their roads.

text.title: I hate those who harbor iniquitous thoughts:

pasuk.text: Those who think thoughts of iniquity, like (Job 20:2): “Therefore, my thoughts (סעפי) answer me” ; (I Kings 18:21), “between two ideas (הסעפים).” When you read סְעִפִים, it concerns the thought, but when you read סֵעֲפִים, the language refers to those who think it.

text.title: and I shall constantly engage in Your statutes:

pasuk.text: Heb. ואשעה, and I shall engage, like (Exod. 5:9): “and let them not engage (ישעו) in useless things.” Another explanation: [It is] an expression of telling and reciting, as we translate (Deut. 28:37): “and a recitation (ולשועין).”
Heb. סלית, You trampled; You made them a thing trampled on, like (Lam. 1:15): “The Lord trampled (סלה) all my mighty men.”
Heb. סמר, like (Job 4:15): “it made the hair of my flesh stand on end (מסמר),” as a person whose hair stands on end, harizer in Old French, se herisser in modern French, to bristle.
The retribution for Your decrees.
Heb. ערב, garantis in French, to vouch for. Be a guarantor for me against the evil (i.e., be a guarantor that I keep Your precepts).

text.title: and for the word of Your righteousness:

pasuk.text: The promise that You promised me.

text.title: revive me according to Your word:

pasuk.text: Just as You promised me good, through Nathan the prophet.

text.title: A time to do for the Lord, etc.:

pasuk.text: This goes back to the verse preceding it: Enable me to understand, and I shall know Your testimonies, to know a time to do for Your name. What should they do, those who made Your Torah void, to find good will and forgiveness, and that You should be found by them, and I will do so for every transgression that I have committed. Our Rabbis, however, derived from it [from this verse] that we may transgress the words of the Torah in order to make a fence and a wall [a safeguard] for Israel, e.g. Gideon and Elijah on Mount Carmel, who sacrificed on high places (Ber. 63a). I saw [it] further expounded upon in the Aggadah (Yerushalmi Ber. 9:4, Mid. Sam 1: 1) as meaning: A person who is idle and leisurely, who devotes [only occasional] times to his Torah, makes void the covenant, for an idle person must toil in the Torah all hours of the day.

Heb. על-כן. Because I loved Your commandments, it is fitting that You teach me a time of good will, and what I should do for You that You should accept me. There are many [instances of] על-כן that are to be interpreted as “because” ; e. g., (Gen. 33:10): “because (כי על-כן) I have seen your face” ; (Num. 10:33).“because (כי על-כן) you know our encampment” ; (Isa. 15: 7), “Because of (כי על-כן) the many things they did.”

text.title: Because I considered all precepts of all things upright:

pasuk.text: All precepts, everything that You commanded in your Torah.
Heb. ישרתי. They were upright in my eyes, and I said about them that they are upright. Because of this, I deserve that You forgive me and favor me.
They are covered, and your testimonies are hidden from the sons of men. There are easy commandments for which He gave a large reward, such as sending away the nest.
All of them, because it is not known which is better.

text.title: The commencement of Your words enlightens:

pasuk.text: The beginning of your words enlightened the heart of Israel, that You understated the simple, by Your statement (Exod. 20:2): “I am… Who took you out.” You let them know the favor that You did for themthat You acquired them from the house of bondageto know that You are their Master, and they should accept Your kingdom upon themselves. (Exod. 20:3): “You shall not have another god, etc.” and afterwards You made Your decrees (Cf. Mechilta ad loc.). Another explanation:

text.title: The commencement of Your words enlightens:

pasuk.text: The beginning of Your words in the Creation was (Gen. 1:3): “Let there be light.”
From there, everyone will understand and will commence with words of Torah. Tanchuma (Vayakhel 6).
Heb. ואשאפה, an expression of swallowing, as (Jer. 2:24): “snuffs up (שאפה) the wind.”

text.title: Redeem me from the oppression of man:

pasuk.text: From the evil inclination, which oppresses the people (from the good pathParshandatha). In other commentaries I found:

text.title: Redeem me from the oppression of man:

pasuk.text: Redeem me so that no man oppress me.
Heb. קנאתי. The zeal with which I am zealous for Your name against those who forget Your words, cuts me and incenses me against them.

As it is stated (I Sam. 17:14): “And David was the youngest.” I am despised to the extent that I humble myself beside those who engage in the Torah, to learn, for I have not forgotten Your precepts; [nor have I refrained] from searching and debating with them about Your righteousness that is within them [the precepts], which is righteousness and truth to eternity; and even though troubles have befallen me, they were my occupation. And forever enable me to understand their righteousness and I shall live by them (Deut. 30:20): “for it [the Torah] is your life and the length of your days.”
(The acronym of, עֵדְוֹתֶי is דמה בן פֶרֶץ; the “vav” is vowelized with a “holam,” but in the other instances, it is עֵדֹתֶי; the “daleth” is vowelized with a “holam.”)

Half the night, two watches, and according to one who says that the night consists of three watches, David would rise from bed at the first third of the night and engage in Torah until midnight, as it is said: “to speak of Your word.” From midnight on, he would engage in songs and praises, as it is said (verse 62): “At midnight, I rise to give thanks to You.”

text.title: Pursuers of lewdness have drawn near:

pasuk.text: a counsel of sins. They follow the counsel of their sins and distance themselves from your Torah to draw near to the counsel of their evil.
to these faraway people, who distance themselves from Your Torah, if they repent of their way.

text.title: From before, I knew from Your testimonies:

pasuk.text: Before the thing came about, I knew it from Your testimonies. Before they inherited the land, You commanded them about the first fruits, heave offerings, and tithes, and before You gave them rest from their enemies, You commanded them (Deut. 25:19): “And it will be, when the Lord Your God gives you rest, etc.” to appoint a king, to annihilate Amalek, and to build the Temple.
For You established Your testimonies concerning all things destined to be until the end of the world.

text.title: The beginning of Your word is true:

pasuk.text: And the end of Your word is not true? Rather, the end of Your word proves that the beginning of Your word is true. For, when the nations heard, “I am the Lord your God,” and “You shall not have [another god],” and “You shall not take, etc.,” they said, “Everything is for His benefit and for His glory.” As soon as they heard, “Honor, etc.; You shall not murder; You shall not commit adultery,” they admitted [that they had erred] about the beginning of Your word, that it is true.

Over Your promise that You promised me. Another explanation: Over one of Your enigmatic statements, when I understand it. Our Rabbis, however, interpreted it as referring to circumcision, for [when] David was in the bathhouse and saw himself without zizith, without tefillin, and without Torah, he said, “Woe is to me, for I am naked of all commandments.” As soon as he thought of the circumcision, he rejoiced and said when he emerged (from the bathhouse), “I rejoice over Your word.” [This refers to] circumcision, which was first given with a saying (אמירה), and not with speaking (דיבור) , as it is said (Gen. 17:9): “And God said (ויאמר) to Abraham, ‘And you shall keep My covenant.’”
In the morning, twice before the reading of “Shema” and once after it, and in the evening, twice before it and twice after it.
For the reading of the Shema, which consists of words of Torah.

text.title: for all my ways are before You:

pasuk.text: You know all my ways.

text.title: according to Your word, enable me to understand:

pasuk.text: the words of Your Torah; according to their law and in the order in which they stand.
will speak.

Heb. תען. Every [expression of] עַנִיָה is an expression of a loud voice, and the “father” of them all is (Deut. 27:14): “And the Levites shall proclaim (וענו) and say [to all Israel with a loud voice].”

which the Levites will recite on the fifteen steps that go down from the Israelites’ court to the Women’s court, and there are fifteen psalms entitled “A song of ascents” (Suc. 5:4, Mid 2:5). And our Rabbis said that David composed them to raise the deep, as is explained in Tractate Succah (53a). And according to the Aggadah (Yerushalmi Sanh. 10:2, 52b), it is to be interpreted: A song for a hundred steps (שיר למאה עולות).
The arm of those who hunt people with their mouth with wicked accusations.
[What can] the Holy One, blessed be He [give you]?

text.title: and what can He add to you:

pasuk.text: [What] safeguard and walls? Behold you are placed within two walls.

text.title: Sharpened arrows of a mighty man:

pasuk.text: Behold you kill in a distant place like an arrow.

All coals, when extinguished on the outside, are extinguished on the inside, but these extinguish themselves on the outside but not on the inside (ibid.). Another explanation: What will He give you? What is the Holy One, blessed be He, destined to decree upon you? Arrows of a mighty man with coals of brooms. His arrows from above and Gehinnom from below.
says the congregation of Israel, for I have already suffered in many exiles. Behold I sojourned in Meshech with the sons of Japheth in the kingdom of Persia, Greece, and Meshech.
With them.
peacefully with them, they come to wage war with me.
The simple meaning is that when the Levites began to ascend the steps, they recited this song. Although this song is not written first, there is no chronological sequence.) (In other books I found:

[The Psalmist] alludes, in the second psalm, to the steps that ascend for the righteous in the future from beneath the tree of life to the Throne of Glory, as we learned in Sifrei (Ekev 47): “It does not say here, ‘A song of ascents’ but, ‘A song for ascents’; a song for the One Who is destined to make ascents for the righteous in the future.” This is what the Kalir established (in the concluding poem of the morning service for the second day of Succoth, which was composed by Rabbi Elazar the son of Rabbi Simon the son of Yochai in Chagigah, chapter “We may not expound,” see there): “And from beneath them thirty steps, one above the other until the Throne of Glory, flying and ascending with the pleasant speech of the song of ascents.”

text.title: I rejoiced when they said to me:

pasuk.text: I heard people saying, “When will that old man die, and his son Solomon reign and build the Temple, and we shall go up on the festival pilgrimages?” And I am happy.
in battle everywhere because of the gates of Jerusalem, where they were engaged in Torah.
When my son Solomon builds the Temple within it [Jerusalem], it will be built with the Shechinah, the Temple, the Ark, and the altar.

text.title: is like a city that was joined together within itself:

pasuk.text: Like Shiloh, for Scripture compared them to one another, as it is said (Deut. 12:9): “to the rest and to the inheritance.” The rest is Shiloh. The inheritance is Jerusalem (see Sifrei Re’eh 66). And our Rabbis said (Ta’an. 5a): There is a Jerusalem in heaven, and the Jerusalem on earth is destined to be like it.
For there in Shiloh the tribes ascended when they went up from Egypt, and the Tabernacle was established in its midst.

Heb. י-ָהּ, which is testimony to Israel, for the heathens were talking about them when they left Egypt, and they would say about them that they were the offspring of adulterous unions. If the Egyptians ruled over their own bodies, surely [they ruled] over their wives. Said the Holy One, blessed be He, “I attest that they are the sons of their fathers.” He bestowed His name upon them: the Reubenites (הראובני), the Simeonites (השמעוני) (Num. 26). He added the letters of the name, one on this side and one on that side. The result is that this name י-ָהּ is testimony to Israel.

text.title: For there were set thrones, etc.:

pasuk.text: For also in Jerusalem the Shechinah will rest, and thrones will sit there upon which to judge the nations, and the royal thrones of the house of David.
and say to her, “May those who love you enjoy tranquility, and let there be peace in your wall.”
Israel, my brethren and my companions
I, King David, [shall now speak] of peace in you.
Heb. הישבי.The “yud” is superfluous.
[With] the ridicule of the complacent heathens we are sated.
that they despised the valley of doves, which is Jerusalem.
Heb. לגאיונים. It is written as one word and read as two.

text.title: when their anger was kindled against us:

pasuk.text: Heb. בחרות, “when their anger was kindled against us,” is the same form as בעשות, “when he made.”
Heb. נחלה, Hehhhhddan expression of illness (חלי).

text.title: Our soul escaped like a bird:

pasuk.text: [It escaped] from them like a bird that escaped from the hunter’s snare.

text.title: Those who trust in the Lord:

pasuk.text: will not falter, like Mount Zion, which will not falter, for just as Jerusalem is surrounded by mountains, so is the Holy One, blessed be He, around His people.

text.title: For the rod of wickedness will not rest on the lot of the righteous:

pasuk.text: For the Holy One, blessed be He, will not allow the rule of the wicked to rest on the righteous because the righteous are careful not to stretch out their hand in wrongdoing.

text.title: and those who turn their crooked ways:

pasuk.text: on the people to find wicked accusationsmay the Lord lead them away with the workers of iniquity.

text.title: When the Lord returns the returnees to Zion:

pasuk.text: from the Babylonian exile, we were like dreamers.

Like rivulets in arid land, which moisten it, so shall we be moistened [freshened] when You return [us from] our captivity, for those who sow in an arid land, with tears, worrying that it will not grow, reap with song through the rivulets of water, when they are directed into it [that land].

text.title: He will go along weeping, etc.:

pasuk.text: So do Israel in exile sow charity in tears, and they will reap it when You pay their reward in the future.

text.title: A song of ascents about Solomon:

pasuk.text: This song David recited about his son, Solomon, for he saw through the holy spirit that he [Solomon] was destined to build the Temple, and on that very day, Solomon would marry Pharaoh’s daughter, and concerning this was said (Jer. 32:31): “For this city has aroused My anger and My wrath since the day they built it.” Therefore, he recited this song. My son, why should you build a house and turn away from following the Omnipresent? Since He does not desire it, its workers have toiled at it in vain.

text.title: [its] watcher keeps his vigil in vain:

pasuk.text: The watchman watches it in vain.
The craftsmen, who rise early and stay late at their work and sustain themselves with toil and labor, with bread of toil, [i.e.,] of the toil of work.
The Holy One, blessed be He, [will give] sustenance to him who banishes his sleep from his eyes in order to engage in the Torah.
Heb. לידידו שנא. to one who banishes (מנדד) sleep from his eyes.

text.title: Behold, the heritage of the Lord:

pasuk.text: for that man [who banishes sleep from his eyes].
These are the disciples whom he sets up, who are to him like sons.

text.title: the reward is the fruit of the innards:

pasuk.text: The reward is the fruit of the Torah that is in his heart as it is said (Prov. 22:18): “For it is pleasant that you guard them in your innards.”

text.title: Like arrows in the hand of a mighty man:

pasuk.text: with which to battle his enemies.

text.title: so are the sons of one’s youth:

pasuk.text: The disciples that a man sets up in his youth.

text.title: Praiseworthy is the man who has filled his quiver:

pasuk.text: with those arrows. אשפה is the arrowcase, called cuyvre in Old French.

text.title: they will not be ashamed when they talk to the enemies in the gate:

pasuk.text: Torah scholars who defeat one another in halachah and appear as enemies to one another (addendum).

text.title: A song of ascents. Praiseworthy is every man who fears the Lord:

pasuk.text: All of these are admonitions and disciplines. Because it is written, “Praiseworthy is the man”, “Praiseworthy is a man,” it therefore says here “every,” to include a woman.

text.title: If… the toil of your hands:

pasuk.text: He who benefits from the toil of his hands inherits two worlds. In Tractate Berachoth (8a).
Every woman whose blood is abundant will have many children.

text.title: in the innermost parts of your house:

pasuk.text: Because it is customary to have marital relations in secret. Another explanation:
If your wife is menstruating, put her into the innermost parts of your house so that you will not become accustomed to being with her.

text.title: your sons will be like olive shoots:

pasuk.text: Just as olive trees cannot be grafted, so will your sons not have any disqualification.
which is the gate of heaven. Moreover, in the merit of Zion they would be fruitful and multiply, as it is written (I Kings 4: 20): “Judah and Israel [were] many.”
And you shall rejoice with all the good.

text.title: And may you see children [born] to your children:

pasuk.text: and they shall not come to quarrel about halitzah, [since that is performed only if there are no children,] and then there will be peace upon Israel (addendum).
They will inherit the estate, and no woman will be subject to the levir [in a levirate marriage]. Then there will be peace in the world.

text.title: the plowmen… they lengthened their furrow:

pasuk.text: That is the hill of the plowshare, as (I Sam. 13:14): “about half a furrow (מענה) [which] a yoke [of oxen plow in] a field.”

text.title: which, before it is plucked, withers:

pasuk.text: Which, before they pluck it and uproot it from its place, is withered.
Like (Isa. 49:22): “and they will bring your sons in [their] arms (בחצן) ,” aisselle in French, and so (Neh. 5:13): “Also I shook out my arm (חצני).”
You did not give permission to an agent to forgive, as it is said (Exod. 23:21): “for he will not forgive your transgression.”

text.title: in order that You be feared:

pasuk.text: for this, so that no man will rely on the forgiveness of another. (I found this.)

text.title: I hoped, O Lord; yea, my soul hoped:

pasuk.text: one hope after another hope, similar to (above 27:14): “Hope for the Lord, be strong and He will give your heart courage, and hope,” and similar to “among those who await the morning, those who await the morning.”

text.title: My soul is to the Lord among those who await the morning:

pasuk.text: I am among those who look forward to the redemption.
They look forward and repeatedly look forward for one end after another end. (I found this.)

text.title: my heart was not haughty, etc.:

pasuk.text: I did not behave with superiority. I did not make great things pleasures, buildings, and plantings as my son made. Behold I am with You like one who has no hands or feet, like an incomplete form lying before You.
my soul upon You, like a suckling who is placed upon his mother. גָמוּל is one who sucks the breasts.

text.title: like a suckling was my soul with me:

pasuk.text: My soul within me was before You as an infant sucking its mother’s breasts.

text.title: A song of ascents. Remember, O Lord, onto David all his affliction:

pasuk.text: The affliction of his soul, how he worked and toiled to find a place for You.
Until it will be known where the place of His sanctuary will be. (I found this.)
The tidings.
In the most esteemed and superior place, like (I Sam. 1:1): “the son of Toku, the son of Zuph, an Ephrathite,” an important person, a palace dweller. Another explanation:

In the Book of Joshua (ch. 15), who came from Ephraim. In all the boundaries he says, “And the border went up… and the border circled,” but here he says, “And the border went up by the valley of the son of Hinnon… Jerusalem.” Jerusalem is [therefore] found to be higher than all the lands, and it is fit for the Temple, as it is said (Deut. 17:8): “and you shall arise and ascend to the place, etc.” This teaches [us] that the Temple is higher than the whole land of Israel. So it is expounded upon in tractate Zevahim (54b).

text.title: we found it in the fields of the forest:

pasuk.text: In the boundary of Benjamin, who was likened to a beast of the forest, as it is said (Gen. 49: 27): “Benjamin is a devouring wolf.”
there to His Tabernacles.

text.title: turn not away the face of Your anointed:

pasuk.text: Solomon, when he comes to place the Ark therein.

text.title: and this, My testimony, which I shall teach them:

pasuk.text: This which I shall teach them.
its food.
Heb. יציץ, which shine, like (Ezek. 1:7): “and they sparkled (ונצצים) like the color of burnished copper.”

text.title: Behold how good and how pleasant it is for brothers also to dwell together:

pasuk.text: When the Holy One, blessed be He, will dwell in the Temple with Israel, who are called brothers and friends, and He too will be together with them.
with which Aaron the priest was anointed.

from his head to his beard, to the mouth of his tunic, for the beard rests on the mouth of the tunic. So is the dew of Hermon, which is high, pleasant on the mountains of Zion. Just as the anointing oil is for greatness, so is the dew of Zion for glory and distinction for Israel. Just as the good oil is so, so is the dew of Hermon. Like this, so is that, like (Isa. 24:2): “as with the people, so with the priest.” Our Rabbis explained “for brothers to dwell” as cmemeoncerning Moses and Aaron, regarding unlawful use of the anointment oil, in tractate Horioth (12a) the entire psalm. But [there is], in words of Torah and post-Mosaic Scriptures, an allegory and a figure, and [in the] words of the wise and their riddles, but the primary meaning of the song of ascents is that it was said regarding the Temple.

text.title: He made lightning for the rain:

pasuk.text: They are the flashes in the sky, that flash and lighten before the rain; esloyde, esluyde, esludes, esloisdes, aleydonz in Old French.
Heb. מוצא, an expression of finding. i.e., He prepared a treasury for the wind, and there they are accessible to Him to send them on His mission.
Heb. בתוככי, like בתו in the midst.

text.title: O Lord, Your name is eternal:

pasuk.text: Like Your greatness and Your authority then, so is it also now, and You have the power to judge and to avenge us.

text.title: For the Lord will judge His people:

pasuk.text: He will judge their judgment from their enemies.
He will have another thought.

text.title: neither is there any breath in their mouth:

pasuk.text: There is not even any breath in their mouth like an animal. Now, since they have no breath [in the mouth], he need not explain [that they do not have] the breath of the nose. This אף is vowelized with a “pattah,” whereas (115:6): “they have a nose (אף) but they do not smell,” is vowelized with a “kamatz.” (This is not found in all editions.)
These are the proselytes (I found this).

text.title: To Him Who performs great wonders alone:

pasuk.text: In the beginning, no angel was created when He made the wonders: the heaven, the earth, the sun and the moon.

text.title: To Him Who smote the Egyptians with their firstborn:

pasuk.text: It does not say, “their firstborn,” but “with their firstborn.” The firstborn arose and beat their fathers’ legs because they detained Israel, when they heard about the tenth plague from Moses.
In twelve pieces for the twelve tribes.

Here he alluded to the thirty- one kings, and he compared for them Pharaoh and his host and the plagues of Egypt to mighty kings, harsher than they. Sihon was equal to all of them, [and Og was equal to all of them (Machzor Vitry)], each one individually, and so did he explain above (135: 11): “Sihon the king of the Amorites and Og the king of Bashan and all the kingdoms of Canaan.” So it is in the Aggadah.

text.title: Who remembered us in our humble state:

pasuk.text: In Egypt, He remembered us.
from their midst and performed all these wonders for us.
He alludes here to kindness (to all creatures).

text.title: Gives thanks to the God of heaven:

pasuk.text: Who prepares therein food for every creature. The expression, “for His kindness is eternal,” appears twenty-six times in this psalm, corresponding to the twenty-six generations that the world was without Torah and existed through the kindness of the Holy One, blessed be He.

text.title: By the rivers of Babylon, there we sat:

pasuk.text: when we went down into exile, and Nebuchadnezzar asked them to sing for him as they used to sing on the stage.
Willows of the brook.

Heb. ותוללינו, kinds of musical instruments that they hang up. This is how Menachem interpreted it (p. 184): וְתוֹלָלֵינוּ שמחה, and our musical instruments of joy. וְתוֹלָלֵינוּ can also be interpreted as: our enemies who would scorn and mock and joke with us, an expression of (102:9): “those who scorn me (מהוללי) swear by me.”

text.title: If I forget you, O Jerusalem:

pasuk.text: The congregation of Israel says this.

text.title: If I do not bring up Jerusalem:

pasuk.text: The remembrance of the mourning of its destruction I shall bring up to mention at the head of every joyous occasion of mine.

Heb. עָרוּ is an expression of destruction, and so (Jer. 51:58): “The broad walls of Babylon shall be overthrown (תתערער) ,” and so (Hab. 3:13): “baring (ערות) the foundation.” It is used only for something whose roots are uprooted from the ground.

text.title: before the princes I shall sing Your praises:

pasuk.text: before the eyes of the princes (kings).

text.title: for You magnified Your word over all Your names:

pasuk.text: Your name is mighty, jealous, and vengeful, but You magnified Your word, so that You skip over Your standards, over all Your names, and You forgive us.

When they heard the words of Your mouth: “You shall not murder; You shall not commit adultery,” they acknowledged the words of Your mouth: “I am [the Lord your God]” and “You shall have no [other god].” It is proper to make them first accept the yoke of His kingdom, and then He should levy all His decrees.
Heb. יידע, chastises, like (Jud. 8:16): “and with them he broke (ויודע) the men of Succoth.”

text.title: May the Lord agree with me:

pasuk.text: May He agree with my requests.
The Temple, about which is stated (Exod. 15:16): “Your hands established.”

text.title: You understand how to attach me from afar:

pasuk.text: You understand from afar [how] to attract me to Your friendship and to Your love.
Heb. לרעי, to attach me to You.

text.title: My going about and my lying down You encompassed:

pasuk.text: My way, my lying down, and my dwelling You have encompassed with a wall, for I can do nothing without Your knowledge.

heb. זרית, an expression of (Exod. 25:24): “a gold crown (זר).” Menachem associated it in this manner (p. 82). Our Sages, however, interpreted it (Nid. 31a, Mid. Ps. 139:3) as referring to the droplet of [semen, transmitted in] sexual intercourse, from whose choicest part the fetus is formed, and the meaning of זֵרִיתָ (זורה) is an expression of winnowing the grain to purify it of the refuse it contains.
Heb. הִסכנתה, you are accustomed.

text.title: From the rear and the front:

pasuk.text: My face and my back.
your coercion and your ruling, destroit in Old French.

text.title: Knowledge is hidden from me, etc.:

pasuk.text: A place to escape from You is covered up and hidden from me. (I found this.)

text.title: and if I make my bed:

pasuk.text: Heb. ואציעה, an expression of a spread (מצע) and a bed.

text.title: [If] I take up the wings of dawn:

pasuk.text: If I take up for myself the wings of dawn, which shine at once from one end of the world to the other, so will I fly swiftly until I dwell at the end of the sea.
If I said, “I will be hidden in the darkness, and the darkness will envelop me so that You will not see me.” יְשׁוּפֵנִי is an expression of נֶשֶׁף, evening.

text.title: “and the night will be dark about me”:

pasuk.text: Heb. אור, lit. light. And the night will darken before me. This אוֹר is an expression of darkness, like (Job 37: 11): “he spreads his clouds of darkness (אור) ” ; similarly (below 148:3), “all stars of the night (אור) ” ; similarly (Exod. 14:20), “and it darkened (ויאר) the night.”
there I have no asylum, for no darkness will obscure [anything] from You.

text.title: as darkness, so is the light:

pasuk.text: Both are the same to You.
which think all my thoughts.
Heb. תסכני, [equivalent to] תסוֹככני.
In sexual intercourse.

text.title: in the lowest parts of the earth:

pasuk.text: In the lowest compartment in my mother’s womb.

text.title: Your eyes saw my unformed body:

pasuk.text: From the time that You created the world, Your eyes saw all the forms of the coming generations.
Heb. גלמי. My splendor and the pattern of my form, before I was born and before I came into the world, Your eyes saw.

text.title: and on Your book they were all written:

pasuk.text: And all the creatures of the world, like me, like them, even all of them, before they were created, were together revealed before You.

text.title: days have been formed and one of them:

pasuk.text: All man’s deeds and the end of the days are revealed before You as if they were already formed, although not one of them was in existence, and not one was yet in the world. These are the wonders of God’s works and the way of His might, that future events are revealed to Him before they come. And so, Scripture says (Jer. 1:5): “When I had not yet formed you in the womb, etc.”

text.title: and on Your book, they were all written:
