pasuk.text: The book of the generations of man, which You showed to Adam.
lit. all of them will be written, like נכתבוּ.

text.title: days were formed without one of them:

pasuk.text: Ultimately, many days were destined to be created, but not one of them was yet created. According to the masoretic text, in which לא is written, this is its explanation. And according to the readingfor it is read לו this is its explanation: days have been formedHe showed the days that were destined to be created, and for His share, He chose one of them, viz. the Sabbath day. Another explanation: This is the Day of Atonement, for forgiveness.

text.title: And to me, how dear are Your friends:

pasuk.text: The congregation of Israel says, “How esteemed in my eyes are the righteous in every generation!”
The calculation of their counting, an expression of (Exod. 30:12): “When you take the sum (ראש) of the children of Israel.”

text.title: I shall count them… than sand:

pasuk.text: If I came to count the good of their deeds, they would be more numerous than sand.

text.title: I have come to the end, and I am still with You:

pasuk.text: Behold I have now come to the end of the generations that You allotted from then until today, and this generation is still with You and in fear of You, and I have not turned away from following You.

text.title: If only You would slay the wicked:

pasuk.text: If only You would slay the wicked.

text.title: Who mention You with wicked thought:

pasuk.text: They mention Your name regarding all the thoughts of their evil and call their deities with Your name.
Heb. נשוא, like נשאו, they took up.
Your enemies took up Your name in vain.

text.title: whether there is any vexatious way about me:

pasuk.text: Whether there is a way of vexation and deterioration in me.

text.title: every day they gather to wage war:

pasuk.text: There will be wars in their dwellings and in their settlements.

Heb. חמתעכשוב. חמת is an expression of venom, as (Deut. 32:33): “the venom of (חמת) dragons is their wine,” for if you interpret it as an expression of wrath, does an expression of wrath fit with wine? Rather, it is an expression of venom, venimos in Old French. Similarly, here the term venom relates to “under the lips.”
Heb. עכשוב, a spider, araignee in French.

text.title: and [with] ropes they spread a net:

pasuk.text: It is customary to tie a long rope to the end of a net, and when the hunter sees the birds resting under the net, he draws the rope, and the net falls on the birds.
Beside my paths and my steps.
Heb. ליד, like (II Sam. 14:30): “See, Joab’s field is near mine (ידי).”
The wicked Esau.
Heb. ירומו סלה, because they are arrogant always. Our Rabbis, however (Gen. Rabbah 75:9) explained זממוֹ as an expression of a bit that muzzles the camel, and it is a mishnaic expression.
Heb. תפק אל, Do not take it out of his jaws.

text.title: The numbers of those who surround me:

pasuk.text: Armies of the number of the troops of Esau who plan to surround me, may the lies of their lips cover them. (I found.)
May the coals descend on them. Let them lie upon them until they sink and become extinguished by themselves. The body will thus disintegrate and disappear.

text.title: He will cast them into fire:

pasuk.text: He Who casts and avenges [will cast them] into the fire of Gehinnom.
He will cast them so that they will no longer rise.
Heb. במהמרות, in wars and strife, an expression of (Deut. 9:4): “You have been rebellious (ממרים).”
Esau, who would trap with his mouth.
The evil that he does will trap him.
that ultimately the Lord will perform the judgment of a poor man, and He will avenge the vengeance of His servants.
May he hasten and do it so that the righteous will thank His name.
What I lift up my hands to You.

text.title: O Lord, place a guard for my mouth:

pasuk.text: when I pray before You, that I should speak poetically, that it should be acceptable.
That is the upper lip (like portals of my lips).
May my heart not be inclined toward evil.

text.title: and may I not partake of their feasts:

pasuk.text: And I shall not sit at their feasts.

text.title: May a righteous man strike me with kindness and reprove me:

pasuk.text: It is better that a true and righteous prophet reprove me and chastise me, for all his blows and his reproof are kindness.

text.title: may the oil of the anointment of my head not turn my head away:

pasuk.text: The royal oil that was poured onto my head, as it is said (above 23:5): “You anointed my head with oil,” should not turn my head away from the reproof of the righteous man, to go and eat bread with the workers of iniquity.
For as long as my prayer is in my mouth, it is about the evils of the workers of iniquity, that I should not stumble on them.

text.title: Their judges were led astray by [their hearts of] stone:

pasuk.text: For the judges and leaders of these [people] have been led astray from the good way by the evil inclination and the heart of stone, and it is as hard as a rock.

[my] pleasant [words], which I speak of the commandments, and they do not repent of their evil way. Our Rabbis in the Baraitha of Sifrei (Deut. 3:23) interpreted it concerning Moses and Aaron, but I cannot reconcile the end of the verse with its beginning. I can perhaps reconcile it and say that in stubbornness, these people equal the stubbornness of those through whom Moses and Aaron died through the rock, for these too heard the pleasant words but do not repent.
wood.
So were our bones scattered to reach the entrance of death because of the evils of the transgressors.
Heb. פלח, an expression of splitting, as (Job 16:13): “He splits my kidneys.”

text.title: For to You, etc., are my eyes:

pasuk.text: This goes back to the above verses (3f.): Place a guard for my mouth… Do not incline… for to You… are my eyes, etc.

text.title: do not cast out my soul:

pasuk.text: Heb. אל תער. Do not cast me from before You, like (Gen. 24:20): “and emptied (ותער) her pitcher into the watering trough.”

text.title: May the wicked fall… into his nets:

pasuk.text: May the wicked man himself fall into his nets that he spreads at my feet.
where he severed the skirt of Saul’s robe.
how many snares are in it.
Among all of Saul’s servants, there is no one who protests against him.

text.title: because of me the righteous will crown You:

pasuk.text: Because of me, the righteous will crown You and give thanks to Your name, for You support those who fear You.
to realize the promise that You promised me.

text.title: For an enemy pursued my soul:

pasuk.text: That is to say: If I have sinned before You, behold, I have suffered. This psalm was recited as referring to all of Israel in Babylon.
Heb. ישתומם, an expression of daze and astonishment, like (Ezek. 3:15): “and I remained there overwhelmed (משמים) among them seven days.” Also (II Sam. 13:20): “and Tamar sat, overwhelmed (ושוממה).”

text.title: I remember the days of yore:

pasuk.text: when You performed for us many wondrous miracles.
in exile.
If one longs and does not attain, it is called the pining of the eyes and the pining of the spirit.
When the redemption sprouts. (I found.)

text.title: let me know the way in which I am to go; I lift up my soul:

pasuk.text: that You accept my request.
My tribulations I conceal from all men to tell them to You.

Who flattens and spreads out my people to rest in its place, as (Job 12:23): He spreads out (שוטח) the nations." He makes them great. רוֹדֵד is the Aramaic translation of רוֹקַע, as the Targum renders (Exod. 39:3): וַיְרַקְעוּ, and they spread out; וְרַדִּידוּ. Others interpret הרודד, Who weakens peoples under me. But in an accurate revised version, [the reading is]: עמי, upon which the Masorah states: In three cases, the meaning is עמים, peoples, but the reading is עמי, and on תחתי, it says: the reading is תחתיו, under Him.
What are Persia [Esau, acc. to mss.] and Ishmael before You that You know them to lavish greatness upon them?

text.title: his days are as a fleeting shadow:

pasuk.text: Solomon said (Ecc. 6:12): “that he do them like a shadow,” but he did not explain whether [this refers to] the shadow of a palm or the shadow of a wall, which are permanent. His father already explained, “as a fleeting shadow,” the shadow of a flying bird.
פצני, take me out. That is an expression of saving, and so is (verse 10): “Who delivers (הפוצה) David His servant.” (I found.)

Scripture connects vanity with the mouth and falsehood with the right hand. When they come to tell with their mouth, they invent exaggerations of vanity, even to misrepresent what is known. If they come to stretch forth their right hand to swear, they refrain from vanity, lest they be caught as thieves, but they do swear falsely, for so is their lot.

This speaks about the Rock of the Divisions, when David was close to being seized by Saul (I Sam. 23:27): “A messenger came to Saul, saying, ‘Make haste and go, etc.’” He saved Saul from shedding innocent blood, and David from being killed.
As You delivered me then, so shall You deliver me now.
That is to say that now too this generation is righteous.
which have no blemish, so pure are they from sin. (I found.)
with this good name, that they are like saplings in their youth, growing all their lives; and this praise cannot be substantiated except in the generation of Hezekiah.
are of tall, beautiful stature like the cornerstones of a stone house, in which the cornerstones are placed exactly one opposite the other, and it ascends upward until the corners are even.

text.title: praised as the form of the Temple:

pasuk.text: Praised by those who see them and compare them to the form of the height of the Temple. Our Rabbis, however, explained:
Full of desire as the corners of the altar are full of blood, but they are intimate only with their husbands.
The corners of our storehouses are full of goodness.
Supplying food from year to year.
Heb. מזן אל זן, from the time of the ingathering of this year’s food until the time of the ingathering of next year’s food. זַן is gouvernayl in Old French, food, provisions.
They produce offspring of thousands and ten thousands.
The great princes among us are borne by those smaller than they, for the small ones obey the greater ones, the result being that there is no breach among us.
No bad news goes far away.
There is no sound of the confusion of war.

text.title: Praiseworthy is the people that has this:

pasuk.text: That has all this good.

text.title: Generation to generation will praise Your works:

pasuk.text: And I, too, shall speak of the majesty of the glory of Your splendor.

text.title: And the strength of Your awesome deeds they will tell:

pasuk.text: And I, too, shall recite Your greatness.

text.title: Of the remembrance of Your abundant goodness they will speak:

pasuk.text: i.e., one generation to another generation.

text.title: and they will speak of Your might:

pasuk.text: to each other, saying, “It is good for us to make known to the children of men His mighty deeds and the glory of the majesty of the kingdom of the Holy One, blessed be He.” (I found.)

(The “nun” is missing from the “aleph-beth” because David saw in it a serious downfall [Amos 5:2]: “The virgin of Israel has fallen and shall not continue to rise.” And he returned and supported her with the holy spirit: The Lord supports all those who fall.)

text.title: and satisfy every living thing [with] its desire:

pasuk.text: With a sufficiency to sustain him, He satisfies his goodness, his will, and his blessing.
Heb. רצון, apayement in Old French, propitiation.

text.title: My mouth will speak the praise of the Lord:

pasuk.text: and also all flesh will bless His holy name forever and ever.
Heb. בעודי.
Heb. עשתונותיו his thoughts.

is he in whose help is the God of Jacob, for the Holy One, blessed be He, promised him (Gen. 28: 15): “Behold I am with you, and I shall guard You, etc., and I shall return you.” Now why is He praiseworthy? Because He made heaven and earth and the sea, and since all is His, He has the power to guard him on the sea and on dry land; but a mortal king, although he watches him on dry land, cannot watch him on the sea.
To the end of many generations, He fulfills and keeps the truth of His promise.
Heb. יעודד, an expression of strength.
He will perpetuate His kingdom with the redemption of His children.

text.title: For it is good to sing:

pasuk.text: For it is good to sing to Him.
Heb. לחמה, lit. its bread.
Our Sages explained that he [the raven] is cruel to his offspring, and the Holy One, blessed be He, has pity on them and prepares for them gnats from their excrement, which enter their mouths.

text.title: He does not desire the might of the horse:

pasuk.text: [i.e.,] the Holy One, blessed be He.

text.title: nor does He take pleasure in the legs of man:

pasuk.text: nor does He want the swiftness of the running of the legs of man.
Heb. חלב, lit. fat. The best, fat wheat kernels.
Heb. כפור, jelede in Old French.

text.title: He hurls His ice like crumbs:

pasuk.text: The water congeals and becomes crumbs. [According to] Midrash Aggadah:
Everything [is] according to the burden of the people: the poor manaccording to his lack of clothing, He is lenient with him.
that he should not become chilled from His cold?

text.title: He sends His word and melts them:

pasuk.text: those crumbs.
The west wind, to get rid of the ice, and water runs.
Heb. כוכבי אור, stars of the night.
to them, that this one should serve by day and that one should serve by night.
That decree.
Heb. תנינים, huge fish.
Heb. וברד, gresle or grezle in Old French, hail.
Heb. שלג, neyf or nayf in old French, snow.
וקיטור, an expression of a mist called bruine or broine in Old French, mist, fog.

which performs His word and His mission. Our Sages said (Chag. 12b): These things were originally hidden in heaven, and David came and brought them down to earth because they are kinds of punishment, and it is not fitting for them to be hidden in the dwellings of the Holy One, blessed be He.

text.title: Lofty praises of God in their throats:

pasuk.text: and they will be for them a double-edged sword.
Heb. בזקים, chains.

(Ezek. 2:14) “And I shall lay My vengeance, etc.” If you ask [challenge] that Ezekiel was not yet born when David said this, [I will answer that] David prophesied about the end of the redemption, and when the end comes, the judgment will have been written for a long time.
Heb. במנים ועגב. They are kinds of musical instruments.

Heb. בצלצלי שמע, cymbals that let a sound be heard. שָׁמַע is a noun, like שֶׁמַע, with a “segol,” but because of the “ethnactha” [which denotes a pause], it is vowelized with a long “kamatz,” and therefore, its accent is above, under the “shin.”
